review_text: Deeply unlikeable protagonist (though Racal is a surprisingly good actress, why can't Filipino actors act this naturalistically?!), annoying kid actors whose characters add nothing worthwhile to the story, there's a confusingly written subplot involving another young girl, terribly limp ending, this movie treats Piolo Pascual's pastor like the villain when he's the only morally admirable character in the whole film, which is just one way this film's moral compass is completely topsy-turvy. Oh, the moral rot of the liberal Filipino mind.

jadaone never fails to deliver a movie that starts strong but falls flat and chokes on the message itâ€™s attempting to tell, whatever that may be. every story she writes is abysmal and surface level and almost always advocates for shallow feminism, hanggang doon nalang ba tayo? spouting for womenâ€™s rights without actually understanding the nuance of what youâ€™re actually advocating for?maliban sa poverty porn na kinatutuwaan ipakita palagi ni jadaone, from fan girl to sunshine, she also likes showcasing sexual assault as a plot device, only this time it wasnâ€™t shown to us explicitlyâ€”wow, how sheâ€™s advanced in her writing noh? (sarcasm meant)while i appreciate the gritty and emotional moments of the film especially when the focus is entirely on the movieâ€™s protagonist who itâ€™s named after (maris carried this entire film along with the supporting castâ€™s acting) itâ€™s overshadowed by itâ€™s dogshit abysmal surface level performative writing, its inclusion of imaginary children that is either a representation of the characters and their inner child or their unborn children which confuses and irritates me as theyâ€™re shown way too much, the on the nose messaging of conservatism in the philippines, the lack of detail on how important sunshineâ€™s dream actually is because it focuses on another separate character that rids sunshine a chunk of her story and conflict, and the abstract, hollow message theyâ€™re trying to advocate for.genuinely, can we take the pen away from this grown ass woman? not only does she exploit the masa to serve her story but women as well, nakakabastos sa totoo lang, not very feminist and not very for the masa alsoâ€”add to the fact that jadaone probably thinks that her audience is stupid and canâ€™t read in between the lines for how she chooses to write the story. more actions, less words sana, more time spent in the writerâ€™s room, less color-grading and filming quiapoâ€™s slums for your poverty porn sana.i could say more but iâ€™d have to give half a star at least for the castâ€™s amazing performances, they carried this film, and they deserve the recognition especially maris racal. also nagulat ako andito pala si piolo pascual haha.

In the Philippines, Catholicism is the predominant religion comprising around 80% of the population. Because of the churchâ€™s influence, the countryâ€™s policy is restrictive and conservative, especially regarding family planning. Considering the social context, Jadaoneâ€™s attempt to address the topic of abortion is certainly admirable, but the simplistic and tear-jerking way it is done leaves much to be desired.asianmoviepulse.com/2025/02/film-review-sunshine-2024-by-antoinette-jadaone/

Maraming binukas to na diskurso, pero walang sinara. Ang pinaka-statement ng pelikula patungkol sa teenage/unwanted pregnancy ay: my body, my rules. Na sa kabilang banda ay tama naman, na sa kabilang banda ay hungkag na konseptong liberal. Nakita ng bida ang iba't ibang side ng unwanted pregnancy sa bansa, tulad nung nangyari sa 13 yrs old na side character na lumpen na ginagahasa ng kanyang tito sa tulong ng kanyang mama. Hindi yon unwanted pregnancy dulot ng sarili niyang kapasyahan na makipagtalik ng walang proteksyon. Bunga ito ng sistematikong exploitasyon ng kabataang kababaihan bilang pambayad utang ng kanilang mga magulang. Isa sa mga sanga ng patriyarkal na pananamantala sa sistemang kapital. Ang tanong ngayon ay anong epekto nito sa bida. Ang sagot ay wala. Chase your dreams, choose yourself, my body, my rules.Kahit sa background, walang hudyat ng pagtutol. Ng paglaban para sa abortion. Ng panawagan para sa kapakanan ng mga kabataan at kababaihan. Ng pagtuligsa sa sistemang lumilikha ng uring lumpen. Kaya as much as social commentary ito ng sitwasyon ng kababaihan sa bansa, hungkag at supot ito dahil hindi ito makalahatang panig. Ikumpara halimbawa sa Maynila ni Lino Brocka, kung saan sa kabila ng hindi pagsali ni Julio sa mga protesta, ay nandoon palagi ang mga aktibista, sa likod ng bida, sumisiksik bilang background noise sa panahon ng kanyang mga paglilimi. Ang pakikibaka ay nariyan, ang pelikula ay isang behikulo ng social commentary para ipakita ang lahat ng nariyan.Sa kabila ng husay ng pelikula na buksan ang usapin patungkol sa abortion, kulang na kulang ito sa pagtulak ng kampanya. Pulitikal ang sinusubukan pasukin ng pelikula, pero takot itong pumanig at pinipilit pumagitna. Sumatotal, ang liberalistang posisyon sa abortion e humahantong sa charity para sa mga nasa laylayan na hindi nakakatamasa ng 'my body, my rules' dahil wala sila sa pusisyon para talaga mamili. Nakakaiyak, oo, nakakabagabag damdamin. Nakakagalit, oo, pero ano ngayon? Ang husay ng mga mamemelikula ay bigyan direksyon ang audience sa kung anong dapat gawin pagkatapos -- lalo na social commentary. Ano ang landas palabas ng reyalidad na inilalahad ng kwento? Pano tayo aalpas sa patriyarkal-kapitalistang kuntsabahan na nananamantala sa ating mga kababaihan? Ano ang landas palabas ng pelikula? Dapat marunong mag-imagine ang socially-aware na mamemelikula kung paano babaguhin ang reyalidad na sinasalamin niya sa kanyang pelikula. Sa ganitong pamantayan, palyado ang pelikula sa kanyang agenda. Ang pagpapamulat ay dapat laging tumatagos sa pagpapakilos.

For a movie that capitalizes on the pain and injustice that continues to harm Philippine women every day, I expected . Sunshine learns to forgive herself for choosing not to have the child. That's a strong message to have, especially in this political and religious climate. Women should feel empowered to decide. But while the film builds its emotional core around that choice, it also gestures at larger social issues that it never fully grapples with. The unborn child becomesâ€¦

SUNSHINE advances itself as a film about bodily autonomy in a nation that denies its very terminology, yet it does so through the insulated idiom of psychological realism rather than the concretised mapping of the material conditions that make autonomy, abortion, and girlhood existentially precarious. We are immersed in affect, but the structure underpinning these sensations is left either ambient or altogether unrendered. Yes, the pharmacy exists as a moral space and the hospital as carceral, but where is the livelihood? Who funds the training? What does it mean, materially, to be a 19-year-old athleteâ€”and an international one, at thatâ€”with no visible labouring parent and no bread line to back it up?Abortion is outlawed in the Philippines because it preserves state-church power and results in the reproductive labour of the poor as exploitable and their agency criminal, but to bracket class from the narrativeâ€”in a context where economic vulnerability is the foremost determinant of reproductive injusticeâ€”is consequential. Instead, the endless deferral into mood, while expressive, is in itself a seductive alibi for political disengagement. I understand that this is a film of interiorityâ€”that the point is to reflect Sunshineâ€™s constrained perceptual fieldâ€”but her interiority is a response to economic realities that the film chooses to elude, and when the audience is asked to interpolate systemic weight from ambience without any clear depiction of how deprivation functions, what we get is an abstraction that parades as empathy, and from that abstraction, other evasions proliferate: the neoliberal myth of the meritocratic athlete, whose suffering must be understood as psychological strain rather than as infrastructural abandonment; the convenient fiction that ambition alone propels a body through state-sponsored regimes without subsidy or the material realities the film forgoes. To abstract oppression into psychic distress then, while refusing its logistical origins, is to risk reproducing the same symbolic economy the Church relies upon: one in which the body is meaningful only as a metaphor and a vessel onto which morality is projected.This aesthetic disposition of interiority is of course obviously a structure inherited from the exportable idiom of European festival realism where the trauma of the Filipina is depicted legibly for the global North. From this perspective, it would make sense that the institutions that manufacture her precarity are rendered as emotional rather than historical, inviting the audience to feel with her but never to accountâ€”but by doing so, what emerges is not so much a Filipino film but a Filipino offering: an artefact of pain rendered in tones familiar to jurors abroad, a choice that aligns seamlessly with both (1) Jadaoneâ€™s career pivot into the international circuit, having premiered the film at Berlinale and TIFF, and (2) the filmâ€™s own final sequence: Sunshine performing her routine at the SEA games before a panel of foreign adjudicators, body taut and calibrated for approval by those who will never understand the weight of what she forfeited to arrive there. By naming these two parallels do we metabolise the rage of a system into something palatable and interpretable, and since both Jadaone and Sunshine must contort to be seen, in being seen, they are asked to become less what they mean. Perhaps the question is not whether SUNSHINE fails as a film or recedes as an offering, but whether it was ever permitted the autonomy to be anything elseâ€”whether within the landscape of Philippine cinema, where funding is precarious, distribution systems anaemic, and state culture support present only for the films that do not threaten it, a film like SUNSHINE must already enter the frame pre-legibilised and pre-digested, its rage ironed out for export. This is, after all, by the admission of its own producer Bianca Balbuena, a film that delayed its domestic release in order â€˜to premiere in top festivals [around] the world to create noise and curiosityâ€™, with the implication that only through international approval could the film attain enough value to justify its own existence at home. Thus, to resist the very circuit that enables its existence is impossible, but recognising this sharpens our understanding of the conditions under which those evasions occur. What we must ask, then, is what kind of complicity we are willing to forgive in a nation that punishes truth so severely that even its cinema must contort just to be heard.

I had been waiting a long time to watch Sunshine, especially since I never got the chance to see it on the big screen. So, when it finally arrived on Netflix, I was so excited, only for that excitement to fade the longer I watched.The premise is undeniably compelling: a young gymnast discovers sheâ€™s pregnant just as her lifelong dream of reaching the Olympics is within reach. Itâ€™s a setup filled with emotional stakes and potential for a powerful, character-driven story.But instead of exploring her dedication to the sport, the film shifts almost entirely to her pregnancy and her attempts to deal with it. I kept waiting for scenes that would show her fighting for her dream, intense training, the pressure of competition, the physical and emotional toll of gymnastics, but those moments never really come. The narrative focuses more on side characters and subplots that feel unnecessary and, frankly, uninteresting.I couldnâ€™t help comparing this film to other international athlete biopics that portray the grit, passion, and relentless work behind the journey. Sunshine had all the ingredients to deliver that kind of inspiring story, but it simply doesnâ€™t stick the landing.Overall, Iâ€™m disappointed. With a stronger focus on the athletic journey and the challenges of balancing an unexpected pregnancy with Olympic ambitions, this could have been a much more compelling and memorable film

I feel like it never really lands on its feet.What do you meanâ€”they leave it open-ended pa?! I almost punched the wall.Give ko though, kasi I like the fact that this film depict Manila in its realistic formâ€”hindi niromanticize at hindi poverty-porn-ish.

I really wanted to give this a five-star rating because it garnered accolades internationally. Sadly, there isnâ€™t much to love after watching it (I mostly blame the writing).It started strong, not gonna lie â€” the pressure and obstacles hindering her chance to become an Olympic gymnast were compelling. Then came that scene â€” her inner voice? The amalgamation of being a future mother? Or just a little kid guiding her throughout the movie? Okay, neat.After that, more happens around her, but nothing happens with the main character (the gymnast storyline disappears until the ending). The film also tries to touch on the status of abortion in the Philippines, but it falls flat and feels unnecessary.Still, hats off to the director for tackling one of the taboo topics here in the Philippines, even if it could have been executed better.

The filmâ€™s most striking stroke lies in its visualization of fetuses within two pregnant womenâ€™s wombs as tangible, living childrenâ€”these vivid little figures, like walking metaphors of life, infuse the work with poignant symbolic weight. Regrettably, the thin screenplay structure and somewhat lackluster overall execution still cannot mask their flaws; they fail to fully nurture this unique metaphorical expression, nor do they successfully ground the depth of the topic or the emotional resonance of the characters.

It's a rather decent take on the current status of the Philippine status quo on women's health and the healthcare system in general. Rather a hit and miss for me with the kids being a figure of speech so to speak and that the little kid's dream is also Sunshine's dream being the same but should have been clear that both won't be able to meet as per the dialogues. Story-wise, everything somehow fell into place in such a way that all the things that could have been possible in terms of occurrences akin to a deus ex machina of sorts, giving the sense that everything was too good to be true - still, point stands; it's a great film to talk about and amazingly delivers points that we should discuss more of a society, especially when it concerns the lives of women, children, and the difficulties of being a woman in a third world country.<<Objectively, story continuity could have been better which could have convinced me of giving it a higher score.>>

the film hits too close to home for me. sunshine is suffocating, and maybe that's a directorial choice. it hits in the most uncomfortable and painful parts of me at times. it resonates with every woman who has to determine a better choice out of two shitty choices: one that might shackle her freedom or one that may free her but haunt her at the same time. it makes you feel rage at systemic failures which birth a backward society that villifies women for their lapses of judgment--damned if they do, damned if they don't. sunshine is linear in its plot. it never really takes you out of sunshine's head, so you see how raw everything is, how immature she is, how she's desperate and breaking apart but trying to keep it together, and how she's just a kid who fucked up. the film works because of this approach, albeit some plot devices are too on the nose--making them iffy and questionable, and may have muddled the film's stance. there are obvious plot holes, little details that could have enriched the world-building were overlooked. some subplots lack depth, but the performances made me look past on these things, in a sense that it was pleasant enough to watch for me. not for everyone, but everyone should be part of the discussion. jadaone's films are usually hits-or-misses for me, but sunshine is one of her better ones. the message may be clear and hopeful, but real life presents a much darker truth: for most women, there are no olympics and dreams to hold on to. in reality, we still have a long way to go in paving for a more humane society for filipino women.here's to working towards a future where women are not shamed for reclaiming their agency, and where their indiscretions are not berated and ridiculed, but treated with proper education and compassion.

Sunshine (Maris Racal) is a record-breaking national athlete, but the film fails to show the weight of that achievement.She wears a tank top marked â€œAsian Games 2018,â€ and her coach (Meryll Soriano) warns her against complacency: â€œBalewala lahat ng gold mo sa Asian Games.â€Since the Asian Games are held every four years, and Sunshine is about 19 or 20, this suggests she won multiple golds in 2018 â€” a rare feat. She would be gymnastics royalty, a media darling, likely the most successful Filipina rhythmic gymnast in history.Yet the film doesnâ€™t show her as a public figure. No news clippings, no media buzz, no crowdsâ€”just a few kids asking for a selfie. It also focuses mostly on her ribbon routine, barely showing the hoop, ball, or clubsâ€”all key to establishing her as Olympic-level.Sunshineâ€™s decision to abort is quick, and her fears and ambitions are underexplored. The Olympics, in fact, feel more like her coachâ€™s dreamâ€”the film tells us this but doesnâ€™t show it.Thereâ€™s no pressure from a country rooting for her, nor from sponsors who presumably funded her expensive training (which weâ€™re left to assume, since rhythmic gymnastics is an elite sport). No rival gymnast, no sense of competition, no major stakes, and no real glimpse into the demanding world of elite sport.All this undercuts the tension around her unwanted pregnancy.Jadaone instead spends a chunk of screen time on soapy magical realism. An imaginary, foul-mouthed child follows Sunshine around, mocking her decisions. But instead of adding insight, this character becomes repetitive and irritating.Rhed Bustamante plays another pregnant teen, awkwardly inserted into the plot in an effort to cover too many sides of the abortion debate. But Rhedâ€™s more serious situation makes Sunshineâ€™s dilemma feel shallowâ€”like a story about a girl careless with sex and unwilling to face the consequences.Some visuals in Sunshine hit hard: abortifacients sold beside religious icons outside Quiapo Churchâ€”a jab at how the Catholic Church, in practice, is more ritual than moral compass. Thereâ€™s also a grim motel scene. But these moments canâ€™t save the film.Set in the predominantly Catholic Philippines, where abortion is illegal, Sunshine tries to raise issues around teen pregnancy and reproductive rights, like overcrowded maternity wards. True enough, the Philippines has one of the highest teenage pregnancy rates in Southeast Asia, especially among the poor.But if a film brings this up, it must give some context. The Reproductive Health Law, passed only in 2012, was meant to helpâ€”but the Catholic Bishopsâ€™ Conference of the Philippines (CBCP) continues to fight tooth and nail against sex education and birth control.The film ignores all this. Instead, it gives us a cartoonish, Bible-thumping doctor and a patriarchal pastorâ€”villains standing in for real problems. We donâ€™t expect to be spoon-fed, but when a film enters controversial ground and hints at bigger issues, it has a duty to avoid shallow symbols.In the end, Sunshine parrots Western slogans like â€œMy body, my choiceâ€ without anchoring its stance in the Philippine context. The message feels imported and emotionally flat.ğŸ”´READ FULL REVIEW (DAILY TRIBUNE): https://tribune.net.ph/2025/07/26/sunshine-review-abortion-tale-misses-the-mark

Maris is nothing but a big revelation of a great artist

Switching between goofy magic realism, teenage coming-of-age clichÃ©s and a gritty look at the reality of trying to get an abortion in the Philippines â€” which is prohibited in the constitution itself â€” Sunshine is a heartfelt story with an angry edge. Maris Racal stars as the wonderfully-named Sunshine Francisco, an aspiring gymnast whose potential tryouts at the Olympics are derailed by an unexpected pregnancy. With no officials to turn to, she is forced to search the black market, where she is followed by a strange young girl (Annika Co) who appears to be a figment of her imagination (itâ€™s obvious when no one else interacts!). While the film certainly draws awareness to this issue of womenâ€™s rights in the Philippines, Jadaoneâ€™s cornier tendencies overwhelm the message.Part of our Berlinale Generation coverage

Iâ€™ll be honest, underwhelming siya for me. Siguro kasi sobrang dami ko nang nakitang ganitong atake sa short films at full-length lalo na kapag tungkol sa abortion kaya hindi na bago sa paningin ko. The movie is a very honest look at young pregnancy in the Philippines. Although the transitions between scenes were clumsy and the acting of some actors felt too much, the film's message came through.It highlights how laws, beliefs and traditions often do not help women here, and shines a light on many serious problems in the Philippines, such as poor healthcare, unsupportive laws and economic disparity. Itâ€™s an eye-opener for privileged viewers and should make people who have power over these issues think deeply. I also liked the ending, which felt subtle yet a strong push for change.

I'm still rooting for Jadaone and some other directors to make more realistic and relatable mainstream drama films.

Admirable effort to tackle abortion, a huge taboo in a largely Catholic population. I can commend it for what it tries to speak up about which is how abortion should be an option for the women in this country, which I can definitely agree with. It even brings up the age old question of â€œIf youâ€™re against abortion what about a child that is a victim of rape?â€ through that one character. However, Itâ€™s all very on the nose, and leaves me wanting more about Sunshineâ€™s motivations, more into the psychological unraveling as she grapples with her situation (that isnâ€™t just her seeing those kids), I wouldâ€™ve loved to have seen more about her dynamics with her sister who is a single mother. I wanted the film to really expound on her emotions, not just kids being a figment of her imagination being used as a way to talk about her feelings without showing it. It all just felt a bit cliche, and the ending was such a cop out for me, I wanted to see her make that choice, grapple with its moral dilemma and watch her claw her way back to be in tip top shape for the nationals and then the Olympics.

I love that Antoinette Jadaone got to make a film about such an important issue with a big star as its lead. However, depicting Sunshineâ€™s unborn child as the opposite of thatâ€”a fully grown child that is even capable of swearing and questioning her motherâ€™s decisionsâ€”defeats the purpose of the film. That way of thinking is exactly why we are not making any progress in legalizing abortion. In a truly pro-choice film, the story would only be about how Sunshine deserves to be safe and supported as she pursues her athletic ambitions. For a film that boldly criticizes closed-minded Christians, I found it confusing why it was simultaneously trying to seem neutral by giving the pro-life argument some representation. I thought it was going to be braver than that. On top of the ambiguity of its politics is the underwhelming presentation of what is at stake for Sunshine. Many scenes still felt a little too shallow, quick, and simple. As if the film is telling me a story Iâ€™m supposed to already know. For a supposedly hard-hitting film, not much was framed as a revelation. Iâ€™m just disappointed because this was heavily marketed as a groundbreaking film, yet with a lack of a clear vision, it seems like itâ€™s not helping us move at all.

oo, maganda ang pagkakagawa sa pelikula. magaling ang performance, lalo na ni maris at ni jennica. yung sound design, walang kapantay - iyong tunog ng pagdaan ng lrt dapat bigyan ng award. gusto ko rin na, kaiba sa mga pinapag-international, hindi nag-bobrocka cosplay na wala namang amor sa masa (alam na kung sino). hindi nauwi sa maynila masikip mabaho mahirap tapos hindi naman pinapag-isip ang nanonood.ayun nga lang, kung iisipin, mukhang hindi talaga para sa pilipino ito. ibig kong sabihin, yung intervention ng sunshine sa usapin ng abortion ay nakakawing sa political discourse ng amerika. kumbaga, yung wika ng us sinubukang isalin dito. para bang gustong sabihin na, di lang kayo, may bodily autonomy din kami sa pinas. malinaw naman kung para kanino to kahit hindi mo alam na sa berlin unang pinalabas. yung mga subtitle halimbawa - yung 3.5k naging 70 dollars.hindi naman din problema na magkuwento para sa tagalabas. may mga punto nga na incisive ang pagbasa sa kulturang nirerepresenta. halimbawa, yung buong eksena sa motel, hindi magagawa nang ganoon kung hindi babad sa maynila. isa pa, sharp observation yung pag-introduce ng religious element bukod sa Simbahang Katoliko - laganap nga naman iyong mga evangelical prosperity gospel ngayon (saka yung cameo!). sa kabilang banda, sa pananaw ko, may mga malalaking bagay na hindi nakuha nang tumpak o na-miss. sa pananaw ko, hindi na angkop gamiting proxy para sa konserbatismo sa lipunan ang Simbahan, una dahil hindi naman na ganoon kalakas ang hatak nito at pangalawa, sa sobrang pagka-urong ng lipunan natin ay progresibong pwersa kung wawariin ang Simbahan. ipagpipilit ko itong dalawang punto dahil nadadaanan ko tuwing magsisimba iyong mural sa gilid ng simbahan na "sa gobyernong tapat, angat buhay lahat" na after three years ay hindi pa rin tinatabunan.pero sa tingin ko, mas malaking kakulangan yung nabiting konsiderasyon sa materyal na kalagayan ng mga tauhan. maganda kung paano ipinakita yung socioeconomic status ni sunshine, na hindi gaanong mayaman (kumpara kay miggy) at hindi rin gaanong kahirap (kumpara kay mary grace). nakakaattend sa private school, malamang siguro gawa ng scholarship, pero hindi kalakihan ang bahay na inuuwian. kaso, hindi na binalikan nang mabili na niya yung gamot. iyong lahat ng pinagdaanan ni mary grace, parang naging tuntungan lang ng internal at external resolution ni sunshine. kumbaga, hindi gaanong interesado ang pelikula na pag-usapan ang socioeconomic na aspekto ng usaping abortion. gawa nga siguro ng intensiyon na makipag-usap sa wika ng mga american liberal. hindi naman talaga lapat sa konteksto dito itong non-intersectional idpol - wala namang roe at walang supreme court na bumaliktad sa roe kaya nag-imbento na lang ng mga walang kwentang doktor para humaliling kalaban.sa dulo, masaya na si sunshine at nagpeperform para sa mga banyagang judge. may mga review na ditong nagsabi na parallel sa karanasan ni direk jadaone na sinadyang ipalabas muna sa international festivals itong gawa niya. nanalo pa nga ito sa berlinale. samantala, may panawagang i-boycott ang berlin film fest ngayong taon bilang bahagi ng mas malawak na kilusang i-boycott ang mga cultural events sa germany na siyang pangalawang pinakamalaking arms provider sa israel. hindi sa gusto kong i-cancel si direk o ang pelikula (sa mga usapan tulad nito tungkol sa frankfurt book fair, lumalabas na may lehitimong dahilan para lumahok), pero hindi rin maiwasang ipagtabi ang moral-ideological na posisyon ng pelikula sa komplisidad sa genocide ng mga nagtatanghal at nagbibigay-premyo dito - lalo na't mayorya sa mga biktima ng genocide sa Gaza ay babae at bata. kung iisipin, mas sukdulang nakakabahala ang kalagayan ng reproductive health sa Palestine dahil nga pati mga ospital at klinik ay binobomba ng israel. hindi naman nakakabawas sa gustong sabihin ng pelikula, pero hindi na rin talaga maikaila na hindi para sa atin. mas para sa k-hive siguro.interesanteng i-kumpara sa hinugot sa langit, isa sa mga huling pelikula ni ishmael bernal. halos parehas din ang kuwento sa sunshine, parehas ng pinagdaanan at pinagpasyahan si maris at si maricel (uy, tita ni coach). parehas nga siguro ng moral position itong dalawa. pero noong pinanood ko noon, hindi ko naisip na may ibang kinakausap na taga-states. hindi ko rin maisip kung bakit. pero may full movie sa youtube. baka okay na panoorin ulit. It's decent to say the least, it's a Jadaone movie for Jadaone fans. But that's the thing, it's myopic that it themes and logic of the narrative presented is as only limited as the filmmaker's worldview to say the least, or rather it is limited to how Jadaone sees the subject matter in regards to abortion and having an agency which is told in such a simplistic way, lacking that empathy and how objective it is. However, I commend the script to call out against the prejudiced perception but that's how it is, it did not hold accountable to it, and while Sunshine had conviction to make her decision in the end, and matters in her own hands, it didn't feel unearned to be honest. Like who is Sunshine to the audience, as a main character? Why do the audience should root for her, I think the screenplay failed to make its audience care and thank god Maris Racal made it somehow work because she did put effort to act in those dramatic scenes and it shows she's into that role, kudos for putting an extra work on gymnastic scenes.But in some light hearted scenes, it felt like she didn't convey those emotions that at times it felt monotone. She could've shown a more human and relatable side of Sunshine.It didn't helped that the runtime could've expanded or improve some things that were lacking, but overall the film did ok. Lastly, I have a message to those who are invoking Brocka's name or likening it to the film or the filmmaker: "keep his name out of your mouth."

This film is, at its core, a well-intentioned and emotionally resonant film. It tackles difficult subject matter with sincerity, and for the most part, it does so with grace. However, I found that the inclusion of fantastical or imaginary elements occasionally detracted from the weight of its core issues. While I understand the metaphorical ambition behind these stylistic choices as well as their function in softening the emotional blows with humor or levity, I believe the film is at its most powerful when it forgoes embellishment and leans fully into the raw intensity of its subject matter. In those moments, when it embraces the chaos, the pain, and the emotional urgency it really becomes something far more affecting and memorable, allowing the simplicity it strives for to emerge, though itâ€™s often overshadowed. At times, the dialogue veers into overtly inspirational or didactic terrain, feeling more like affirmations meant to uplift than naturalistic exchanges between characters. Itâ€™s clear that the film doesnâ€™t only aim to tell a story, it wants to educate, to empower, to stir social consciousness. Yet in doing so, it sometimes edges closer to the tone of an educational TV movie than a fully realized work of cinema. Thatâ€™s not a critique of its moral imperative, itâ€™s a film that should be shown in schools but rather an observation about its limitations as a piece of narrative storytelling. The emotional and ideological weight it seeks to carry isnâ€™t always supported by the nuance or complexity that cinematic storytelling demands.What grounds the film and gives it its most enduring power is its emotional core. Maris Racal delivers a performance of quiet strength and vulnerability, anchoring the film with remarkable consistency. Especially compelling is the subplot involving Rhed Bustamanteâ€™s character. Without revealing too much, her arc resonated with me more deeply than the central storyline. It was heartbreakingly authentic, subtle, restrained, and profoundly human. In that thread, the film touches something honest and unflinching.I also admired Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s formal restraint in certain key scenes, particularly her choice to mute the sound. In a film so concerned with voice and expression, those pockets of silence carried tremendous weight. They allowed the viewer a moment of stillness, a space for reflection and imbued the film with a haunting quietude that deepened the emotional stakes.That said, the filmâ€™s message doesnâ€™t always land with clarity. After a pivotal hospital scene, I overheard two audience members blame the protagonist for her choices, siding with the doctor who confronts her. That reaction, while anecdotal, reveals a significant shortcoming: the narrative may not have sufficiently challenged ingrained prejudices or prompted the kind of empathy it aspired to cultivate. It bravely addresses urgent topics- reproductive rights, bodily autonomy, the realities of being a young woman navigating unjust systems but the film doesnâ€™t always sharpen these into a coherent or persuasive argument. In trying to reach everyone, it occasionally loses the sharpness needed to truly confront.Still, â€œSunshineâ€ is a valuable film, one with earnestness, compassion, and purpose. Its flaws are born of ambition: the desire to inspire, to uplift, and to inform all at once. But perhaps empowerment doesnâ€™t always need to be accompanied by joy. Sometimes, it is in the unvarnished confrontation of pain without fantasy, without consolation that we discover our deepest strength. I donâ€™t mean to suggest the film ought to have ended in despair, but rather that its final act, which shifts into metaphor and closes with a success story, might have benefitted from something more grounded, more unresolved or ambiguous . Real life rarely provides a clean arc, and in a film so rooted in truth, the ending felt almost too easy, too neat.

We are in a limbo. So much of Philippine cinema, especially that which makes the rounds in local and international film festivals, is stuck churning out â€œgroundbreakingâ€ firsts. Because our cultural discourse is so behind, our filmmakers are tasked not only with telling stories, but also with inventing the stories to be told. Theyâ€™re required to stake out new thematic ground, not in service of aesthetic evolution, but simply to keep up with the global conversation. The cost of this is a cinema that often feels overburdened with didactic intent and undernourished in emotional and formal rigor.In a particularly polarizing gesture, Jadaone introduces a hallucinated child character, a device that indirectly echoes Jojo Rabbit (2019). But this choice results in jarring tonal shifts that muddle the filmâ€™s emotional center. What was perhaps intended as farce to illustrate inner turmoil instead dilutes the stakes, softening the thorniness of the subject matter with a cartoonish detour. Itâ€™s an interesting idea but one that never quite coheres with the rest of the filmâ€™s pro-choice sensibility. In fact, by personifying an unborn child as a character which speaks and thinks, then Sunshine unintentionally reinforces the very moral framing that anti-abortion rhetoric thrives on. It circles back into the age-old â€œwhen does life begin?â€ debateâ€”a question that continues to paralyze policymaking in the country, even when the conversation should be about autonomy, access, and proper healthcare. The film doesnâ€™t just inherit this moral hang-up; it stages it, literalizes it, and in doing so, muddies the clarity of its own politics. Whatâ€™s more revealing than the film itself is the discourse surrounding it: a ubiquity of gender-essentialist and bioessentialist defenses, as if any critique of any form is automatically a threat to representation. That instinct: to guard a filmâ€™s cause rather than evaluate its craft just proves how far behind we are as a nation in talking about gender politics in filmmaking. The refusal to embrace genuinely revolutionary tactics, whether in politics or art, has kept us coasting on the optics of progress ever since.Full review for the Kinoise Substack published here

Matino ang mga pangalawang aktor, may tamang balanse ng kritikang panlipunanâ€”ng mga gagong biktima ng sistema (at sadyang gago lang) at mga gustong maging mabuti sa gitna nitoâ€”at may gustong sabihin, ipaunawa. THE FILM SUNSHINE (2024), IS REALLY A SUNSHINE? 1000%! YES IT IS!Whatâ€™s more amazingly beautiful about the screenplay & direction is how the film starts and how it ends. Interestingly, there are moments where she silences the noise and does what she feels and loves. It also acts as a symbolic gesture of how she manages to pull herself out of an unwanted situation: the way she shuts down all the chaos and harsh experiences.The film is a social critique of how, for more than a century, certain laws have undermined reproductive rights, and how 1000s of Filipino women die each year from complications. Although the film is native to the Philippines, its commentary reflects many countries where abortion rights are still completely prohibited.It is not merely directed toward capturing Sunshine's journey (played by Maris Racal) facing psychological and emotional conflict within society; it also explores the dynamics of the families involved, especially her elder sister with a months-old baby, crafted in a way that reflects Sunshine's future & the collapse of her dreams.What I loved most is how director Antoinette creatively puts Sunshineâ€™s moral consciousness as a physical character, played by Annika Co, showing how it never really leaves her. Their conversations are intricately written, sometimes her conscience is angry and argumentative, and sometimes it simply smiles back at her.All in all, it is film that softens & sharpens at the same time. It gives voice to the women who are rarely heard & reveals the emotional truth behind difficult choices. Above all, it reminds us that agency is power, and that every woman deserves the right to define her own future.

DROWN OUT THE NOISE.Sunshine (2024), directed by Antoinette Jadaone, follows Sunshine (Maris Racal), a young rhythmic gymnast who dreams of making the national team and competing in the Olympics. Her life takes a sudden turn when she discovers she is pregnant right before the final selection. Refusing to give up on her dream or her life, she desperately searches for an illegal way to terminate the pregnancy in a society where abortion is strictly prohibited.Fyi, this is the first Filipino film Iâ€™ve ever watched, and surprisingly itâ€™s pretty ok. It feels like a fusion of Posesif (2017) and Dua Garis Biru (2019) combine those two and you basically get Sunshine. Overall I still enjoyed it, but I think the chasing the dream aspect, which shouldâ€™ve been the core of the film, felt meh. There werenâ€™t really any moments that pushed the conflict harder. For example, revealing Sunshineâ€™s pregnancy during her rhythmic gymnastics training, or showing how exhausting her training was to the point she almost gave up. Little things like that couldâ€™ve made the struggle hit much deeper. Thatâ€™s just my random thought, but I do feel those moments wouldâ€™ve strengthened the heart of the story, since Sunshineâ€™s core conflict truly lies in chasing her dream as an athlete and the harsh reality sheâ€™s forced to face.

maganda na meron tayong mga movies na ganito: matapang at sinusubok ang mga established nang beliefs ng bansa natin: na kasalanan ang pagpapalaglag, na para ka nang pumatay ng tao at nagdesisyon para sa Diyos, aka beliefs pantanga. mga paniniwalang ginawa para pagnakawan ng karapatan ang mga kababaihan sa sarili nilang katawan. simple. naihatid naman yung point, na okay, di nya gusto maging nanay, delikado ang pagpapalaglag sa bansa natin, maraming nabubuntis na hindi naman na dapat pang ikeep pa. sana lang mas pinalalim pa, superb na nga ang cast, maganda ang simula, parang â€˜di lang napanindigan. parang ang dami pang pwedeng gawin, lalo na doon sa part na nakikialam na yung 'pastor', christianity. sana lang mas nabigyang diin pa. parang ang ironic lang din na may mga bata pa na 'unborn' children kuno nila. kung titignan mo, parang mala pro-life ang stand ng movie e,,,, doon sa part na yun. imbis na iconvince ka ng pelikula na hindi naman kasalanan at pagpatay ang abortion, mas lalo pang nagmukhang pumapatay ka ng may buhay. goofy naman at times pero ewan ko, parang pampagulo lang doon sa pinaka point ng movie. parang mas nakakakonsensya pa yun para sa mga babaeng di na gustong ipagpatuloy yung pagbubuntis nila. sana gets ???????matapang ang pelikula. pero hindi ganon katapang para gumising ng natutulog. maganda na rin at meron tayong mga gantong 'kontrobersyal' n films, sabi nga nila, art disturbs the comfortable! it comforts the disturbed! sana may mas maganda pang films na makakapagpakita nito. yung gigising sa ating lahat.sa lahat ng to, ang pinaka nagustuhan ko lang ay yung pagpapakita na sobrang aligaga ni sunshine sa maynila, ramdam mo talaga siya. yung gulo, hindi lang sakanya pero sa mismong lugar. yung mga teenage moms na hindi alam ang gagawin, yung glimpse ng shitty healthcare system natin na dikit dikit na ang mga pasyente. yung desperation na makikita mo talaga kay sunshine, yung paglapit nya sa mga nagbebenta ng pampalaglag. ang realistic lang, at nakaka botherâ€”yun naman talaga yung pinaparamdam ng pelikula, at ang galing nila doon kasi pati ikaw mag aalala ka para sakanya. yung mga katulad ni sunshine na desperado nang humingi ng tulong, marami sila sa bansa natin, sana ganito rin natin sila alalahanin. maraming nasa kalagayan niya na hindi alam ang gagawin at hindi pa handang magbuntis. sana imbis na islutshame sila, maliitin at laitin, bigyan natin sila ng tulong na kailangan nila. sana maging legal na ang abortion at mas maging accessible na ang services na ito sa lahat ng kababaihan, para wala nang mga babaeng kailangan pang ilagay sa peligro ang mga sarili nila para lang magawa ang isang bagay na bahagi naman dapat ng karapatan nila sa katawan nila.

First Letterboxd essay â€” I had an itch to scratch so bad with this one. Also medyo late, crammer kasi year-end na :) Right off the bat, I knew how reviews of this film would look like. At hindi naman nagkamali. This film is highly praised, receiving remarks such as masterpiece, brave, and a stepping stone.Yet to my surprise, a few share the same sentiments I had, thoughts that were brewing in me while watching Sunshine. Kaya rin ang hirap buuin ng review na ito (bukod sa hindi naman talaga ako nag-eessay sa plataporma na ito), kasi ayoko maging echo lamang.Anyways, just for the sake of sharing kahit onti:(1) I agree that the supposed personified child is, safe to say, contradictory. Kahit may explanation si Direk Jadaone, it still felt conflicting and made the film unsure of itself.(2) The introduction of some characters felt out of place. In some aspect parang chess yan, character placement and arcs matter, so the player must be aware of their moves.(3) The slap in the face commentary on religion felt overdone. Sayang ang parts and points na pwede pang mahimay.Oh diba, dami niyang sinasabi. But in all honesty, I really felt the need to essay the hell out of this review. Mahalaga sa akin ang usapang SRH at syempre mahalaga rin sa akin na maging diskurso ito.And dahil diyan, hereâ€™s a point I feel no one else has raised. Personally, it felt like under-researched ang pelikula. Bakit? Mababaw pa ang na-capture nitong realidad ng abortion at ang hirap na nadadanas ng kababaihan sa kalusugan. These are things you would know agad with one simple search on Reddit. Gets ba? (Lol) And to think na mas layered and complex pa dapat ito sa sitwasyon ni Sunshine, as a student-athlete with financial instability. Sayang lang, ano? Syempre may good points din ang Sunshine sa pananaw ko. Visually, it did its thing. Acting, no doubt, great talents, especially Maris and Jennica. The fact that I watched this with my parents and that they were genuinely interested and concerned about the film is a good point.Sa dulo naman, baka expectations ko rin ang rason kaya ko ito naisip. From here on, sana hindi laging hanggang unang bato lang. Hereâ€™s to hoping na makahakbang at makausad na tayo.

"gets ko na"that line literally sent me into the abyss. going into the film, i was so confused about the little girl following sunshine. i thought she was sunshineâ€™s inner child, like a guide through the mess, reminding her who she was and what she actually wanted. but when they introduced ariana, the kid that â€œbataâ€ playmate during that night, everything started clicking.then the incident happened. mary grace (rhed bustamante) tried to get an abortion, and her baby died. when we saw ariana recognize mary grace, and then later, at the hospital, the nurse announced the baby didnâ€™t make itâ€¦ ariana just disappeared. thatâ€™s when it hit me: ariana and bata was supposed to represent the baby, their baby. it felt ironic at first because youâ€™re torn between â€œshould i feel bad?â€ and â€œshould i feel sad about the literal premise of the film?â€ but then bata said to sunshine, â€œgets ko na,â€ and the whole film just punched my soul.maris racal is easily one of the best actresses of this generation, and sunshine proves that. the film is raw, very indie pinoy cinema vibes, and it works. it also doesnâ€™t shy away from the heavy stuff, like how brutal the philippines can be when judging teenage pregnancy and abortion. the shame, the gossip, the pressure to â€œkeep it,â€ the lack of safe spacesâ€¦ the film shows how hard it is for girls to make choices about their own bodies when everyone feels entitled to comment.i just kinda wish they explored sunshine being a public athlete more, like the public eye, the rumors, the judgment sheâ€™d face online and her community as the time goes by. the ending showing her making it to the sea games was nice, but i feel like addressing the backlash and the pressure couldâ€™ve made the story even stronger.overall: great film. beautiful, painful, and honest. i love you, sunshine.

Abortion is such a complicated moral dilemma, and I personally lean toward not agreeing with it, so it was hard for me to empathize with the protagonist. A lot of her suffering felt like the result of her own choices, and the filmâ€™s attempt to make me feel sorry for her by surrounding her with awful people sometimes felt manipulative.The imaginary child concept also didnâ€™t always work for me. Sheâ€™s clearly meant to be a moral compass or a symbol of societal pressure, but without her, the film already shows how judgmental and unforgiving the world around her is. It made her presence feel more forced than meaningful. Sometimes I see her just to connect story and keep the plot moving or a way to feel sorry for her more.However, I connected more with the side characterâ€™s story. I can understand why abortion is legal if thats the case. Her pain and the horror that she went through and also affecting how I see Sunshine. nevertheless, I still think itâ€™s worth watching. It reveals how religion and society can stand between someone and the life they want.

Sunshine leaned heavily on the acting prowess of Maris Racal, and at times felt more like a montage of stellar performances from its ensemble cast than a cohesive narrative. The story was messy, and the moral dilemma was problematic. Perhaps this was intentional: not to preach, but to spark discourse. Still, I find this approach risky, especially when tackling a sensitive topic in a conservative country like the Philippines. My perspective might change over time, but my immediate takeaway is that it was a missed opportunity.

Sunshine is undeniably a political filmâ€”one that challenges the norms and cultural assumptions of the Filipino psyche. It is the kind of film that is marketed in such a way like an indie local blockbuster. Yung tipong kakagatin ng professors back in senior high or college and ipapa-assignment, and there is no doubt why many would watch it with unquestioning interest.Maris Racal delivers a committed performance, fully inhabiting a character who makes questionable and sometimes erratic choices. Her portrayal is compelling, yet itâ€™s hampered by a script that lacks the gravitas her story deserves. While the film touches on important issues, it never fully dives deep, ultimately limiting the emotional impact.Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s direction, though ambitious, is occasionally overshadowed by comedic moments that dilute the filmâ€™s central message about womenâ€™s rights. I found myself thinking, â€œSeryoso ka ba, Direk?â€â€”because the challenges had already been clearly established. As someone who strongly believes in a womanâ€™s autonomy over her body, I appreciate the filmâ€™s intentions, but the execution leaves the core message feeling imposed and emotionally flat by the end. Honestly, the audience I was with, mostly magbabarkadaâ€”kept asking, â€œPinalaglag niya ba? o hindi?â€ â€œOpen ended nanaman lagi yang director na yanâ€ and it frustrated me, because even if everything was already implied, it signaled that thereâ€™s a group of audience that failed to get the message. Which then leads me to the point that the weight of personal choiceâ€”the triumph and struggle inherent in itâ€”is never fully realized, which keeps the story from resonating as deeply as it could. Gets ko na, pero sana gets niyo rin.Sunshine is a film with admirable intentions and flashes of brilliance, yet it struggles to fully harness its potential. Actually, itâ€™s a palatable film about that struggle. To say na ang tapang ng pelikula na â€˜to is a feat that I donâ€™t think it deserves fully. It is a conversation starter, but one that often feels louder than it is profound, gaya nga ng sabi ni Sunshine sa pagpalit niya ng kanta sa set niya â€” parang kulang sa heart.

No coz wtf is up with it trying to be like Challengers in the exhibition scene?I donâ€™t think itâ€™s worth the hype that itâ€™s getting, but it doesnâ€™t necessarily mean that itâ€™s not a good movie. It doesnâ€™t have a resolution nor does the message really sticks it landing. It is however, simply a story told that is based on the bits and pieces of reality that we can only conceive. Itâ€™s a conversation starter, but its certainly does not explore much of the topic that its centered on. So much so that the film doesnâ€™t really let you grow to care about the Protagonistâ€™s support system, thus their presence, their wisdom and their comfort, falls flat in terms of having and relevance to you. There are moments wherein I enjoyed the humor, but you can only do so much with curse words in dialogues that it starts to sound like Daryl Yapâ€™s films, the only difference here is that it handled a topic thatâ€™s taboo and has managed to deliver its point across, however at the expense of being safe enough to be told, but less poignant and thought provoking to be considered as something to be discussed in depth. What I like about Sunshine is this film fully embraced Antoinette Jadaone's artistry as a filmmaker, similar to her magnum opus "Fan Girl".The luscious colors and shades at the backdrop of a failing city. The grounded surrealism. And Jadaone's honesty in what she wanted to convey in the film. Much like her previous romance films Alone/Together and Never Not Love You, this film grappled with social and economic uncertainty but this time it highlighted Maris Racal's character's struggle to love her passion in gymnastics. It's no surprise Racal acted the hell out of her role, but my flowers are for Jennica Garcia who encapsulated the ghost of Sunshine's what-could-have-been. Sunshine further proves Jadaone is in her prime, and there's so much more she can make in the next years.

This movie is brave in tackling a very delicate issue, but at times, it tries too hard to deliver its message. It needed more grit and heart, and less aesthetics and preachiness. It works well when it shows its heart -- the tender moments between sisters, the heartbreaking text message to a friend before a risky decision. Maris Racal is good, and the supporting cast also deserves a lot of praise (the Quiapo vendor was great).

Yesterday, I stumbled upon a Twitter post pointing out parallelisms between Jadaone's Sunshine and Brocka's Insiang with how both films' main characters, in at least one scene, were framed behind bars, mirroring their metaphorical imprisonment within gendered norms of their respective social milieus. Indeed, although almost 50 years have passed between the two films, it's an unfortunate reality that women's rights in the Philippines still have a long way to go, with conservative Catholic values hindering its advancement. Both Jadaone and Brocka present us with their titular characters' fractured psyches, trying everything within their limited power to achieve some kind of self-emancipation. Another Twitter post, however, posits that while Jadaone echoes Brocka in some ways, she ultimately diverges from him by virtue of her "woman's instinct" that also augments her narratives with an "added layer." Obvious gender essentialism and identity politics aside, this is a sentiment that I'm keen on interrogating: what does it actually mean to have a female directorial sensibility, particularly in the vein of Antoinette Jadaone?An easy answer would be to look at the central conflict of Sunshine, that is, unwanted pregnancy, and that Jadaone opts for a female teenager as its main focalizer. I'm pointing this out because trans men and intersex people can also get pregnant hence a pregnancy plot point would not inherently be women-specific (although there would surely be many overlaps), so it's Jadaone's directorial decision to create a female protagonist that imbues the film with intricacies of the female experience---how proceeding with motherhood would be career suicide for an athlete aiming for the Olympics, how Sunshine is constantly berated by self-righteous people she encounters, how society itself was built against female self-determination, and despite all these, how Sunshine finds small pockets of refuge in other women---a friend, a mentor, an inn receptionist, a doctor, an abused prepubescent, a sister---who are empathetic enough to understand her pain and conviction, and to whom she's equally compelled to reciprocate kindness whenever the situation permits.Further, Jadaone digs deeper and finds the Catholic religious institution, itself a remnant of feudalism, as an underlying hegemonic force against women empowerment, so culturally embedded in Philippine society that Sunshine finds it wherever she goes, be it in the drugstore, in the hospital, in the university, in the sport that she loves, even in the man who got her pregnant. Unfortunately, here is also where Jadaone's supposed female sensibility loses steam: religious guilt is so ubiquitous that even she is not aware that it limits her perspective, that instead of finding multiple angles of inquiry she instead chooses to hammer in the same anti-religious (therefore anti-patriarchal) talking point over and over and over again, even to the point of physicalizing the unborn children, a weirdly pro-life creative decision in a film that self-categorizes as pro-choice. Heck, the film just assumes that the audience already knows about the economic facets of being a Filipino athlete so it makes no effort in examining it, nor is it concerned with how Sunshine and her family earn their money (nobody seems to be working!). No, those aren't important; just focus on the fact that Sunshine is a woman and that she's oppressed because of it. "Drown out the noise," her coach tells her, but is it really necessary to drown it out if the noise is as repetitively monotonous (albeit still imminently threatening) as Jadaone presented it?My argument is that uncritical admiration for "female sensibility" is as dangerous as the patriarchy it contends with, and that it's the same liberal narrow-sightedness that applauds Jadaone's bravery for tackling taboo gender topics and turns a blind eye to her cowardice in heeding the pro-Palestine boycott of the Berlinale film festival in the same breath; what's the point of female sensibility if it is devoid of anti-fascist solidarity? Perhaps Sunshine is actually a self-surrogate for the lengths Jadaone is willing to go through in pursuit of her career, and we're all just supposed to root for her because it's great that Philippine cinema is acknowledged and praised internationally, everything else be damned.And maybe I'm expecting too much from Jadaone, that I should just accept that her films are self-contained texts that will never reach the same kind of radicalism and depth as Brocka's (which is admittedly a high standard to reach), but deep inside I want to believe that she's capable of bolder, stronger filmic statements.

Thereâ€™s no denying Sunshine matters - it speaks to harsh truths and tackles its themes with care and emotional honesty. The film had a timely subject, sincere writing, and phenomenal acting - Maris Racal was stellar, while Jennica Garcia delivered with quiet power. But I struggled with certain elements, particularly its attempt at magical realism. The presence of the imaginary child felt clunky, tonally jarring, and out of sync with the otherwise grounded narrative. Frankly, the character felt unnecessary - the film had already evolved past the need for her. The story had power, and I wish it had trusted its own strength without the added flourish. Ultimately, I admired its purpose more than loving its execution.

This is my first film in FOUR months?! Itâ€™s horrible for my cinephile ass out hereâ€¦This is the Happening of Filipino cinema, except itâ€™s less thrilling and more aligned with the traditional storytelling of Filipino drama.Perhaps my favorite element of this new project from Antoinette Jadaone is the contrast between morality and sin as personified by the hawker who sells abortion pills behind figures of saints beside Quiapo Church, which is arguably the most popular place of veneration among Catholic Filipinos throughout the country.Beyond that, Iâ€™m struggling to seek nuance and proper closure. What sets this work, aside from the palpable gentleness toward the female main character, apart from the many stories about abortion out there?Itâ€™s worth noting, however, that stories about women are told by women, just like what Jadaone manages to deliver here. I believe (cis) male filmmakers, no matter how genuine their intent is, cannot tell stories about women because womenâ€™s danas, the distinct Filipino word for experience, is not menâ€™s danas.[Watched at SM Mall of Asia Cinema 1]

Sunshine (2024) would be a perfect double feature with Eliza Hittman's Never Rarely Sometimes Always (2020) as they both tackle similar topics but with a stark difference in privilege and access.where the latter becomes a story of sisterhood and compassion, as two girls cross state lines to get access to healthcare, Sunshine offers no such respite to our eponymous protagonist.in here, what Sunshine wants is not even a matter of choice, it is something that she is forced to bear. all alone as her confidants succumb to the stigma of her dilemma, Sunshine takes to the streets of Manila in search of a way to terminate her pregnancy.the plot moves along while the audience is served scenes of what i believe to be one of the better cinematic depictions of modern Manila. the first few minutes almost feel like an entirely different film (one i would have particularly liked more) until the plot takes a peculiar detour.in all of its realism and poignancy i found a particular element in its storytelling very out of place and oftentimes distracting. while the ending made me understand why those choices were made i just don't think a semblance of Magical Realism is the perfect vehicle for a message as heavy as this one.while i think the point that: "an entire generation of Filipino women being forced to reckon with their unborn children as if the choice of abortion is something that has to be explained, and in turn, be understood." is a step in the right direction for this nation's pro-choice discourse, the delivery just felt like it was bordering into Diary of an Unborn Child territory. with that being said, i still thoroughly enjoyed Sunshine and i would still highly recommend it. despite some of my grievances with the film, the unblemished ray of sunshine known as Maris Racal delivers a stellar performance in the titular role. perhaps even a mariesteller one. *wink* *wink*

Itâ€™s so odd to see Jadaone out of her boxâ€”or perhaps returning to her old form. If Fan Girl leaned into the dark, Sunshine veers into the gritty. The clever use of environment makes Maris Racalâ€™s performance feel grounded and central, without overly commenting on political allegories like in Jadaoneâ€™s previous work. Orendainâ€™s shots donâ€™t try to elevate the storyâ€”they move hand-in-hand with it, gripping tightly to the isolation of being a young woman in the Philippines.I havenâ€™t seen any Filipino film tackle abortion quite like this. The nuance of setting it in a deeply religious country is compelling. It opens the conversation, but perhaps plays a little too safeâ€”maybe to appeal to a broader audience. I was hoping for a stronger push, but it chooses to be understated: a film beaming with quiet urgency and an accurate reflection of the current climate surrounding womenâ€™s reproductive rights.

This is a film of two parts. This film is part compelling drama, with a strong lead performance from the young actor and a powerful examination of the treatment of women in the Phillipines. This film is also part surrealist, but in a way that I feel undermines the strengths of the film. There is a young girl who appears at various points throughout the film; her identity is left to interpretation. However I feel that this apparition weakens every scene she's in. You'll have this powerful understated drama and then this wise-cracking girl appears to swear at you. It is clear that they couldn't even make her fit throughout the film because she disappears for at least half an hour in the middle. The filmmaker said this was the original core concept of the film and I understand that, but I feel that the film moved beyond the need for this character. I will say that I found the final interaction between the girl and our protagonist quite touching. Maybe if the girl was more understated it could have worked better. I do want to mention that it was really lovely to be in the TIFF audience for this one; the Filipino community was so passionate about this film and it was the longest and most involved Q&A I'd ever seen. It's really inspiring to see how beloved it was.

Iâ€™ve been waiting for Sunshine's release ever since its TIFF premiere last September. With limited showings, the wait for a global or streaming release felt even longer. When Netflix announced they had acquired the film, I was excited... only to learn it was geo-blocked to the Philippines. But even with its depressing distribution, I can finally say Iâ€™ve watched it!As a woman who cares deeply about reproductive rights, the filmâ€™s subject matter resonated with me on a level thatâ€™s difficult to articulate. Sunshine arrives in an era where there's endless debate over motherhood, declining birth rates & womenâ€™s bodily autonomy at large. We're living in a world where conservative politics are resurging, where five years of Tiktok is undoing decades of feminist work, and where technofascists pour billions in service of a pronatalist agenda. In the midst of all the noise and the pressure placed on womenâ€™s bodies, Sunshine truly feels like sunshine. Itâ€™s a reminder of the lived reality of pregnancy: the physical toll, the emotional burden, the loss of autonomy, and the ways class determines what choices a woman can or cannot afford.Maris Racal delivers a truly compelling performance â€“ her pain is honest and palpable. I loved the dynamic between Sunshine and Geleen; their relationship grounds the film. The scene where Geleen hugs Sunshine and promises to support her decisions no matter what is one of the movie's most affecting moments â€“ an affirmation of sisterhood untouched by financial instability or the harshness of their circumstances.Could the film have done more? Absolutely. There are ideas that couldâ€™ve been explored further but in an era when mainstream studios and streaming services seem determined to churn out utter slop, Sunshine feels like a breath of fresh air. I also learnt the title was changed from Gymnast to Sunshine and I think it was the perfect choice for a movie like this (especially with that ending!). Iâ€™m grateful this movie exists and Iâ€™m even more grateful I finally got to see it.

Sunshine and ShadowsSunshine follows a young gymnast whose Olympic hopes are abruptly derailed by an unplanned pregnancy, with a plot that resonates because it treats her crisis with urgency, clarity, and emotional truth. Its strongest attraction is the filmâ€™s willingness to confront issues head-on, using the leadâ€™s personal struggle to mirror the realities many Filipinos navigate. Themes of autonomy, pressure, and the weight of expectation run through every scene. Acting is exceptional, with Maris Racal delivering a raw performance that anchors the film while the supporting cast sharpens the emotional stakes. The dialogue stays direct and natural. Cinematography captures Manila with unpolished grit and contrasts it with the rigid discipline of the gym. Editing is tight and controlled. Direction is confident and compassionate, balancing social commentary with intimate storytelling. The â€œitâ€ factor is the filmâ€™s grounded honesty and relevance while framing a life in crisis with empathy instead of judgment.

I had the chance to watch this at JAFF 2025. The plot twist is simple, but the message is powerful. The film highlights issues of sexual harassment and sexual violence involving minors. At JAFF, the director shared a little about how sexual issues are still considered taboo in the Philippines, and how the film also touches on the topic of abortion.Listening to the director speak at JAFF about the impact of this film, several discussions regarding cases of sexual harassment and violence in the Philippines have begun to open up, even if only slightly. According to him, this film has helped pave the way for filmmakers there to create similar works, which are still relatively rare.

I may be on the unpopular side of this: I want to love this so badly but for some reason, I can't help to mull-on & pinpoint some details lacked for me and thought it needed more revising story-wise. I am not hating on this. In fact, I actually like several parts of the movie. I think it's fair to say (and undeniably so) that this is an important and a refreshing story on what's the take of abortion & body autonomy here in the Philippines and I do appreciate this movie for that. (I added the half star plus because it still is an important movie)I want to love this movie (but only like it) because I thought it obviously have such a great potential to be "a great movie" on most aspects. What holds me back is the writing, story-wise.It started really strong and direct to the point which I really liked. By the next part, we'd see a little girl who follows Sunshine. At first it seems to me that it could be her inner child or her unborn future child so it confused me a bit (most especially on the part where Sunshine was rushed to the hospital, we'd see a blood on her crotch area as well). This device they used provided a bit of comic relief in the movie which I thought is cute and actually can be an effective way to delve deeper sentimentally because its so personal. However, I came to learn (through online reading) that she is indeed her unborn future child (bc of Ariana disappearing). To be honest, I couldn't finalize my thoughts on this whether I like it or not because with that in mind, the mix message does confuse some a bit on whether or not it's a "pro-life" but I guess that could also be the point that it is complicated. Afterall, Sunshine did kept coming back to the church scenes and this can represent a lot of women who faces/d the same situation. I just thought the movie might have to clarify in telling that message.I also much prefer her being Sunshine's inner child (which could be a "tangible" reminder on what the whole movie is all about, Sunshine taking control of her own life and the dream of being a national athlete ever since she's a child). But the line "Gets ko na" have such a great impact on people because of its "casualness" but its the words that has a really heavy weight on it that I thought is effective to pull people's heartstrings in. Another aspect of the movie that kinda lacked for me which is, I think a big part of it: I want to see how much Sunshine wants it by seeing her own training to be a gymnast. What does she do every day as a training athlete? How does she balance everything in her life-- being a sister/aunt/student/friend/a woman in general while also being a training athlete? What do you to do train as a gymnast? How heavy does it weigh on her that she's truly doing every thing she can to be in olympics and be a great gymnast, what does it look like? I wished she saw that a bit (even just in a montage) before or during the moment she found out she got pregnant. I want to see her really work hard and see how much blood, sweat, and tears and really feel and see that "goddamn it i want this so bad" and not just tell it. I guess what I want to say is that I want more training scenes too because I am also interested in watching gymnasts do their thing haha.I also thought that by the 3/4 part of the movie where we do meet Ariana is kinda took a different turn for the movie. I am not sure if it is necessary that we meet another kid (Ariana, not Mary Grace) and that maybe without that, they could still end up getting the same storyline/result (though don't get me wrong, I did like Ariana, i think she's fab). It also didn't do much impact on Sunshine's decision but rather it does prove how fucked up it is that this happen in reality and how shitty it is again that we don't have much (legal and safe, known) access to women's sexual and reproductive health services, let alone being a woman/person who's forced into something they aren't ready to be/never wanted be in the first place.More so, the visuals and cinematography, can't deny that it is beautiful, that's a given. Acting is amazing, no notes no doubt.A little predictable on emphasizing on the Manila landscape and scenery although it is still beautiful to look at (especially considering to people haven't been to Manila/Philippines, at least they'd get the gist of it even though its not all picturesque all the time). I especially appreciate the movie getting in deep and showing the grim & messy ways of taking different methods of abortion. I thought its very important to see how harrowing and fucking hard/harsh/unfair/dangerous it is that women have to/had no choice to do experiences like these. I only wished that they showed the method of when Sunshine made an appointment for that Doctor Helena because maybe it could also show that abortion could also have safe and harmless way that would make people feel less wary and scared of it and maybe even talk about it.With all that, in conclusion I think I do like this movie. It is an important movie to exists especially at our modern times, it's long overdue that we finally talk about this here in our country. I hope we keep talking about it because it is necessary for us we want to keep fighting for women's rights. I don't love it but I do like it and I appreciate it for what it did.

More didactic than her previous films, but this is still a great â€œsocial issuesâ€ drama (albeit one with some magical realist touches), with a moving central performance. In terms of â€œabortion movies,â€ it really does a great job of making its case. For a teenage gymnast, carrying a baby to term really does completely remove that path as a possibility for her lifeâ€”that dream just gets immediately destroyed, in a way that (obviously) wonâ€™t happen for the babyâ€™s father, and itâ€™s why itâ€™s so essential to this filmâ€™s success that Jadaone so skillfully captures the tactile and practical *reality* of Sunshineâ€™s body in the gymnastic scenes: that body, with its graceful and athletic movements, that she has spent her entire life molding for this sole purpose of Olympic gold, and it will go away, permanently, if she doesnâ€™t have an abortion. I also think Jadaone does a good job of avoiding deck-stacking. Yes, the pro-life nurse who castigates Sunshine is portrayed as a witch, but the saleswoman who gives her the abortifacients is also shown to be a greedy haggler herself. And while the two male figures pressuring her to have the baby (her boyfriend and her boyfriendâ€™s father) both make specious and insincere cases, it is again to Jadaoneâ€™s credit that she cast two dynamic male performers for these roles (Elijah Canlas and Pio Pascualâ€”whom I didnâ€™t recognize in a straight-up â€œDadâ€ role, after decades playing the heart-throb!)â€¦this is one of those reviews where in the process of writing it Iâ€™ve realized I liked the movie a lot more than I thought I did while the credits were rolling. Jadaone, sheâ€™ll do that to you!

i liked the narrative and character of Sunshine. a well-performing gymnast who carried it all alone, refusing to give up her passion over being a childbearer. but there's something more to see, something to observe about â€” the country's system is rotten. beggars crossing your struggles only to be fed. the extreme language of Filipino people to express rage. busy and wasted streets to feel unsafe yet realistically implied. hospitals rejecting patients instead of living out the work ethic of saving lives. being a bad influence for expressing what you really feel. religion as a coping mechanism. plans of abortion kept clandestinely to hide against the law. and the most of it all, choosing to smile as a way to focus on doing what you love. additionally, showcasing Sunshine's child manifestation was wild. it was her conscience at the same time â€” guilt tripping the heck out of her.curses to the legal system. curses to insensitive and lustful men.curses to irresponsible parents.ang gwapo ni Piolo Pascual.

Walang pressure from it. Pinapakita nung una na Pagbuo sa bata vs Pangarap niya, hindi gaano najustify yung pangarap niya at ano siya bilang sasali sa Olympics. abortion is a topic i usually avoid because itâ€™s morally, socially, and emotionally heavy. what i loved about this film is how it didnâ€™t shy away from that weight, showing how complicated it really is especially in a conservative, Catholic society like ours where abortion is still illegal and pregnant teens are often judged and shamed. i liked how they showed that harsh reality here. and i also really liked Maris Racalâ€™s performance, i think she brought so much depth and vulnerability to her role.iâ€™m a Christian, so of course i have my own beliefs. but i do believe every woman should have a say over her own body. we shouldn't force someone into a choice they aren't ready for. if she isn't ready to be a mother, she may not be able to provide the care a child deserves. sometimes, the bravest and kindest choice a woman can make is the one who chooses the best for herself, who considers her life and circumstances. at the end of the day, it's not our body, not our life, not our consequences so we shouldn't judge. we're called to love, to show mercy, and to respect the dignity and choice of others. after all... autonomy is a lifeline.

Yes! This is the type of films the Philippines should make more! Finally a movie with substance, relevance, and courage to tell a story despite cultural taboo. This is required and essential.I thought an hour and a half wouldnâ€™t be enough to dig deeper into the journey of Sunshine but it was actually just enough to see all of it. Although, there were unnecessary choices made in the film that I disliked and that I wish were done differently and I wish saw more of Sunshineâ€™s character in the lowest of lows or maybe Iâ€™m just greedy. However,Maris Racal is a revelation. And for the Philippines to have such a film like this one that speaks to so many women, even men, in the country. I hope this is a step forward for the country to move progressively and this be a force for politicians to pass that bill. Because after all, films are made to speak out, protest, and to implement change. Lastly, Sunshine is such a huge step towards good filmmaking in the Philippines. We need more films that speak of truth and of society. Stories that need to be heard and not rely too much on fake romance. Though Sunshine isnâ€™t perfect as a film itself, the courage and the amount of truth revealed in an hour and a half are enough to have the voices of so many women be heard. Men are in fact, disappointing. And so is the society we live in.One of the biggest reasons why the Philippinesâ€™ notion of sex can be described as â€˜backwardsâ€™ or â€˜two-facedâ€™ is because of the fact that it is a predominantly Catholic country that has been culturally conservative and pro-life. Many pro-life institutions and religious affiliations proliferate misinformation on reproductive health. However, the film presents this juxtaposition of vendors selling abortifacients within church grounds, a stark contrast of what Catholicism believes in. I like how this element was woven into the movie. I also like the inclusion of the unnamed girl and â€˜Arianaâ€™ into the narrative. Though at first it may be confusing, Iâ€™d like to think that those kids were the unborn children of Sunshine and the 13 year-old Mary Grace. The scene where Sunshine was practicing and the unnamed girl cheered for her, and when Sunshine asked if the unnamed girl understands her decision - this almost moved me to tears. The movie hints that the Philippines is still far from being an ideal place for women and children to live in, especially when it comes to rights pertaining to their bodies. It also serves as a haunting reminder that once a seed is planted, whichever path you may go, every path is painful. And thereâ€™s no turning back.

there were moments in sunshine that genuinely broke me. i kept thinking about all the women who have gone through abortion terrified, ashamed, and unsafe, wondering if they would make it out alive. the film doesnâ€™t have to scream horror for you to feel the fear. it lingers quietly in the room, in the body, in the choices a woman is forced to make when society refuses to give her one.iâ€™ve always had a deep fear of getting pregnant. i donâ€™t want to be a mother. and even with contraceptives and all the precautions in the world, there is always that small, terrifying chance. so my dream is to live in a philippines where abortion is decriminalized, where women are trusted with their own bodies. i want a country that gives them safe options, not moral punishment. a country where they donâ€™t have to risk their lives just to choose the life they want.if youâ€™re reading this and youâ€™ve thought about it, or youâ€™ve gone through it, i support you. you deserve safety. you deserve dignity. you deserve choice.to direk tonet and the whole team, thank you for telling this story honestly. i hope sunshine reaches the people who need to hear it.
