A Powerful Dive into Dreams and Despairâ€‹Antoinette Jadaone's "Sunshine" delivers a gut-wrenching, yet profoundly necessary, look at a young Filipino athlete's life derailed. The film centers on Sunshine, a dedicated and promising gymnast on the cusp of national team tryoutsâ€”her last shot at Olympic glory.â€‹The narrative brutally shifts when she discovers she is two months pregnant. This sudden realization shatters her dreams, highlighting the devastating conflict between personal ambition and an unexpected life-altering reality.â€‹Set against the backdrop of the Philippines, where abortion is strictly illegal, the film powerfully spotlights the immense social and legal pressures faced by women. It's a sharp social critique that exposes the isolation, judgment, and high risks inherent in navigating reproductive choices in a conservative society. The crushing weight of a lost future, compounded by moral and legal taboos, is palpable.â€‹Ultimately, "Sunshine" culminates in a powerful and courageous decision made by the protagonist. This choice serves not only as a personal turning point but also as a stirring statement about resilience and taking control in a system designed to strip away agency. Itâ€™s a film that resonates long after the credits roll.

It's a first step, but a step nonetheless. In a country where abortion is considered legally and morally reprehensible, it's difficult to come to terms that "abortion = bad" is the norm, the standard. Women are made to suffer through it and because of it, and this film portrays that perfectly.I tell myself it's a first step towards delivering more biting, more critical, and more experimental works, because while Sunshine does an A+ job of presenting the struggles and suffering women in her position experience, it's only that. A presentation, however biting and cruel and very, very real. While we follow Sunshine's story, Sunshine feels like a mouthpiece than a character. We know her dreams and what she's willing to do to achieve these dreams, and that's about it. I feel like the film tries to deliver an generalization or capsule of why women's healthcare is not prioritized in the Philippines and what the general (conservative) opinion on abortion is, instead of focusing on Sunshine as a character, a nineteen-year-old who is faced with a difficult decision and how she handles it and how she experiences it.But anyway, this isn't a film that screams abortion is no sin and that abortion should be legalized, but it's a film that talks about it and it's better than nothing.I hope we get to see more films that dare challenge the conservative, sexist, and misogynist media landscape in the Philippines.

Sunshine, to its very core, is the type of film we so desperately need in this country. Itâ€™s a familiar yet socially relevant narrative that aims to eventually legalise abortion and decriminalise the women facing these circumstances. Props to Jadaone for championing this narrative and actually making a change through screenings with our countryâ€™s lawmakers. The film is at its strongest when it remains simplistic. Personally, the incorporation of magical realism through the physical manifestation of these children remain counterproductive and muddied the overall tone.I wish this film had a longer runtime and room for the other repercussions and consequences in the context of being a public figure in the Philippines especially in the pursuit of becoming an Olympian. I feel like then we can truly feel her obsession and the weight of the dilemma sheâ€™s facing. My last nitpick is the cinematography. There are so many scenes that I feel needed that extra push when heavy scenes unfolded. Especially during the ribbon dancing sequences. I just wished shot selection felt more intentional in order to make each scene flow together, considering the elegance of the sport itself. Small things like these can further complement Sunshineâ€™s love for the sport.Regardless, powerhouse performances though from the entire cast especially from Maris Racal. Clearly a character that she carefully researched and eventually embodied.

inhalesunshine, like many teenage Filipina pregnancies, is a product of a failed system rooted in the patriarchal beliefs of a conservative country. it is diabolical yet profound to witness the realities experienced by abused minorities, especially young girls. this film portrayed politics, injustices, gender inequality, religion, passion, beliefs, cultures, and more.direk Tonet was able to encapsulate the imbalances not only in terms of gender, but in social class as well, something we continue to fight against to this day.in the end, it breaks barriers by delivering the truth that womenâ€™s bodies are ours. and it is our choice. and how cruel that women need support and rights (yes, how unlawful) to be able to make their choices regarding reproductive health. i believe this film also diminishes the patriarchal belief that being a woman automatically equates to being a mother. no. it will depend on us, not the society we live in.exhale

glad it's not like those other type of movies where the female lead has no choice but to face motherhood and forced to see the beauty, the silver lining, the usual ito pala purpose ko or na-realize ko 'yung ganda ng buhay because of a child.sunshine effectively embarks you on the same anxious and troubling journey of answering whether or not to do it lalo dahil nakakatakot at illegal sa batas piliin ang sarili at pangarap sa ganitong punto. sobrang on point ng mga lines ng bata sa kanya esp. on the first few scenes nila together. murderer... na isa sa mga usual na argumento ng mga taong nasa kabilang side. it truly is an eye opener for the harsh reality na pasan ng mga kababaihan at ng bawat desisyong ginagawa nila.however, there really are some awkward scenes. i honestly am not a fan of the scenes with the children lalo nung dulo. medyo awkward yung pagkakalapat sa kwento. but i get the point, of showing a different side---'yung realidad lalo para sa mga nasa laylayan ng lipunan. kung gaano ka-normal. kung gaano ka-hayop ang mga tao. kung gaano ka walang pake para sa kinabukasan lalo ng mga bata. even the scene with elijah and his father... it just feels weirdly inserted. and i just... couldn't feel her strong desire.. the childhood dream of succeeding in gymnastics and of being an olympian. her scene with the child --- kung yung bata man na yun talaga ay representation niya nung bata siya could've probably did a better job to unfold that part. it felt underwhelming nearing its end because i felt like marami pang pwede ma explore. medyo hilaw ang ibang parts. i felt like it didn't add anything new to what we already know about this issue. pero this film also has tons of strengths that's still worthy of giving it a try and seeing it.

Sucked I had to see this in a theater with poor sound proofing, occasionally overhearing the crashing sound design of Weapons playing in the next cinema. Nevertheless, it's a gripping cinematic experience with convincing performances across the board. But what stood out for me is its provoking use of the locale. Manila is so alive in this film, capturing all its noise and dirt from the restless streets of Quiapo, its sketchy motel rooms, to the crowded and understaffed hospitals. It's as if the city is actively sabotaging Sunshine's Olympic dreams. And it's not just her ambition being stolen away but also her agency as a woman. After all, it's the city that produces uncaring doctors and breeds men like Miggy and Bobot, through its misogynistic and outdated laws overwhelmed by patriarchal and religious pressures. And yet, the film never loses sight of hope. In the same rotting place, Sunshine finds hope and solidarity among other women, from her caring sister and trainer, a role-model coach, a concerned friend, a doctor willing to serve unpaid, a street vendor selling abortion pills for a cheaper price, and even from a hotel owner who does not allow solo bookings in fear they commit suicide. The idea that goodness always prevails is expected for a film like Sunshine. Otherwise, it risks being criticized as another cynical and pessimistic portrayal of our country. Empowerment is the name of the game today. Still, I find that the film's shine dims, ironically, when it avoids bleakness. Which is why I find the tonal shifts off-putting at times. The decision to physicalize Sunshine's conscience â€“ through the inclusion of an imaginary girl who keeps following her â€“ resulted in scenes that felt incompatible with the heavy subject matter. At one point, the guilt-turned-child is seen getting a haircut and performing gymnastics while reprimanding Sunshine. It verges into quirky territory which clashes with the established grittiness of the film that resembled Brocka's social realist drama (I know Jojo Rabbit was an inspiration but Sunshine is not purely satirical for the quirkiness to work). At worst, this plot device unconsciously validates the argument of the pro-life movement that abortion is killing lives, even if unborn. At the end, the unborn girl says she "gets it now" as if permitting Sunshine to eliminate her. In reality, an embryo is merely a clump of cells incapable of thinking and feeling. Granted, it's all part of Sunshine internally and subjectively dealing with her own religious trauma, but it still leaves the film with a somewhat undetermined morality. Sunshine is not murdering a kid for the Olympics. And I know the filmmakers â€“ and most audiences â€“ know better than to interpret the film that way, but when even influential celebrities appear to miss its progressive themes even if they were supposedly moved by the picture, perhaps it indicates to, not the incompetence of the viewers, but the film's potential to be more direct, not in an unimaginative way, but directness in political conviction. Sunshine is a bold move, but it can still be bolder. But maybe this sets a precursor for these kinds of dialogue to finally take place in our country, and actually impact policymaking. In that sense, I get it.

Sunshine is, by far, Jadaone's most daringâ€”steering away from the familiar terrain of romantic drama-comedy and into one charged with grit, hope, and unflinching honesty. At its core, the film follows the uneven arc of a gymnast reclaiming her agency amid the fractures of a rigid system and her own doubts. It is not simply about sportsâ€”it is about reclaiming space in a world quick to sideline those who falter.Jadaone's decision to root the narrative in sports is a masterstroke. Athletics here is not mere backdrop but a battlefield for selfhoodâ€”a metaphorical and literal arena where gymnastics becomes a language for autonomy. Instead of reducing it to spectacle, Jadaone transforms every stretch and pivot into a political gestureâ€”a critique of structures that discipline bodies, particularly women's, into compliance. The message is not whispered; it is delivered through the tensile beauty of bodies resisting definition.Beneath its sunlit optimism runs a current of protest. It critiques entrenched gender biases and class divides without falling into sermonizing, letting action speak louder than dialogue. When the protagonist stands firm in a world that tells her to shrink, the film achieves something rare: it politicizes persistence. And yet, it never loses its warmth. It believes in ambition as a form of defiance.While the final act feels slightly hurriedâ€”resolving arcs with a neatness that undercuts the turbulence that precedes itâ€”the journey there is luminous. Few films manage to be both intimate and insurgent, tender yet tactical. Sunshine does. It is a film about sports, but more than that, it is about refusing to stand still when the world insists you should.

better late than never, i guess.the fact that i was able to see this film three weeks after it opened in sm cinemas is a testament to the power of storytelling as a means to tackle complex topics, abortion in particular being quite meaningful in a catholic-majority country like the philippines. nearly half of the theater i was in was filled up, most being college students (since i had opted to catch this in an sm along the university belt). but the most memorable reaction i was privvy to was that of two middle-aged ladies seated a few rows behind me. during the film, one of them would occasionally mumble "hala" or "naku" at the main distressing occurrences in the narrative. given her age bracket, my preconceived notion was that these were noises of disapproval. only as we left the theater did i overhear the true intent - she told her companion "parang si sunshine din ako dati" and she said it not with any harrowing emotion, but casually, with a tinge of sheepishness and maybe even regret, as if it was a fact of life that took place long ago in her past and had faded into a memory tucked away in some cabinet in her mind. such is the nature of stigmatized issues like this one. jadaone's film shines when it allows the city and people of manila to reflect the truths that women encounter every day, from the closeness to religion despite its sharp edges, to the alternating concern of some strangers and quick condemnation of others. that's how sunshine breaks away from the sports movie template it begins with.but (and yes, finally, i am getting to the but) there's a certain questionable plot device used here that makes little sense. lots of other friends have said so, and i'd have to agree. personifying unborn children, to the point of dedicating a chunk of what was honestly a promising sideplot about abortion in the worst of circumstances, took away from the narrative rather than served it. there are moments where it made sense, a way to drive home sunshine's inner turmoil, but it overstayed its welcome, barely supported by the film's structure. it was a jarring choice in a story that mainly mimics social realist cinema and the thematic arcs of a sports movie (despite largely brushing over the specifics of a filipino student athlete's struggle - another flaw altogether). tl;dr: this is an ambitious work, and it could have driven home its convictions even more, if only it were not so keen to resort to choices broadly inspired by other filmmakers and sensibilities. sunshine is empowering as it is, but ultimately falls just a bit short in its vision. still, i am so, so glad it exists. maris racal was amazing.my full review(but also, take a look at mac's excellent review that takes an even deeper dive!)

What a very confronting film. It wasn't afraid to show some of the contradictions and irony of the paternalistic Filipino culture - abortion pills stands near the church, medical doctors of science who are extremely religious, future grandparents (and coach) who only really care for their own image, and so much more.Some of my female friends told me they cried while watching this. I almost did as well, but I think this film just hits different if you are a woman yourself (i blame my cis maleness). I found myself feeling for Sunshine (portrayed so convincingly by Maris) - with all the burden, shame, and guilt she had to endure, for something that she should've been able to do with her own will in the first place.I haven't heard so much swear words from a Filipino film in a while, specially most were said by little kids, but I guess it added to the harsh and cruel nature of the film (and also little kids saying curse words so brazenly are funny I guess). But I really wasn't sure what to feel with that kids plot device (which to be fair I did not fully get until much later). I felt that it takes off a bit from the realism the film was so good at, but it was very compelling for most of the scenes.I saw this here in Sydney, thousands of miles away from home, in a group of fellow Filipino immigrants. I kept thinking how the film's core issue was being received (specially if there were conservative titos and titas) but it was lowkey comforting to be around so much Pinoys again, who I'm sure the majority also watched and supported Sunshine (both the character and the film) with an open mind.

Sunshine is a film of gesturesâ€”tender, tremulous, and at times, transcendent. Very few Filipino films dare to tackle the taboo of abortion so openly. But while it proposes itself as a daring reflection on female agency and bodily autonomy, it stops short of critically examining the material and systemic forces that make them, and being a woman in general, so perilous in the first place.The world wages war on women, and in countries like the Philippines, the battlefield is their bodies and nobody can defend them, except themselves. That's the thesis of Sunshine. But instead of grounding its story in the socio-political architecture of the Philippinesâ€”where the abortion ban preserves the state-church alliance and renders poor women's reproductive labor both exploitable and punishableâ€”Sunshine chooses to dwell in personal emotion. Nothing inherently wrong about that, as it is just as important as the political. It actually hits very close to home, personally knowing women who have had to make these impossible choices in silence. However, the result then that we get is a film rich in atmosphere and affect but somewhat impoverished in nuance and context. We viewers are asked to infer structural violence from moody silences, bleak backdrops, and ambient dread, but the economic insecurity that shapes Sunshine's world largely remains abstract and unexplored. Her status as a decorated student-gymnast is stripped of its socioeconomic weight: no scheduling conflict, no public adulation and media scrutiny, no evidence of the extremely costly training such an elite athlete would require, no inspection whatsoever of how her athletic pursuit is ultimately tied to her material conditions, etc. We only see hints of these realities in where she lives, where she goes, and how she gets there, but the glaring absence of any meaningful insight into how she and her seemingly lower-middle-class family fund this vocationâ€”or what hopes they've pinned to itâ€”as well as her daily struggles as a teenager, blunt the actual stakes of her journey as a young Olympic aspirant with huge ambitions, now undermined by an unwanted pregnancy. Her abortion is framed as a personal reckoning, but the film somehow fails to convincingly connect it to her material realities. This disconnect is quite frustrating, not because the film avoids these questions entirely, but because there are attempts to address them, only to remain silent when it matters most.Antoinette Jadaone's use of magical realism then feels less like narrative innovation and more like gimmicky deflection. The film toys with the trauma of the Filipina facing an unwanted pregnancy but fully resists naming the forces that dictate it. Refusing to explicitly address even just some of the oppressive forces and structural problems that trap Sunshineâ€”e.g., the Catholic Church's (and other powerful religious groups') political influence, the inferiority and inaccessibility of the Philippine public healthcare system, and the class dimensions of access to reproductive healthâ€”leaves its message emotionally resonant but intellectually uncommitted.Still, there are moments that land (especially Maris Racal's emotive, career-defining performance), but these fragments unfortunately can't fully compensate for a film that abstracts real-world oppression into mood, then sells that mood as meaning.In the end, Sunshine is not a failure of craft but a failure of courage. Its reluctance to take big swings is its fatal flaw. It could've been a more powerful, assertive statement. But what we're left with is a lukewarm social commentary that gestures towards discomfort but avoids naming what that discomfort is and where it stems from.I guess the public discourse and the private conversations following the release of this film are (gonna be) much more compelling than the film itselfâ€”discussions about choice, dreams, regret, and what it means to be a woman in a pseudo-progressive country like the Philippines. Perhaps this is a film that merely reopens important discussions in our society but never challenges the very status quo it tackles. But maybe that's all we need right now to start inspiring change in this country.Decriminalize abortion, here and everywhere.

For a country deeply rooted in Catholicism and sacredness of life, gusto ko maniwala na maraming parte ng script o di kaya ng mga eksena ang mananatili na lang sa mata ng cast at crew kasi baka hindi pa handa ang madla sa katotohanan. Sa pagkakaalam ko, wala pa rin namang lisensyadong mag-facilitate ng abortion. Pero meron yan, tago lang.

after sunshine finds out that sheâ€™s pregnant, the pacing almost immediately starts to dip, and the plot device struggles where to go toward the end, but still managed to land decently. still, the heart of this film outshines everything. women don't have to carry the weight of the world on their hands. women are allowed to take agency over their truths.

maganda para sa akin ang attempt ni jadaone na magtry ng bagong film technique na ginagawa nina dwein baltazar lalo pa't isa siya sa sinasabi na mainstream director. at the same time, hindi niya tinalikuran ang kanyang kulay sa sariling pagdidirihe ng film. pinagsasama niya ang dalawang style na magandang ipakita ngayon para mag introduce sa mga pilipino na "ah, umaalpas na tayo sa dating style ng pagkwekwento."kung sa kwento naman, maganda rin ang attempt na talakayin ang abortion. pero sana pinalalim ito at iniugat sa isang patriyarkal na sistema â€” sa sports, sa healthcare, sa pamilya, sa eskwelahan, pati na rin sa relihiyon. patriyarka ang nagtutulak kung bakit nagiging taboo ang tungkol sa abortion sa lipunan pero hindi ito nabigyang linaw sa kwento. may attempt, oo. pero may takot ngunit gets naman ito dahil masyadong konserbatibo ang usapin lalo pa't sa bansa natin. indibidwal ang kwento na umiikot sa naratibo ni sunshine pero kung magpapakita ka ng lansangan ng kamaynilaan, ng kaguluhan sa kalunsuran, may gusto kang ipakita na tumatagos ito sa bawat taoâ€” nakaugat ito sa sistema ng lipunan.ang wish ko ngayon ay sana makuha ng mainstream audience filipino ang type ng silent film na madalas ginagawa ng asian films at tumiwalag sa mga western type ng psgkwekwento. baka rito, kayang mas maintindihan ang naratibo at emosyon ng isang tao at hindi humihingi ng spoonfeeding na parang nilalatag na mismo sayo na kailangan mong maintindihan ang mensahe nito sa gitna ng kaguluhan.dagdag: naramdaman ko sa sarili kong puke ang ginawa ni sunshine. sobrang galing ng scene na yon, nagtaasan ang balahibo ko. naalala ko lang ang mga reflection namin sa mp classes na "kailangan pa ba ipakita ang rape scene?" dito natuwa ako na pinakita ang pagpasok ni sunshine ng pampaabort sa kanyang puke at pakiramdam ko, dito mas nagagamit ang mga ganoong scenes. ang galing.

Little girl in pretty chains, dance for us.Sunshine is a total assault on the senses â€“ imagine the absurd demand for a girl to â€œdream and believeâ€ in a grimy, claustrophobic hell where rabid animals breathe down her neck at every second.Needless to say, this not really a film about gymnastics. Itâ€™s more about young Filipinas who want to write their own destiny, in spite of the gangrenous, decrepit, conservative society that tries to hold them down.Overall itâ€™s an excellently acted picture, even if the narrative gets overdrawn and soapy at the end... but if thatâ€™s what it takes to garner pathos from the target audience then so be it.Moral of the story:Do gymnastics to obtain the superhuman speed and explosive power to crush bottles over pedophilesâ€™ skulls. Oh and to join the Olympics I guess.

something felt lacking but i couldnâ€™t really pinpoint it, then i saw this review saying how personifying the lump of flesh in the charactersâ€™ wombs was such a weirdly pro-life thing to do. it reinforces the guilt that the religious people think we ought to feel if we decide to not give birth to a child. i also felt that this film was too two-dimensional and oversimplified (the same review i read mentioned that it wasnâ€™t shown who earned for sunshineâ€™s family & the repetitive lines of the religious people). it merely tackled sunshineâ€™s ambitions as a gymnast and her unwanted pregnancy, nothing more and less, when in reality, it is much more multifaceted than that. the fact that it also tried to be a bit neutral by not directly criticizng religion as the cause of it all kind of just puts me off? on the brighter side, this has more capability to appeal to the hardheaded conservatives than other sociopolitical films that will shout right at their face. it reminded me of my experience of pregnancy scare where i decided that i will kms if it turned out i rly was pregnant. it really, really captured how lonely and scary it felt, but unlike me, sunshine had the support system and the means to abort by the end. it made me wonder just how much more difficult it could have been for those without a reliable family to get pregnant. it angers me how i could have been in that positionâ€”it angers me how as we speak, thousands and thousands of children are experiencing it. all for the sake of a system of beliefs built up for them to cope with the uncertainty of life; that that same system is what was used as a means to control and colonize us which we still perpetuate.cried to this in the cinemas with anhzel, shane and ynah
Drown the noise. It will always be your choice.

Sunshine delivers a strong message that directly contests the religious nature of the Philippines. It highlights the severely lacking accessibility in women's healthcare and how abortion is a right (something our country still can't understand). It proves as a means of taking back what is rightfully ours - whether it be our dreams, our youth, or simply our freedom to choose. However, I felt that the movie missed the opportunity to bring layers of complexity to the plot. It could have discussed the struggle of Filipino athletes to secure funding from the government or showed more of society's scorn towards teenage pregnancies.Still doesn't negate the fact this is a good movie with good acting that made me tear up a bit :')

It's hard to be a woman like Sunshine in the Philippines. The decisions on their body and their future must conform to a forbidding, critical and at times unsympathetic society. As a result, unintended pregnancies are confided in whispers and resorted to unsafe abortion treatments. Antoinette Jadaone's film unravels the theme through the Sunshine's struggle from unsupportive partner up to the ironies of faith. May it serve to strike a conversation.One of the takeaways from the film is that a ray of sympathy and support to every woman like Sunshine makes a brighter future for our country.

A movie showcasing an aspiring knocked-up olympian explaining herself to her unborn daughter's the reason for terminating her pregnancy is quite confused if it wants to be a drama or a comedyâ€”a very Filipino movie. I firmly believe that the characters would react with quips given their context, but I think they are also written like that with the Filipino humor in mind. There is so much potential to the film's last act to be more emotional, but the scenes are terminated earlyâ€”just like the baby(ies).The film shines in the brightest in the acting department. Maris Racal, Jennica Garcia, and Meryll Soriano just lifts (and jumps, and flips). Was not a fan of the acting of the child. Her cursing at first is funny, but it's become a stretch by the end. Jadaone's direction is just perfection. Manila is depicted in it's rawness.

I think I've seen this film before....and thank God I liked the ending...horror genre at its peak. The decisions a someone in that situation goes through is immensely traumatizing and scary. A better support system is necessary and the movie was not shy to express that.

Bitin siya for me. Ang daming pwedeng i-explore pero hindi pinakita. Wala masyadong depth sa abortion process, â€˜yung emotional weight or aftermath. â€˜Yung kabaliwan ng main characterâ€”nandoon, pero parang hindi enough.Mas na-highlight â€˜yung pagtulong niya sa bata, which is okay, pero sana mas nakita rin natin how she helped herself. Like girl, youâ€™re spiraling, and all we got were hints. Parang kulang sa closure or kahit confrontation sa sarili.Sayang, kasi ang ganda ng premise. Sana lang mas sinagad pa.

I was going through a study just now for a work-related task I needed to finish, and I read something that made me think of this film again: *95 percent of Filipino youth disapprove of abortion* (how do you italicize text on the browser version? anyway...) Seeing that number shouldn't be surprising to me--I went to a private Catholic school until I was twelve and I grew up in an intensely Catholic household, surrounded by adults whose overflowing devotion often spilled into violent fanaticism; I went to mass every Sunday, made sure I finished my novenas before I went to bed, brought my rosary and prayer booklets with me everyday; Catholic imagery looms throughout every stage of my life and continues to haunt me, still (even in college I had bottles of holy water sitting on the window sills of my dorm room). I *should* know that Catholicism is so deeply entrenched within our culture, and that, of course, most people would disapprove of abortion because Catholic doctrine is so integrated in our epistemological structure that it basically wires the way we think and how we understand the world. I *should* know because up until high school, I couldn't fathom how other people don't consider the fetus as a full human being. That idea was unintelligible to me. Yet the fact that *95 percent* of young Filipinos disapprove of abortion (to be clear, this number varies depending on the given context e.g., if the mother's life were at risk, more people seem to be comfortable with the idea of abortion, although overall the numbers were overwhelmingly anti-abortion) still seems unreal to me, somehow. Maybe because I thought the world has gotten significantly more progressive now than it actually is. I guess this is why the decision to personify Sunshine's fetus and depict it as a fully fleshed-out little girl seemed initially off-putting to me. I just couldn't understand why a film that seems to be pro-abortion in its overall messaging would want to insert a plot device that seems to counter or undo that messaging (not to mention tonally incongruent with the rest of the film, which is mostly gritty drama)? But it does make sense. And I understand the intention behind that choice now. I think the little girl is less of a personification of Sunshine's unborn fetus, but more of a personification of Sunshine's Catholic guilt. Throughout the film, Catholic imagery looms in the background--we see it in her home, on the jeepney, in the streets. The film captures its embeddedness in Filipino culture in a way that isn't overstated. At the same time, it also captures how embedded Catholicism is in the Filipino psyche--and perhaps in a way that is occasionally overstated. Maybe there are better ways of showing how a young Filipino woman grapples with--and eventually overcomes--her Catholic guilt as she struggles for bodily autonomy, but personifying that guilt as a stubborn child and having the woman reason with it--reluctantly, aggressively, lovingly--also works (surprisingly well). I'd also like to emphasize how well-acted this film is! Obviously, Maris is the star here, and she definitely stands out, but all the background characters hold their own, even with such minimal lines and screentime (e.g. the Quiapo vendor, the inn receptionist, Rod). My only main criticism is that the plot point involving Rhed Bustamante seems crammed into the overall story, perhaps just to drive the point further home, especially for people who are still unconvinced that Sunshine's case makes abortion justifiable. And I can understand that, but it makes the film a bit too overstuffed for me, and the addition of Ariana could have been left out completely, since it was already clear what these imaginary children were supposed to represent. (Retroactively deducting half a star because I remembered that this film was still entered into Berlinale despite calls for a boycott)

Para sa isang lipunan kung saan nalilimitihan pa rin ang karapatan ng kababaihan, dadako at dadako ang mga ito sa 'illegal' na paraan para mabawasan ang pasan. How couldnt they?Sa loob ng pelikulang 'Sunshine,' binubuksan nito ang mahirap at hindi napaguusapang diskurso ukol sa karapatan ng kababaihan ayon sa kanilang katawan, aborsyon, guilt, morals, pati na rin ang Sexual abuse/harassment partikular sa mga kabataan o menor de edad. At sa kabilang banda naman, napoportray dito yung bond na nabubuo ng mga kababaihan sa loob ng pyudal na lipunan. Ilang beses akong naiyak habang nanonood, especially nung scene na ni Maris na nagtake siya ng pampalaglag. Ang bigat panoorin nito actually, kasi what do you mean na para mabawi ko yung buhay na mayroon ako before, kailangan kong pumunta ng Quiapo para bumili ng pampalaglag at pagdaanan yung sakit para lang duguin ako ulit? Sunod pa ay yung dinala si Rhed sa hospital dahil binuntis siya ng tito niya. 13 lang siya. Ang mga ganitong klaseng halimbawa ay pinapakita kung gaano ka-devastating yung fact na walang tulong ang narereceive ng mga kababaihan with this kind of situation. Meron naman siguro, pero mahirap at hindi lahat ay may kakayahang makakuha nitong "tulong" na ito dahil halos lahat ay kailangan ng pera.Nakaka-mind fuck yung situation ni Rhed (kahit short amount of time lang sha ron s film) kasi sa lipunan natin ngayon, ang daming batang babae ang nabubuntis, at bawat taon, pababa nang pababa ang edad ng mga ito. Ngunit, sino ba ang bumubuntis sakanila?Ang abortion ay hindi isang paraan upang mag-promote ng sarap sa sex sa mga kabataan;And with films like this, maganda yung na-aacknowledge na may ganitong klaseng pangyayari sa lipunan. Pero kagaya ng iba pang pelikula that tackles issues like this ay tulad ng 'Uninvited,' bakit hanggang acknowledge lang?Sa role ni Maris bilang Sunshine, pinapakita nito ang journey niya sa loob ng mundong nangguguiltrip and self-devoted Christians, matatanda, etc etc (at napepersonify itong guilt na to through the character of Bata (played by annika)), nakita niya na may mga batang nabubuntis, nakita niya na may judgement agad yung mga tao sa tulad niya, nakita niya na hindi madaling nakakatanggap at nakakahingi ng tulong yung mga nasa sitwasyon niyaâ€”pero even after all these, walang self-reflection or closure yung film or yung character ni Sunshine mismo (since first-hand niyang nawitness and naexperience lahat) sa lahat ng issue na naipakita. Parang "bahala ka na kung ano gusto mo isipin, basta eto yung pinapakita namin." Solid 6-7/10.

it was kind of crazy to enter a huge cinema house and see it packed for the first time since the pandemic, especially for a film as clearly pro-choice as this one. it was also in sunshine where i finally understood what people meant when they describe a performance as brave. maris' portrayal of sunshine is so stunning and raw and harrowing, it is easily the best part of a film that has, to be fair, a lot of great things going for it. solid and important, overall. every scene that showed the grime and reality of manila felt suffocating in a good way. it's just that one major plot device that didn't completely work for me. too on the nose and leaned too heavily on the melodrama, by the end of things

recently read the translation of farrokhzadâ€™s review/justification for golestanâ€™s the brick and the mirror where she said the film is a movement in a stagnant environment which should be in motion. i think that also applies to sunshine. philippine cinema (and even jadaone herself) has a tendency of producing movies that expand the capital. after all, you only get to have a second movie if your first one is profitable enough. from a moral perspective, sunshine is a dare to move something in philippine cinema. itâ€™s not the first stroke, of course, and not the boldest either, but this film occupying the same space that other safe bet family dramas and love team romcom is a shift we rarely see these days. itâ€™s a small ripple but it keeps the momentum (or at least rattle the conscience) in an environment that refuses to progress with time. i wish it was bolder, but it is angry, at least.

this is a story that is close to many womenâ€™s hearts. a story that we need right now with the rise on conservatism & esp with this issue still being as taboo as it is i think more than its execution, i loved the purpose. i loved how open and real and raw it talked about issues like abortion, catholic hypocrisy, even as far as incest which is an unspoken cause for many young womenâ€™s pregnancies in this country. i loved the gritiness it depicted manila. i loved seeing all the raw emotion and thoughts that come through a young womanâ€™s mind when it comes to an unwanted pregnancy and how sunshine navigates a very self righteous manila. i loved seeing it all from the background of a gymnast/athlete whoâ€™s stakes are so high and who u can feel this story a little more because of the pregnancy coming at the peak of her athletic career. i loved the small pockets of refuge sunshine found in various women, despite it feeling like the entire world was against her and especially coming from her sister. this movie is not without faults though. iâ€™ll be honest, i dont necessarily know what i feel about the child consciouness/magic realism. while i appreciate annika coâ€™s performance, it also felt jarring in such a grounded narrative. i think the story is powerful enough to stand on its own, and i was made to believe this was solely sunshineâ€™s story but it was more of sunshine + the girl with her presence being so omnipresent. i just felt a bit like it undermines the strength of the narrative when really, the film can move past using these devices. i also think the ending didnt stick the landing as much as i had hoped. i know this film assumes its audience to be smart & im grateful for that but sometimes it felt there was too much ambiguity/left up to interpretation to fully get into the story. there was just so much more to tell here i swear!still, like what i said, im a bigger fan of its purpose than its eventual execution. theres clearly so much grit and heart put into this film that i appreciate. marisâ€™ performance here (& jennicaâ€™s!!) is amazing, and i wish for the two to have such a long career ahead. i cried so many times, i felt my chest hurting so many times, i thought back to all the times women in my life have talked about these struggles, i went back to a time i thought i was pregnant & felt like my entire world was collapsing behind me. this is a very important and brave story and the kind that we need right now more than ever

Habang nasa kalagitnaan ng pelikula, nasabi ko na lamang sa sarili ko, â€œPara saan ba talaga â€˜tong pelikula na â€˜to? Ano bang point nito?â€ Yun pala, ako lang ang hindi agad naka-gets.Ang fucked up lang kasi isipin kung yung bata ay literal na physical manifestation ng nasa tiyan ni Sunshine, parang anim na taong gulang na anyo ng dapat sanaâ€™y magiging anak. Mas fucked up pa kasi kinokonsensya niya si Sunshine (tinawag siyang murderer). Pero later on na-realize ko: hindi siya totoong bata, kundi visual representation lang ng internal conflict ni Sunshine. Siya yung konsensya. Siya yung maliit na boses sa loob. Siya rin si Sunshine.Kaya hindi talaga tungkol sa journey ni Sunshine sa pag-abot ng mga pangarap niya ang pelikula. Mas tungkol ito sa batang karakterâ€”na hindi rin pala talaga bataâ€”at sa mas malawak na karanasang pangkababaihan. Kasi sa totoo lang, ang kwento ng abortion ay hindi tungkol sa bata. Ito ay tungkol kay Sunshine. Sa mga babae. Sa mga may katawan. Sa mga may kakayahang magdesisyon para sa sarili nila.Maganda naman ang ending. Medyo parang Modess commercial nga lang (charot). Pero kung tatanungin ako, feeling ko may kulang. Bilang manonood, hindi ko gaanong naramdaman ang bigat ng emosyon. Kulang sa lalim. Kulang sa hugot. Pero nabawi naman sa pagganap ng mga aktorâ€”walang tapon, mahusay ang lahat.Isang halimbawa ng kakulangan sa emotional connection para sa akin ay yung eksenang umiiyak si Sunshine sa loob ng inn habang isinasagawa ang abortion. Malapit na akong bumigay nun, ramdam na ramdam ko na, pero biglang nag-cut to a shot from outside the window of her emoting and yung maingay na traffic. Aesthetic, oo. Maganda, pero di ko gusto. Parang sinampal ako pabalik sa reyalidad na, â€œHoy, hindi ka kasama sa kwento.â€ Saksi ka lang. I donâ€™t know about you guys, but I donâ€™t like that.Favorite scene ko siguro ay yung early scene sa pelikula, yung umiiyak si Sunshine sa jeep. Maingay sa simula, tapos unti-unting tumahimik habang nakatutok lang ang lente sa kanya. Ang galing nun. Ang ganda. In addition, siksik sa intensyon ang mga detalyeâ€”katulad ng painting sa unahan ng jeep na may nakasulat na â€œGift from God.â€ Hala siya, eh di ikaw na ang tumanggap. (charot)Anyways, ang dami kong nasabi. Pero ngayon na lang naman â€˜to. Ang galing ni Maris. At isang malaking middle finger sa mga mahilig makialam sa buhay ng ibaâ€”lalo naâ€™t hindi naman hinihingi ang opinyon nila. Wala rin namang ambag. Oo, may ambagan!+0.5 star kasi super ganda ng official poster!!

No pussyfooting. No moral tightropes and softened edges. Just a filmmaker confronting what many still wonâ€™t say out loud.SUNSHINE is exactly the kind of film Philippine cinema needs right nowâ€”flawed and sometimes didactic, yes; but also fierce, deliberate, and unafraid. Antoinette Jadaone isnâ€™t interested in tiptoeing around which moral ground to stand on. Instead, she charges straight into the discomfortâ€”of female bodily autonomy, of shame and silence, of what choice looks like in a country that rarely allows one.In a society still steeped in religiosity and conditioned to conflate questioning with sin, this is a film that asks: What if we made space for empathy instead?Jadaone may have just delivered her finest hour. Interesting na rhythmic gymnastics ang sports ni Sunshine (Maris Racal). Hindi ito kilala sa ating bansa pero kitang-kita sa sports na ito na kailangan ng marinading determinasyon at disiplina hindi lamang sa larangan ng sports dito sa Pilipinas pati na rin sa paghahanda sa paglaban sa Olympics. Kaya naman ng mabuntis si Sunshine ay naharap siya sa isang desisyong babago sa kanyang buhay at sa mga tao sa paligid niya. Ilan sa mga isyu na nilatag ng pelikula ay ang kakulangan ng sex education at accessibility ng legal abortion sa Pilipinas dahil na rin sa konserbatibong paniniwala. Idagdag pa ang kulang na suporta ng gobyerno pagdating sa ating atleta tulad na lamang sa eksenang sila pa mismo ng pamilya niya ang naghanda ng kanyang isusuot sa Olympics. Religious hypocrisy din ang kinokompronta ng pelikula tulad sa eksenang giniguilt trip ng isang sarado Katoliko na OB GYNE at muli ring pang-guilt trip sa kanya ng pastor na ama ni Miggy kay Sunshine. Si Miggy ay pastor kid na nakabuntis sa dalaga. Hindi na rin naman bago ang pagtalakay ng abortion sa Pilipinas sa pelikulang Pilipino dahil nariyan ang "High School Scandal" (1982) sa direksyon ni Gil Portes at "Hinugot sa Langit" (1985) na pinagbidahan ni Maricel Soriano at dinirek ni Ishmael Bernal. Ang kagandahan ng pelikula ay babaeng filmmaker ang lumikha at alam niya ang nadarama at pinagdadaanan mapa-pisikal, emosyonal at sikolohikal ng kapwa babae. Napakahusay ni Maris Racal sa pelikulang ito. Ang laking tulong ng cinematog kasi 'yun ang nag-set ng tone at mood ng pelikula over-all. Somewhat reminded of "Gusto kita with all my hypothalamus" pagdating sa cinematog. Regarding sa discussion of abortion, medyo closer sa controversial indie film na "Call Jane".
despite its tonal inconsistency, I highly admire its narrative courage

one of the very few women centered filipino films that talks about a taboo topic in our country and it did a great job at showing the realities and effects of us not having the right to choose a safer option because of it being illegal. I really like how this film didnt shy away from showing the different people we encounter in our society and how they view what should be a basic right of women as criminal and how badly they shame them for choosing themselves and their dreams instead of an unborn fetus. yung line na "gets ko na" is so powerful ksi it came after numerous prejudices and it shows that coming from a place of understanding is much more important than just blindly enforcing your beliets unto others especially when you dont know their entire situation. one thing Ing na nagkulang ako is the dialogue and breaking point tiga ni sunshine. I wanted to hear what she has to say and how she feels mismo tlga not just through yung interactions niya with the people around her pero from her like bruh let her ACTTTToverall a much needed film in our country. ipapanuod sa mga pro lifers wahahahaha.

The script tackles a lot of issues that share deep commentary about our social reality. It's a social realism film with metaphysical personification of guilt and morality as I would call it. No matter what your political stance is, you can't deny how the script threaded with care and empathy towards women and women's health.I'm glad they went for an ambiguous ending because if not, it would've been too preachy and they would alienate or estrange a large group of people, but instead its rhetoric opened up an important topic to debate on. I actually agree that it's one of the most important Filipino films of modern times and it's Jadaone's strongest work yet.

the film's message is very clear.3.5 for now, since we missed the first few scenes which might have included the entire plot build up -- will definitely rewatch, so i am hoping for the best thaat the universe finds a way to add more show dates... or i'll just have to wait for it to become available on a streaming platform.definitely felt the authenticity of sunshine. i know for sure that sunshine is a character woven from real-life experiences of women in our society. and if one day we cross paths with a sunshine in our lives, i truly hope we meet her with compassion and empathy. nawa'y magawa natin siyang intindihin, yakapin, suportahan, at samahan siya nang walang halong pag-aalinlanganâ€”lalo na ang mga biktim ng mga tarantadong kalalakihan na punong-puno ng libido at kasinungalan sa katawan. tototo ang mga sunshine at ang kanilang mga karanasan.let women decide for themselves.let women speak for themselves.let women be heard.let women express themselves.women deserve choices and options.women should help women.men are trash. let's take down the patriarchy.gets din kita, shine. just like your siblings and best friend stayed with you until the very end, no matter what you chose, i am with you, sunshine. you will never be alone.

jadaone doesnâ€™t whisper this time (like the subtle hints in fan girl)â€”sunshine (2024) is loud, urgent, and painfully clear. a teenage gymnast finds herself pregnant before her olympic tryouts, and what follows isnâ€™t just her story, but the story of so many filipinas who are told to shrink themselves before theyâ€™re ever allowed to soar.you feel every breath, every silence, every jeepney horn in manilaâ€™s night. itâ€™s anxious, tender, and brutally real. sometimes the metaphors (like the child characters) felt a bit heavy-handed, but the heart of the film? unstoppable.more than a film, itâ€™s a cry for choice. sunshine didnâ€™t ask to be a symbol; she just wanted to fly. and watching her leap anyway broke me.

This was honestly just a sad movie. Even though you should be at least happy for Racal's character at the end. She went through hell and back just for the sake of her dream. It was a poignant (POIGNANT?!) commentary on a person's instinct to pursue one's dream and how it can lead to decisions and sacrifices to avoid compromise or delay. The other commentary is definitely about teen pregnancy/sex education/family planning in the Philippines. Despite having dramatized scenes, the burden that tolls on the characters is easily felt. Direk Tonet's writing, cinematography, directing, and overall vision really had a strong impact with this movie. Grabe talaga, its one of those films na babalikan mo in the future. Some people will never understand what it feels like to be a woman.Some will never understand what it feels like to be poor.Some will never understand what it feels like to have no choiceâ€”and to only be left with the harmful one.This film carries the burden of making you feel something about these topics and it does, effectively.It does not shy away from addressing these themes. Yet at the same time, the film never forces them down the audienceâ€™s throat. These issues are real. The depiction of Manila is painfully real. The horror of what Sunshine is going through feels immediate and heavy.Gorgeously shot. Gorgeously written. Gorgeously acted. This is Tonette at her bravest. Iâ€™m excited for what comes next.

Casts a revealing ray of light on the plight of women in the Philippines being held captive by outdated laws and hypocritical social mores on abortion. Maris Racal turns in an inspired peformance as a gymnast with dreams of competing in the Olympics. She was able to portray the emotional and psychological toll of her ordeal and the unwavering determination to follow her dreams at any cost. In the end, the film makes a strong statement that this could be the new breed of Filipinas, hardworking and capable of greatness. If the problem can fixed, then the country should be better off. Recommended viewing.

This film is not perfect. There are some storytelling choices that made me cringed and wished to have been done in a different way. But, it is definitely human. And what i admire it for the most is its bravery to tackle something that is truly taboo in today's society---and even more so in a country that hinges a huge part of its culture in religion. The point of "Sunshine" is to show you the reality being faced by women who are forced into motherhood just because the church and the government refuse to budge from their self righteous ground. To show how majority of this country sees the "unborn child" as human, but refuse to perceive the humanness in women, especially young ones, who are being stripped of their own rights to their body. Of course, they will feel cornered, and distressed, and forced to just settle it all on their own no matter how shady and dangerous the procedure might be. Because they are deprived of healthcare support and are even shamed for going through this. The film greatly tackles the rawness of that desperation to just...fix everything.You're just sure that so many filipino household that decided to watch this had polarizing opinions about it and may even have triggered an arguement. And I am glad for that, because it means Sunshine opened doors for this taboo discussion to be brought into the table. May there many more to come.

Still, Sunshine remains an important film, especially in a country like ours.

Because sometimes the best thing to do is to be selfish.Sunshine is a great pick to watch with your friends on a cold December night with popcorn kernels sprawled all over the floor.I coincidentally saw a gorgeous edit of the film on my For You page and found myself watching said film 9 hours laterâ€”curled up on my friendâ€™s couch and mentally cursing out the disordered state of our world for women. This movie tackles such important topics in a manner that just makes sense to me.For a country that prides itself on its gender equalityâ€”the Philippines being part of the Top 20 of the Global Gap Reportâ€”it hides myriads of abhorrent secrets that goes against women. This film places a pin on just that: sex being a taboo, ostracizing of teen moms, the weightlessness of menâ€™s actions and faults, the catholic guilt associated with abortions, and the lack of accessible healthcare. Sunshine outwardly tells the viewers that women are allowed to dream, to put theirselves first before the gripes of society. It tells us that our hypocrisyâ€”be it in our ethics or in our religionsâ€”creates a harder world for women to live in. You, much like Sunshineâ€™s ability to change and choose her performanceâ€™s music for the sole reason that she does not like it, have a choice in what you are and who you want to be. You are not just a womb nor a title.

So raw and beautiful. This film did not stray away from the dark underbelly of Manila where a church and stores selling abortion pills exist in close proximity. I love the scenes in the bustling city which acts as an embodiment of the chaos going on in sunshineâ€˜s mind. The hypocrisies and contention were explored but i wished the sister played a larger role, seeing as she also went through a pregnancy and seemingly without a husband. The magical realism worked for the most part. The scene of the girl (representing the unborn child?) understanding why Sunshine had to make the difficult decision of getting an abortion after seeing her kn her element at her gymnast was emotional.

i absolutely love how nuanced this is. how it took into consideration filipino contexts in discussing such a sensitive topic. i love the cinematography, absolutely stunning. captured the vibe of living in the busy and harmful streets of manila.discussed this with my gf but i find the heavy incorporation of religion in this quite integral to the story. while westerners may be able to discuss about abortion more openly, filipinos whose lives revolve around religion, are not at all the same. we were taught at an early age that religion is the absolute law, and we must follow every rule made in the name of religion. and so, the guilt sunshine carries throughout the film is heavier than ever, because not only was she dealing with the judgment of others, she was also dealing with the judgment of God, â€œThe Father.â€ And, surprisingly enough, I find the presence of the child important. At first, she bothered me a bit, how she accused shine of being a murderer, stopped shine from her attempts at abortion. Sheâ€™s the superego, the guilt that follows shine everywhere. But also, sheâ€™s a part of sunshine, hence her line â€œPangarap ko ang pangarap niya.â€ (non verbatim) and so, she too, wishes to see sunshine succeed. Her running to sunshine after her final performance and saying â€œgets ko naâ€ was her way of easing shineâ€™s guilt. After all, as people love to give life to everyoneâ€™s unborn child, then I guess this once, I too, shall make use of that. Viewing sunshineâ€™s life through the eyes of her â€œunborn childâ€ must have been painful, yet every child I know has questioned (at least once) how good of a life their mother wouldâ€™ve had, had they never been born. And just like every living child, the kid too, understood how much gymnastics meant to shine. And she was willing to trade the loss of her life for sunshineâ€™s happiness, because she will always be a part of sunshine.

Sunshine affected me deeply. The film explored womenâ€™s autonomy with so much honesty, and the charactersâ€™ struggles and victories felt incredibly real. I loved how it showed the layered challenges that come with unwanted pregnancies and the emotional, physical, and social weight women carry. The story treated its themes with grace and intelligence, and I truly believe it deserves a wide audience.One of the most powerful elements came from Sunshineâ€™s relationship with her sister. Watching the difficulty of her sisterâ€™s life, especially the reality of raising a child, shaped her own decision. It felt like she saw her future in that picture, a future filled with sacrifices and dreams placed on hold. That glimpse alone said so much about choice, survival, and the pressure placed on women.The film also opened an entire landscape of conversations. Misogyny, womenâ€™s choices, abortion, body autonomy, laws, healthcare, and the quiet burdens carried by women in this country. These are everyday truths, yet they rarely reach the screen with this level of sincerity. I crave more stories with this courage, stories that explore mature themes with depth and curiosity. This film touched many important ideas and left me eager for even richer layers. Symbolism filled the entire narrative, and I loved how each detail carried emotional weight. I could spend an entire afternoon unpacking everything.One scene stays with me the most. The motel sequence. The stillness, the rumble of the train, her actions, and the aftermath created a breathtaking moment. That scene captured the danger of doing something unfamiliar to oneâ€™s body and the immense pressure created by law and religion. It felt intense, raw, and beautifully crafted.And the presence of the kid as her guilty conscience completed the emotional arc in such a striking way. It felt like a final haunting reminder of everything she carried.

What I love the most of this film is the face-on paradoxes that unfortunately reflects the reality. You see a doctor, who is supposed to save lives regardless, ignore a teenager because she took pills. You see the main character fully knowing the consequences of her actions but most people around her thinks she should do this or that. And you see pro-life always insisting that the aborted children could be someone great, but never giving a glance to thoseâ€¦

The cinematography, the composition, the colours, and the character were all absolutely stunning. This was obviously handled with so much care and love, as it should be, you can tell that the director has a clear vision of exactly what she wants the film to feel and look like which was executed flawlessly. I will never know what itâ€™s like to be a woman with child but this film made me feel all the conflicted, complicated, and crushing emotions of what itâ€™s like to make that oh so difficult decision. Yes itâ€™s incredibly sad yet she has to make the choice thatâ€™s best for her even though it literally breaks every inch of her soul. It accurately portrays Filipino societyâ€™s perception around abortion and how religion and gender roles play an integral part in the whole ordeal when it absolutely should not. It should be between the woman and her doctor alone, the outsiders opinion only makes this life altering decision so much harder than it already is. Itâ€™s so wonderfully nuanced and so so beautiful, thank you for keeping Filipino cinema alive Sunshine. I also loved that her kid had a rainbow shirt on which comes after a sunshine.

â€œPangarap ko din mga pangarap mo, Sunshineâ€This movie was so beautifully written, directed and acted. Grabe, hands down kay maris kasi ramdam na ramdam mo yung emosyon niya and struggle throughout the whole movie. This literally depicts women around the philippinesâ€”-no matter what economic class they may beâ€” when it comes to teenage pregnancy. Whether or not we care to admit it, no teenage pregnancy is planned and the toll that has on a developing woman will never ever ne experienced by ANY man. So miggy, pakyu.Pero grabe, you can feel the internal battle Sunshine was going through and I think that every single woman who has a dream, a goal in life perhaps, if situated the same, would go through the same lengths. Maybe not through all of that extent, but this is such an eye opening movie to those who still feel like abortion in the philippines is taboo. You would literally rather have all these women dying instead of getting and giving them the right medical treatment? These are children, btw. Yes, they did adult things but bear in mind that there is no such thing as a consenting child in the eyes of the law.Oh Antoinette Jadona, the woman that you are. Thanks for showing us a movie that says na we can choose ourselves. We can decide our future and no amount of guilt tripâ€”whether it be from the church or from any ball-lacking manâ€”can stop us from persuing that.

â€œSunshineâ€ hit me way too real. It made me think about my mom and all the dreams she had before life rushed her. Sometimes I wish I could go back and tell her she could skip my part for a moment and chase everything she wanted.

some bits I especially liked: - sunshine praying just outside the church, feeling unworthy to enter for what she's about to do- her sister helping her stretch her shoulders, trying to motivate her by saying "SEA games" "olympics" and so on, accidentally doing what is opposite her intention and instead adding a burden to sunshine's shoulders. - the focus on rape-incest cases. it happens so much in our country but its been kept under wraps for way too long. im glad a film that has gained this much traction helped put it, and the many ways that it's the mothers and maternal figures that facilitate such violations of their own children has been put to light. i felt conflicted watching what is supposed to be these imaginary consciousnesses of unborn children running about and acting as, what i initially thought to be, a device for invoking guilt in these young and unwilling kids and anger in its audience. but perhaps they were an avenue for the world to understand that while they have a future too, so does sunshine. so does the thirteen year old. what are these pastors and doctors planning for /their/ future? anyways im glad the movie stuck by its pro-abortion stances and did not pull back any punches. women's and children's healthcare has been on a serious decline in this country. its high time we see changes that put women as priority not some hypothetical individual.

Sunshine itu film yang keliatannya lembut, tapi makin lama ditonton makin kerasa nyentil. Ceritanya ngikutin seorang remaja yang harus menghadapi tekanan dari lingkungan, keluarga, sampai norma sosial yang bikin hidupnya seolah bukan miliknya sendiri. Banyak hal dibiarkan ambigu, tapi justru itu yang bikin interpretasinya hidup. Kita diajak ngikutin proses dia ngambil kembali kendali atas tubuh dan masa depannya, pelan-pelan, tanpa drama berlebihan. Aku merasa ada satu titik di mana semuanya terasa klik. Bukan karena dijelasin, tapi karena apa ya bisa pahamlah gitu dari caranya bersikap dan bertindak.Akhirnya juga bukan yang gimana-gimana, tapi ya kerasa personal dan melegakan. Intinya sih, ini sebuah film tentang betapa susahnya perempuan punya pilihan di tempat yang konservatif, dan gimana tetap bisa berdiri di atas kaki sendiri meski nggak ada yang dukung.

Worth the year long wait, brilliant film and really cements Antoinette Jadaone as an Auteur of Philippine Cinema. I think what I found so strikingly sad about this is that, fourteen years removed from the Philippines (more than half of my life!); I try to tread carefully when I talk about Manila, the people and their struggles. I don't think that my incredibly sheltered memory of the place would hold as much cultural weight than that of a local, and yet fourteen years later Manila is still...Manila. And if I am brought to tears by this, I wonder about the grief carried by generations of young women failed by a dated system. In all her films, what Jadaone ultimately wants, or rather demands for her female protagonists, is Space. Space to exist safely and choose freely.To break women out of crowded public maternity wards with shared beds, obsolete facilities, abject doctors (with their religious biases), and to bring them into the clearing of their dreams, the main-stage gymnasium, the Olympics.

â€œAyoko maging nanay. Hindi ko ipapanganak â€˜to dahil hindi ako ready maging nanay.â€ / English: I donâ€™t want to be a mother. I wonâ€™t give birth to this child because Iâ€™m not ready to become a mother.Abortion is illegal in the Philippines, heck even being pro-choice here is looked down upon. Yet, motherhood is an expected life trajectory for many Filipino women, that is if you marry at the â€œright ageâ€ and have more than 1 child at the â€œright timeâ€. So what choice do women have if they are pregnant under different circumstances? For a country that claims to be collectivist (pakikipagkapwa tao mindset ang dapat pinapairal, etc.), how can this principle become a universal behavior for most when its own government continues to throw its own citizens under the bus? Every dire problem that needs to be addressed can be traced back to how fucked Filipinos are by their government. Whatever rhetoric the Spaniards spread about Filipinos being â€œlazyâ€ is still used today by the rich and powerful, their basis why the Philippines continues to be poor. Galit na galit ako sa nagtitinda ng mga pekeng â€œgamotâ€ para sa pagpapalaglag ng bata, the review she showed Sunshine that it was effective could possibly be fake, pero narealize ko na nagbebenta sila ng pekeng solusyon para maka ahon sa buhay (not justification of this behavior). This government continues to fail people in every aspect of life, youâ€™d realize why the crime is so high. But is it such a crime to not want a baby? (It is not).How can Filipinos truly care for the children (whether born or unborn) when elected officials undermine reproductive health in this country, primarily womenâ€™s health. The Reproductive Health Law faced a long legislative battle just to get passed, and it still took two years for the law to be fully accessible for the public. When your prospects are so thin, people will do anything to get what they want, even if it costs their life. That is a hard pill to swallow for a lot of Filipinos. At the end of the day, Filipinos are treated as just mere statistics in politics.

this is a film that shows several harsh realities that many young women face every day. it tackles sensitive yet crucial issues such as unplanned pregnancy, illegal abortion, sexual assault committed by a family member, the heavy influence of religion on decision-making, and how one snap can completely shatter a young personâ€™s future. these themes are not exaggerated; they are painful and real. â€œMahirap maging babae, mas lalo na babae sa Pilipinas.â€the film drop a reality line about women especially here in the philippines. this resonates the lived experiences of countless young women who grew up navigating a society that often blames them first before offering help.the movie also embodied the noisesâ€”the noise of judgment from society, the noise of broken dreams, and the noise coming from people who desperately need help but have nowhere to turn. it speaks out that the loudest sound isnâ€™t the chaos of Manilaâ€™s streets, but the silent cries of countless helpless women. the film exposes the flaws in our cultural, social, and institutional systems, making it easy to see where we are lacking the most.the scene showing the overcrowded OB department in a public hospital was somehow alarming. itâ€™s chaotic, understaffed, and overcrowdedâ€”yet this reflects reality. it reveals how instead of creating long-term solutions, government tend to simply acknowledge the issue or, worse, disregard it. the systems remain weak and unresponsive.beyond all of these social issues, the film also shows how dreams can easily collapse under the weight of societal pressure. this makes the film more than just a filmâ€”it becomes a moviefied reflection of the everyday struggles of filipino youth, especially young women who are forced to grow up too fast.overall, the movie sunshine is a wake-up call. itâ€™s a call for empathy, understanding, and meaningful change.

Sunshine is a feat for Philippine cinema. It tackles a topic most are scared to produce and it was written WELL. Yes, without the poverty porn or political porn most films of ours subtexts. There are characters that are REAL. Not written to tell unjustly-unrelated issues but to support the story itself. And so, characters that are in poverty arenâ€™t written to convey another message, rather to stand with what the film is about in the first place. This film is easily the one of the best written films of all time in our history. Not only does it tell a beautiful picture of a character undergoing such a life-turning â€œaccidentâ€ but how it tells it psychologically, and powerfully. It never let go of what it portrays nor does it settle for a scene that would bring in viewers, itâ€™s written SO realistically that youâ€™d forget itâ€™s a movie. A quick one to point out is Sunshine texting her bestfriend, at the time she needs support the most, even if sheâ€™s disappointed for losing contact with her, she still texts out of fear, and thatâ€™s something iâ€™m sure plenty of people have done. Those text messages are so real, raw and incredibly well-written too. The whole story is an absolute masterclass of writing a film straightforwardly without losing the essence of what it is. Itâ€™s a display of perfect world-building, from the story of her boyfriend, the realistic response from him to the story of the tindera, who without building a relationship, completely makes sense of the film. Even built a subtext of a no nonsense coach that adds to fear, support, motive and regret of the main character.I can tell you all about the beautiful writing but this would be too long. Letâ€™s get to the cinematography. Well, itâ€™s good. Definitely better than most films, itâ€™s quite obvious that certain camera works and shots arenâ€™t just to finish the scene but is chosen to look good while portraying a scene nicely. Thereâ€™s a lot of cues that whispers visually, like how she prays with bars infront of her, evoking the feeling of our character not FEELING or BEING welcome inside the church. Shot-selections like those sre essential and quite reliable to make a scene impactful so iâ€™m incredibly proud they excerted better effort to make this film the best it could possibly be. Wouldnâ€™t say itâ€™s a strong suit, but this fil is definitely visually well-made.Iâ€™ve always seen Maris Racal as a great actress before this, now sheâ€™s PHENOMENAL one and is one of the best in the industry right now. One of the biggest factors holding back the Philippines from being as progressive as our neighboring countries like China and Japan is our deep entanglement with religionâ€”Christianity, in particular. As much as faith shapes our culture, it also becomes a hindrance to national progress when religious beliefs are imposed on matters that should prioritize the welfare and rights of all citizens. Imagine how much better our society could be if we allowed personal freedoms and evidence-based policies to guide our decisions, instead of insisting on religious doctrine as the standard for everyone.The movie portrayed this reality so powerfully. It addressed so many issues in one narrativeâ€”how women are often the ones who suffer the most under a misogynistic system, how men can easily walk away from responsibilities while women cannot, and how horrifying it is that young girls, even minors, can be raped and then forced to bear a child. These are the consequences of a society that refuses to give women full autonomy over their own bodies.I truly hope more people come to realize the importance of allowing women to make decisions for themselves by legalizing abortion. Every woman deserves the right to choose what happens to her own body.Despite the heaviness of the story, Iâ€™m glad that Sunshine still managed to pursue the dream she longed for, proving that resilience can still bloom even in the harshest circumstances.

Reproductive health in the Philippines still has a long way to go. Unsafe abortion practices, severely misinformed women, archaic religious politics; there are so many wrongs in this country that make it harder for women to live. Sunshine is a movie that reflects how people and women in this country view abortion. This is evident in the imaginative character of the kid that Sunshine interacts with, which is her possible daughter in the future if she chooses to proceed with her pregnancy. In the ending, we get an assuring â€œgets ko naâ€ which might have been what Sunshine needed to hear regardless if the child was real or not. I think this is an example of how we Filipinos view the nature of abortion, needing a verbal agreement from an unborn person before terminating. Iâ€™m not saying this is a bad thing, don't get me wrong, but I think it is an interesting portrayal of catharsis that Filipinos would resonate to. And it seems like it did. Mabuhay ang pelikulang Pilipino!

this feels very similar to brocka in that it portrays manila as a city full of hardship and loneliness that can leave you so disillusioned and alienated; and where hope and humanity exist on the fringes of it. it's a working-class story with working-class sentiments that fully takes on its own identity because jadaone is able to portray such familar elements in a way that feel completely isolating; the interiors of jeepneys, tricycles, shabby motels, clinics â€” everything feels so alien. which, i guess, offers many people unfamiliar with what these woman go through a much-needed perspective on the importance of dignity and bodily autonomy and how violent, horrible men try to take that away from many women.i think it's also worth noting that religion and patriarchy play such a prominent role here in oppression; jadaone laser-focused on placing religious beliefs and preconceived notions about abortion in the spotlight, all the more affected by teenage pregnancy and how religion has kind of shaped the way many filipinos treat abortion as something so taboo and inhuman that they completely forget how it affects the mother. and it's brought to life by a really incredible maris racal; shaped by all the adversity â€” the kind of performance that requires you to bare your soul to the audience, to beg them to see the humanity behind the people suffering from religious oppression, and why access to abortion services â€” even in a heavily catholic country â€” is of utmost importance.

stream-of-consciousness review (iâ€™ll edit it later): her younger self got mad at her for losing her friend (which i presume was rhedâ€™s baby) cause her younger selfâ€™s view on abortion was that itâ€™s morally wrong. the scene where she made peace with her younger self felt like the magic piece that ties this excellent film together. i love how introspective and culturally true this film is. although scene-setting would have made it better like showing sunshineâ€™s house from the outside, where she lives - more sceneries that show her life.the actress playing her sister gave the best performance in this film. the subtle moves, the eyes, the persona. the abortion topic, of course, is a daring one to talk about for a film by a filipino to be watched by filipinos. abortion is completely illegal and prohibited here, with penalties for those who perform or obtain one. the film successfully tackled a sensitive subject in good taste. i also saw the religious lady doctor character as a commentary on the non existent secularism in the country. that lady confronted with the sister was satisfying to watch.

Whenever Sunshine waves around her colorful ribbon while flowing and gliding through the mat, it's not just a flawless routine at stake. It's the little bit of life growing inside her.Maris Racal anxiously walks through the streets and markets of Quiapo, looking for a way out in the form of illegal drugs hidden beside statues of Mama Mary. Sunshine knows what she wants â€”to be on the Olympic stage, but the world around her from the kid who knocked her up, to the saleslady who's "helping" her, to her sister who also got pregnant, may have different opinions.Sunshine stops by the church, pleading for clarity but also possibly for forgiveness and absolution. But a ghost in the form a kid that calls her a "murderer" haunts her the most, popping in and out like a conscience. She was nervously waiting to see what Sunshine would finally decide, and so was I.Pelikulang Pinoy ğŸ‡µğŸ‡­

dancing as a form of emotional release, resistance, setting one's self freeâ€”that particular scene is so emotional, and i love how they portrayed the child as grudgeless and accepting. i mean, philippines has tiyanak, but even its origin is a social imposition. one would wonder, what would the child actually feel? if i was the child, i would be more than grateful to not be born in this economy. also love the bits where it quietly proclaims: women help women and we've got each other's backs. it highlights the reality that men are the true antagonists in every woman's story of suffering.maris racal's magnum opus, for now.

the film moves slowly, almost cautiously, letting you sit with people who are trying to hold their lives together even when everything around them keeps slipping sideways. nothing is exaggerated; it all feels painfully ordinary in the way real lives are. the characters are not shouting for answers, they are just trying to make sense of the days piling up. there is this constant push and pull between wanting to break free and accepting that the world has edges you cannot always escape.no big revelation, no sudden salvation. just a slow unraveling-that honesty hits harder than any dramatic twist could. thank you

It was true when they said that this was a brave film. To be one of the first films in pinoy cinema to explore a pro-choice and an unwanted pregnancy narrative is indeed brave, especially when you know the Philippinesâ€™ socio-political and religious climate around topics regarding sex, female desires, pregnancy, bodily autonomy, and parenthood.There were unfortunately some parts of the film that felt like they didnâ€™t work.Iâ€™m not sure but Sunshineâ€™s decision to abort felt too quick. And her dream to be an Olympian felt underexplored and more of her coachâ€™s. Weâ€™re told rather than shown that it was hers.The inclusion of Annika Co whose character can be interpreted as Sunshineâ€™s subconscious/ego or unborn child or whatnot sometimes felt irritating to watch (sorry not sorry). But I guess to reach more towards a predominantly Filipino audience and to highlight Sunshine still being a (teen) child whoâ€™s forced to confront the consequences of her choices by a child: worked? I donâ€™t know. Not to mention that it felt a little silly to include two other characters, where one was another pregnant teen girl, that lowkey felt like their stories were being shoved down to the audienceâ€™s throats. And in the end, felt shallow. I just think that I hoped they showed more of the technicalities of her being an athlete. Rhythmic gymnastics is considered an elite sport. And when you consider it in the Philippine context â€“ the film didnâ€™t really show what was at stake of being an athlete in this sport. The filmâ€™s strong aspects are definitely on the score, cinematography (particularly to highlight the corners of Manila as this chaotic, packed, and cruel city), and of course: Marisâ€™ performance as Sunshine. There were scenes that hit hard and heavy. The irony of abortion drugs sold and found in the street outside a church. The motel scene to show Sunshineâ€™s quiet desperation. Her final rehearsal for her routine before her â€œgets ko naâ€ scene with Annika (where I cried unfort bcz luteal phase duh).The film does show you a glimpse of the unforgiving reality of what many Filipino women go through everyday: teenage pregnancy, overcrowded and underfunded public hospitals, and the lack of comprehensive sexuality education about sexuality and sexual and reproductive health. It lacked, sure. But I guess, for pinoy cinema to start tackling difficult topics such as this: itâ€™s a start.
