â€œnaiintindihan mo ba ako?â€oo, gets ko na.â€this film is raw, relevant and worth seeing. it goes to show that itâ€™s not about changing oneâ€™s political belief, but about having radical kindness. the film doesnâ€™t intend you in changing sides, but it teaches you to be more understanding of peopleâ€™s choices. iâ€™ve known sunshines in my life - a co-worker, a co-workerâ€™s sister, close friends, and old classmates back home. and itâ€™s just sad just how much they were under scrutiny for, for something they should have total control over. it infuriates me even further to realize that back home, abortions are not accessible, and are illegal even. oftentimes the women are frowned upon because of our countryâ€™s conservative and religious culture, they face shame and judgement first before they can even get to decide of their own autonomy. meanwhile, the men that are responsible can get to walk away from all scrutiny just because itâ€™s not theirs to hold and carry. to all the sunshines that we know, get to know and may not know yet, they deserve to talk about these things openly, not in secret, not in shame. sunshine reminds us that we definitely have a long way to go. yet a little empathy can go a long way.

This is a blistering, gut-punching film that doesnâ€™t just ask difficult questions about bodily autonomy and Olympic dreams; it screams them into the humid, chaotic reality of Manila. Itâ€™s a brave, essential piece of cinema that confronts the devastating consequences of living in a country where a womanâ€™s control over her own body is perpetually under threat. The cinematography is nothing short of breathtaking and utterly visceralâ€”itâ€™s relentless, trapping us inside Sunshineâ€™s suffocating anxiety. Jadaone uses the oppressive visual texture of Quiapoâ€™s crowded, sweltering streetsâ€”a perfect, gritty backdropâ€”to symbolize the labyrinthine journey of a young woman navigating impossible choices in a system designed to fail her.A massive and well-deserved standing ovation goes to the central performances. Maris Racal is devastating as the titular gymnast, embodying the crushing physical and emotional burden with every strained muscle and every desperate, silent plea. Her performance is a masterclass in controlled despair, capturing the agony of a lifetime of sacrifice being threatened in an instant. She is perfectly complemented by Annika Coâ€™s mesmerizing, eerie, and unrelenting presence as the Kidâ€”an unsettling narrative device that functions as both Sunshineâ€™s internal critic and her desperate conscience. But letâ€™s be real: the filmâ€™s rawest emotional hook comes from the shocking failure and apathy of the men around her. Their irresponsibility and sheer lack of accountability form a central, infuriating symbol of the patriarchal society that traps Sunshine.Ang hirap maging babae sa Pilipinas. Every day feels like a battle against a society na paulit-ulit kang nilalagay sa kahon, insisting that your worth begins and ends with motherhood. Fuck the stigma na finoforce ang mga kababaihan into roles they never agreed toâ€”parang automatic default na lang na dapat tahimik, dapat magtiis, dapat magpakamartir. Walang puwang para sa sariling pangarap, sariling katawan, sariling desisyon.Kaya sana mas umingay at mas mapag-usapan ang Reproductive Rightsâ€”hindi lang as a â€œwomenâ€™s issueâ€ but as a basic human right. This is about giving women the freedom to choose, the safety to seek care without judgment, and the dignity to exist without being shamed or controlled. Hanggang hindi natin tinatalakay nang seryoso ang mga ito, paulit-ulit lang tayo sa cycle ng stigma, trauma, at kawalan ng choices.Being a woman here shouldn't feel like a punishment. It shouldn't demand silence in exchange for survival. And yet, dito sa Pilipinas, ganun pa rin ang realidadâ€”and thatâ€™s exactly why conversations like this matter.Putangina, Miggy/Miguel na naman!

By film standards, this is nothing new. The story is simple, sometimes too simple, no room for nuance and reading between the lines - and one device it uses feels overused (until that end scene). But itâ€™s the kind of movie Philippine cinema needs. One that sheds light on a societal issue and gets conversations going. Jadoaneâ€™s Manila is tragically beautiful and beautifully tragic at the same time, bleeding with so much color, effervescence, but doesnâ€™t lose its danger and darkness in every street corner. But the heart of Sunshine is Racalâ€™s performance, showing us this is more than just the â€œabortionâ€ film, but one that empathizes the plight of most Filipino women on what itâ€™s like to grow up and live in a society that doesnâ€™t care about you or your struggle. Your dreams are my dreams too.

Sunshine (2024) serves as a powerful and eye-opening film, especially for us Filipinos. As someone working in the healthcare field, I believe the movie highlights an important truth: abortion should not be treated as a taboo subject or inherently immoral. Whether we acknowledge it or not, there are women who do not wish to become pregnant or are not ready to become mothers. Criminalizing abortion does not stop it from happening; it merely drives women toward unsafe procedures that place their lives at greater risk.If one personally identifies as pro-life, then one has the choice not to pursue abortion. However, holding that belief does not grant anyone the authority to dictate or restrict what women can do with their own bodies, especially when they do not contribute to the wellbeing of the child these women may be forced to bear. The health, autonomy, and safety of women must remain our priority. It is time to end the stigma surrounding reproductive choices and to uphold the separation of religion and state in policymaking.

I really applaud Sunshineâ€™s determination to chase her dreams and stay strong in the face of her friends ignoring her and her boyfriend not wanting to take responsibility for their child. Aside from her, I also applaud her family for staying by her side regardless of what her decision may be. â€Ay nako! Talaga naman ang mga kabataan ngayon hindi na makapagpigil.â€Throughout Sunshine, there are several adult figures that do not listen to Sunshine, blinded by either their convictions or Filipino societal norms. They push Sunshine on what she must do: pray, seek forgiveness, give the baby a life, be a mom, and pray. In the adultsâ€™ eyes, Sunshine is not a nineteen-year-old Filipina in Manila going to school and practice. To the adults, Sunshine is already a mom.On Saturday, the Filipino noontime show Itâ€™s Showtime invited parents with 7 or more children for their game Laro, Laro, Pick. A majority of the contestants were women, and two of the mothers interviewed, Elsa and Rosalie, had 15 and 8 children respectively. Elsa, the 63-year-old woman with 12 living children and 3 deceased children recited the ages of her 12 children from the oldest, 46, to the youngest, 24. The gap between the older ones is 1-2 years apart, while the younger ones are about 2-3 years apart. Elsa confesses how difficult life is for her and her children, spouting how without God she would not be as strong as she is today, living off 300 pesos everyday. When Vice Ganda asked Elsa why she has so many children, Elsa plainly said, â€œEhhh di ako marunong mag family planning eh,â€ inciting some laughter in the audience. Elsa even revealed that the father was absent and had a different family, leaving the Filipina mother and her 12 living children to figure out how to live.The second woman, Rosalie, with 8 children echoed the same sentiments as Elsa. She sells sampaguita every day with no days off at the age of 60 something; her children married and had their children early; the highest level of schooling one of her children attained was high school, but never graduated; her children sell sampaguita with no days off; and she has 19 grandchildren to look after in a home with no roof above their heads.What Sunshine, Elsa, and Rosalie have in common is how the patriarchy confines them to suffocating religious ideals, a corrupt and conservative government, and poor healthcare. What Sunshine does not have in common with the two women is the ignorance in family planning. Sunshine is no one's mother! It should never be a reason to have 7 or more children at an early age, with no means of support financially and emotionally, because it is "God's gift," or because they simply want to experience having children. The favorite catchphrase, "Kase malakas ako, kaya ko to" can only thrive for so long with honesty until oppressors abuse the Filipina determination. Access to sexual education MUST be a right, not a privilege nor a taboo subject. Children do not decide when they want to be born, so there should be conscious efforts to assess if the environment people live in can secure their children's/childrens' future(s), especially in a country like the Philippines. Unfortunately, there are connections to poverty and the lack of interest and access to proper education. There is also the inability for Filipinos in poverty to seek other options, or have the real agency to pursue aspirations. While there is such thing as being irresponsible, Filipino women are a laughingstock in conversations surrounding teen pregnancy and reproductive rightsâ€”when realisticallyâ€”they should have the choice to protect themselves, but are instead ruthlessly flayed off by the very system that commands kindness.[Minor spoilers ahead]Annika Co manifests herself as (what I think) Sunshine's Catholic guilt. We first meet Annika after Sunshine prays outside of Quiapo Church and is about to light a cigarette. Annika appears whenever Sunshine does something that will affect the fetus, and often berates Sunshine for being "bad." At first, I was hesitant towards the idea of Annika representing Sunshine's potential child, because it can mistakenly support the pro-life argument of murder (which Annika actually yells at Sunshine), until Annika says, "ang pangarap ko ay pangarap niya." SOBRANG bigat yung line na yan! In a sense, Sunshine and Annika are the same person. Sunshine should be able to pursue her dreams successfully the same way Annika, along with other living and future children, should feel secure enough to be ambitious. The message further builds itself with Ariana, Annika's friend and the 13-year-old girl's potential child. Ariana wants to be the first gay president, but how can they do that in an environment with a r*pist, a neglectful grandmother, and a KID whose choice was stolen?If mothers like Elsa and Rosalie can somehow "get away" with no family planning, how can Sunshine and the 13-year-old girl survive in a Catholic Philippines? The Reproductive Health Law was passed in December 2012, and efforts to educate the masses and distribute contraceptives have improved, yet there is still a high percentage of unintended pregnancies, AIDS rates, and JUSKO POâ€”ISSUES WITH BUDGETING (source 1),(source 2) !!!!!! The Philippines will never progress as a nation if objectivity is blocked by the grip the church and the state have on one another, which ultimately and consistently harms Filipinas who give their best yesterday, today, and tomorrow.I am certain that Sunshine is not the first film to be unapologetically bold and loud for the Filipina, but it is certainly the first to make rounds among the casual movie-goers and the general Filipino. It is not a perfect film and such flawed instances are where:- the narrative of Sunshine being an Olympic-level athlete clashes with the lack of popularity shown outside of practice- the cinematography is poetic without a doubt, but the scenes of Sunshine messaging her Coach, Miggy, and Thea isn't synchronized with Sunshine typing on the phone/isn't even her actually texting. If you're going to place emphasis on the quietest scenes, I believe that something as minor as texting should be clean (this was the same quip I had with the controller scene in Anora like c'mon now....)- the cinematography can be too poetic. for example, the shot of Sunshine looking out of her hotel window with the Metro Manila noise juxtaposing her quiet turmoil contributes to Sunshine purposely not drowning out the noise (or the failure to?), but I found it unnecessary because right after she woke up in pain. the juxtaposition felt like it was purely for aesthetics- the Jojo Rabbit esque character of Annika and Ariana was VERY risky (re: pro-life arguments)- maybe it's just me but the film gives you some breathers with comedic aspects in things like "no bad words" and Annika proceeding to say "putangina" which I found myself like "damn girl ! ! !" though it makes me wonder if those who do not share the same ideals as me laughed at it the same way the audience laughed at Elsa in Laro Laro Pick. In a not long-winding way, and assuming negatively, if tonal shifts struck the audience as a serious matter and not a reactionary narrative.- the last 3 paragraphs of this review regarding how art can effectively stand by its purposeAng hirap maging isang Sunshine sa Pilipinas, at hindi pinaguusapan kahit eto ang reality ng karamihan ng babae at batang babae. Women can dream for themselves. Women can learn to protect for themselves if there are resources available by sources that make themselves available. Women are strong, but you cannot glorify them to always be strong at the expense of exploitation. Sunshine is many of the first steps in Philippine cinema that can continue the conversation. I hope the film incites action in Filipinos to call out the current and future administration, who, under the guise of a devotee to a forgiving religion, perpetuates being uncritical and whose laziness is a disservice to the Filipino people. And most importantly, may Filipinos denounce the administration's vigor in committing violence against them, and reclaim the autonomy all Filipinos are born with.

"naiintindihan mo ba ako?"Sunshine, at its core, is a film that aims to make the people who watch truly understand. hopefully to also change minds but for that to happen, dapat maintindihan muna kung bakit. and in the spectrum of making films that want to make people listen, Sunshine sits perfectly in the middle. hindi masyadong dinikta yung mensahe to the point that it may be a bit too "preachy" kahit walang substance, pero hindi rin nasobrahan sa spectacle at drama at kinulang sa tapang to the point that the message gets blurred. this was a very well executed show and not tell, and show it did.plus everyone was just soooo good. ang husay ng pag arte ng lahat. maris, jennica, annika???? ang husay. no acting to take you out of the scene, no lines to remind you that you're watching a film aiming to be a commercial success (which is a pinoy movie disease, the infamous hugot line syndrome)simple lang. the story was straightforward. it knew what it wanted to tell and it delivered. the topic was handled with care without shying away from the heaviness of it. visually stunning, i love seeing manila filmed as it is and have it be a setting that adds to the storytelling. technically admirable, without losing the heart to tell the story. ms tonet jadaone you've won me over once again. balik nanaman ako sa good side mo po ms jadaone po. please don't stop making pinoy movies tnx po

loveee the solidarity of women in the film. especially jeannica's character (sunshine's sister) ğŸ˜”what stood out to me abt â€œSunshineâ€ is how it handles abortion without turning it into shock value or moral debate. the film treats it the way real life does, quietly, privately, and w a kind of heaviness that doesnâ€™t need big explanations. it shows how a situation like this doesnâ€™t happen in a vacuum; itâ€™s shaped by family, religion, money, expectations, fear, and the silence surrounding womenâ€™s choices, seeing how, in the film, women were denied healthcare even in life or death situations bc of the values and systems upheld in this country.motherhood demands so much, money, energy, time, and an immeasurable amount of emotional labor. once u step into it, there's no turning back. that's why becoming a mother should never be forced, it's not something anyone should bepushed into. it's not easy to be one.being a mother is a beautiful, yet deeply complex role. it should be intentional, it should be a choice.at the same time, every person brought into this world deserves to be born out of intention, love, and readiness. if someone doesn't want to become a mother, that's OKAY. it's only fair, both to her, and to the life she could've been expected to bring into the world.the movie doesnâ€™t try to justify anything or convince u what is right. instead, it shows the reality of how young people end up dealing w choices they were never prepared for. itâ€™s not dramatic, not preachy, just painfully honest. the long pauses, the still shots, the way conversations trail offâ€¦ it all reflects how hard it is to say something out loud when yk uâ€™ll be judged before uâ€™re understood.itâ€™s thoughtful, grounded, and uncomfortable in a necessary way. a reminder that behind every headline or opinion is someone trying to figure out how to move forward when every option hurts.

"Naiintindihan mo ba ako?""Gets ko na."See Greatest Filipino Films Of All TimeSee Jomâ€™s Greatest Films Of All TimeOnce in a while, movies like this will remind us how great Philippine Cinema could be with proper production and marketing.Let's be honest, there are many films like Sunshine out there, produced and marketed independently. The talent of our Filipino directors, writers, and actors is flourishing; it just needs the right hand managing them. Studios surrounding Sunshine took a huge gamble promoting and marketing this movie, because they know how good it is. And it's that fcking good!Sunshine beautifully captures Sunshine, our protagonist, as she battles her way out of an unwanted pregnancy set in the cold city of Manila. This journey was documented with captivating visuals of Sunshine in the gym, in Quiapo, in a motel, etc. On top of this, this is unlike any other dialogue in mainstream Pinoy. The dialogue often has witty layers, purposeful intentions, and emotional punches.Maris Racal delivered a career-defining performance. This is not the same Maris Racal we often see in teleseryes or some other romcom movie. Her performance is an incredible take on such a complex and relatable character.I could nitpick some off details here and there which really bugged me, but I won't talk about it here as I believe that further magnifying this movie's success is what we should do.Sunshine represents every woman, every female, every girl, every lady of any shape or form. It brings up socially relevant topics and issues worthy of discussion. I am most impressed by its bravery to speak all about these, coming from a conservative country. Sunshine, the protagonist, showed bravery in confronting the stigma and the conservative norms. Sunshine, the movie, showed the bravery of promoting and marketing this despite the stigma and the conservative norms.

Antoinette Jadaone's "Sunshine" is anchored by a stellar lead performance from Maris Racal and a neo-realist perspective on the lack of reproductive rights in the Philippines. The film follows a rhythmic gymnast who dreams of participating in the Olympics, only to find out that she is pregnant. The film explores the difficulties of finding the right medical care for abortion. Racal's performance is impressive, and she is solidly supported by Annika Co, Jennica Garcia, and Meryll Soriano. Jadaone is able to capture the dirt and grime of Manila's urban areas, as well as the outdated beliefs in the country.Reproductive rights for all!

â€œDrown out the noise. You are Sunshine.â€itâ€™s heartbreaking how many young women are going through this right now. abortion in the Philippines is not only illegal, but also so deeply stigmatized that many are forced to carry this burden alone, sometimes risking their own lives through unsafe procedures. the film portrays this reality with such quiet honesty that it sticks with you. the symbolism throughout was also so striking, like the â€œGift of Godâ€ sign in the jeepney Sunshine rode, or her so-called imaginary friend who could represent her unborn child or her inner child.it was honestly so satisfying watching her stand up for herself against miggy and his father, whoâ€™s a pastor. then of course, her breaking the bottle on tito bobotâ€™s head? deserved. every mf like him deserves that.the final sequence felt incredibly freeing as well. it was like she was finally free, almost like a release of everything she had been carrying â€” fear, shame, pressure, expectation. her imaginary friend disappearing can be interpreted that she did push through with the abortion (which parallels the 13 y/o kid and ariana), or as her finally finding peace with whatever choice she made. hopefully, this film gives conservatives some perspective on the immense weight placed on women in these situations, and theyâ€™ll finally be able to say, â€œGets ko na.â€ not everyone has the means to raise a child, especially when society is quick to judge. and even if you do have the means, you might simply not be ready because you might still have dreams you want to chase. itâ€™s really tough, and thatâ€™s why kindness matters so much.at the end of the day, we shouldnâ€™t be the ones deciding what women should do with their bodies. and yeah, practice safe sex!!

I hesitated to write a review that delves into the realities women in our country face, because Iâ€™m not the person who should be speaking for them.But SUNSHINE is a deeply powerful film.It wouldâ€™ve been easy for a story like this to sink into pure despair from beginning to end. Yet somehow, the film manages to confront its darkest truths while still carving out a sliver of hope. The performances are extraordinaryâ€”raw, fearless, and honestâ€”but they make the film difficult to watch in the best possible way. It exposes how our country refuses to grow, medicine needed for the operation coming from black markets, how it continues to force women into roles far smaller than what theyâ€™re capable of, and how it avoids addressing issues that desperately need to be talked about. Women deserve choice. They deserve agency. They deserve that right without question.This film places you in the shoes of a woman who believes her life has been shattered by one reckless decision made by someone she trustedâ€”and then shows, unflinchingly, how our society treats victims.Hopefully, the success of this film reignites the conversation around the importance of being pro-choice and pushes us toward building a better, more humane system.All we hope for is a little sunshine to finally break through.

hindi ko alam kung anong mas mabigat habang pinapanood ko Sunshine â€” yung katahimikan ng mga babaeng walang mapagsabihan, o yung ingay ng mundong ang bilis humusga pero ang bagal tumulong. Jadaone films always stab softly, pero ito? Parang dahan-dahang hinihiwa yung dibdib, layer by layer, para ipakita yung takot, pangarap, at kahihiyang matagal nang nakatago sa ilalim ng â€œok lang ako.â€this is the kind of film na hindi mo papanoorin para gumaan ang loob mo, papanoorin mo siya para maalala kung gaano kabigat mabuhay bilang babae sa bansang ayaw umamin na may mali sa sistemang sinasamba nito. Sunshine doesnâ€™t preach. it just stands there, raw and trembling, asking the kind of questions weâ€™re trained to avoid:Paano ka pipili kung lahat ng choice mo ay kasalanan sa mata ng iba?Paano ka lalaban kung mismong katawan mo ang pinaparusahan?Maris Racal is devastating in ways na hindi loud pero lumalalim. hindi siya yung tipikal na dramatic heroine â€” sheâ€™s simply a girl suspended between a dream and a reality that keeps shrinking her choices. her silence says more than any monologue could. every frame feels like a confession: hesitant, trembling, pero totoo.and what struck me most wasnâ€™t the gymnastics, or even the central issue of abortion. it was the ache between who we want to become and what our circumstances force us to be. nakakapagod maging babae sa Pilipinas â€” laging may moral lesson, laging monitored, laging may takot na isang maling galaw lang, tapos na ang lahat. parang ang liit liit ng mundo mo kahit ang laki laki ng pangarap mo.Sunshine doesnâ€™t romanticize any of this. walang sermon, walang cinematic gloss. just a raw, unfiltered look at how dreams bruise under a society na mas mabilis manghusga kaysa umintindi. the filmâ€™s imperfections â€” the loose ends, the uneven metaphors, the sometimes rushed stakes â€” oddly work in its favor. because real life isnâ€™t clean. hindi linear ang trauma. hindi laging malinaw ang choice. and maybe thatâ€™s the point: that weâ€™re all navigating a world built not on empathy, but on fear and control.in the end, Sunshine feels less like a movie and more like a mirror â€” one that forces you to sit with the darkness until you finally admit na masakit talaga ang liwanag. itâ€™s an eye-opener not because it shocks, but because it whispers truths weâ€™ve mastered the art of ignoring.a film worth watching, not because it entertains, but because it confronts. because it nudges you to look beyond the screen and into the world we builtâ€¦ and ask, Bakit ganito?And more importantly â€” hanggang kailan?

crazy movie to watch with your boyfriend for the first time (no regrets)- says a lot that i already knew the realities the movie was meant to expose because it's a very real possibility for me (and i've experienced some parts firsthand) (XD) (i am never going back to reddit that had me believing in some bs) (which is based on truth naman but still you could never fully trust these sites)- some aspects of teenage pregnancy and abortion might be new to some people because these things wouldn't concern them in the first place (men) (conservatives)- which is why the characters feel very planted. as in, their role is In Your Face (to name a few: the kids, piolo pascal*, miggy**, ate, her kid, unhelpful little brother that shares a room with her lol, whole tito boyet sideplot)- but i think the best thing this movie does is spark conversation, especially since it covers those unsaid aspects (e.g., the role of the church & ses, feelings of dread & anxiety when faced with the possibility of being pregnant, again: reddit, the actual pain & danger of an abortion) and makes it Palatable for d general ph audience!!!!!!!- again, since this is a taboo topic, people wouldn't want something too extreme and radical, so this movie is a good first step towards talking about it- still tho, the palatability made the ending so ass for me personally like. everything just started coming together a lil too smoothly for sunshine and honestly... for me ha...... One thing I like about Sunshine is its brazen risk to center the story on a 19-year old who's made consequentially irresponsible choices. It's a gambit that can easily be -- and, judging by discussions surrounding this movie, has already been -- misconstrued as a lesson on the importance of hammering down our society's puritanical views on sex and reproductive health to set teenage girls straight. That, somehow, Sunshine is a lesson in, as the elders say, "opening your legs for just about anybody"; that she did not listen to the adage is an absolute failing on her part, and its consequences fall rightfully on her shoulders. But here's the tricky bit: Sunshine could very well have been about a mother who could no longer give birth to another, and it would have still been met with the same logic-defying resistance that still places the blame squarely on the woman. Minor gripes include a finicky plot device that, at times, feels jarring and slightly questionable in terms of messaging. But it all feels egregious to say because the urgency of its existence really dwarfs over whatever minor flaws it may have. It also helps that Sunshine carried is so deftly by Maris Racal's and Jennica Garcia's career-defining performances, and a score by Rico Blanco that knows how to restrain and reintroduce itself in all the right moments.Sunshine cracks open a conversation on an obstinately immovable subject, and unflinchingly exposes the grim reality on how our women and girls move about our society, bearing the problems that we could easily find solutions to but which our religious guilt and intolerance constantly shame us into denying.

gets na gets na yung hype for Sunshine, naiyak akothis film really opened up a lot of heavy conversations regarding controversial topics that, up to this day, are still very hard to be tackled in our country where most minds are still enveloped by conservative ideologies that have been long influenced by religious policies.the message is straightforward and clear. it showed us the reality of women alike that had to endure the consequences of the patriarchal oppression and the dominance of Catholicism in the country, which is something that the rightists would undoubtedly refuse to accept because they'd still believe their presumed "norms" are what they think what's "best" for everyone and in the country â€” which is so out of touch from reality and it's very frustrating.however, i just had a bit of a problem with the film's inclusion of imaginary children; which i think somehow holds it back from letting the main message have its full weight. i get that they were used as some kind of a metaphor or a device for the plot, but something with it troubles me for reasons i can't quite best explain yet.but all in all, i really commend the bold attempts they did for this film. still a solid gem for Philippine contemporary cinema that's deserving to be watched by so many

And even if we try to drown out the noise, this film refuses to stay quiet. It hits too hard. It shows the very realities women go through in todayâ€™s world.What makes it even bolder is its willingness to be raw, relevant, and unapologetically confrontational in a country where abortion remains illegal. It doesnâ€™t tiptoe. It doesnâ€™t soften its edges. Instead, it stares straight into the contradictions of a culture that claims to protect life while silencing the ones who live it.

Execution is realistic tho. I believe most of us relates in jeepney scene when youâ€™re in the verge of breaking down and you donâ€™t know what to do but to breathe slowly and comfort yourself, hoping no one would notice. Love the irony, the symbolism, and the heats.But then again, they be trying to highlight everything all at once but failed to deliver why weâ€™re here in the first place. It was moving, as a woman. BUT AS A WOMAN I was hoping for a more impactful message since it opened a lot of discourse. Women are far more complex and I was looking for chaos in what a woman feels in a society where everyone are so entitled to decide on how a woman should act and carry themselves. In spite of her past controversies, Maris Racal's performance in this film is the very reason why she remains in the spotlight. Her acting as Sunshine is spectacular. The story requires someone who is capable of letting the viewers feel the heaviness of her pain, the agony, and the hope of standing up for yourself and for what you want, and she made us feel all of that. And though I may not completely agree with everything that's pointed out here, I really admire Jadaone's attempt and bravery at addressing such a taboo topic, not just in the Philippines but the rest of the world. Being prayerful and always going to church do not give us the right to see ourselves as being more morally upright than others. When you put all of that aside, Sunshine is just a teenager who regretfully made a mistake and who made a decision for herself, stood up for what she wanted, and spared the child from the resentment of a mom from being robbed of her own dreams, and of leading her to what could possibly be a miserable life.She knows she could be ridiculed for that decision, but she lived according to her own terms anyway. And we know that in the end, she is happy, and that's all that matters.

Kudos to Direk Tonet, Maris Racal, and the whole team responsible for creating this film, thank you for being brave and casting a light on our nationâ€™s issues often overlooked in fear of the cultural taboo it carries. I would have rated it 5 stars, but the choice to represent Sunshineâ€™s internal conflict with herself through a hallucinated child character doesnâ€™t sit right with me. Jadaoneâ€™s direction results in jarring tonal shifts that muddle the filmâ€™s emotional center. What was perhaps intended as a bold attempt at cinematic expression to illustrate inner turmoil instead dilutes the stakes, softening the thorniness of the subject matter with a cartoonish detour. Itâ€™s an interesting idea but one that never quite coheres with the rest of the filmâ€™s pro-choice sensibility. In fact, by personifying an unborn child as a character which speaks and thinks, then Sunshine unintentionally reinforces the very moral framing that anti-abortion rhetoric thrives on. It circles back into the age-old â€œwhen does life begin?â€ debateâ€”a question that continues to paralyze policymaking in the country, even when the conversation should be about autonomy, access, and proper healthcare. The film doesnâ€™t just inherit this moral hang-up; it stages it, frames it, and in doing so, muddies the clarity of its own politics. Though, I will still give my flowers to this movie. It helped brought upon a conversation in our country long overdue and for that I am grateful. I hope it inspires other filmmakers to be bold in the face of a country that chooses to be blind to issues that continue to grow with no solutions in sight.

Maganda ang Sunshine, napakita ang pagiging taboo ng abortion, teen pregnancy, at kung gaano kakonti ang kontrol ng babae sa sarili nilang katawan sa Pilipinas.Sobrang totoo ng pag-arte ni Maris Racal, kaya ramdam mo lahat ng pinagdadaanan ni Sunshine. Medyo bitin lang sa pagpapakita kung gaano siya kagaling bilang atleta, at may ilang plot, lalo na yung parallel story ng isang buntis na biktima ng pang-aabuso, na kahit malakas, medyo rushed at overwhelming.Pero kahit ganun, malakas pa rin ang dating ng pelikula sa social issues at sa pagpapakita ng totoong buhay sa Maynila.

What will you do if your dream is at stake because of one mistake?Sunshine delivers a powerful message about reproductive rights and the need for access to safe and legal abortion.The film shows the current state of healthcare in the Philippines and how this basic necessity has become inaccessible, especially to those living below the poverty line.I like how the film does not romanticize the societal issue of unwanted pregnancy. Instead, it highlights how stigma deeply affects womenâ€™s decision-making about their own bodies. It shows how the main character struggles with an internal conflict and debates with her own conscience.While the film clearly presents why abortion should be legalized and recognized as part of healthcare in the Philippines, it also portrays how religion and health often clash. It is true that our country is still in the process of accepting that abortion is a right that should be available to all women.Some might argue that safe sex is the only way to avoid these situations, but we cannot ignore the fact that many women experience sexual abuse, rape, or non-consensual ejaculation during intercourse.Sunshine is not just a film that explains why safe abortion should be legalized; it calls our attention to consider the issue without guilt-tripping women through religion or societal pressure.Women should have the freedom to decide what to do with their own bodies. Marriage or co-parenting should not be treated as a band-aid solution to a lifelong responsibility. These solutions do not apply to everyone, especially to those who do not have the means to support a child.I know we all have different perspectives on this issue, but thinking long-term about the future of our children depends on how ready we truly are to take on this responsibility.

Two can tango, but only one makes it out of the dancefloor.The hard truth of women and children being the ones to bear the consequences. May this film be an eye opener. The underlying issues on mental health, socioeconomic burden, and lack of education are directly implied in this film. To bravely put it out on Philippine media is a start of a more aware perspective. The cinematography and script are well combined and well thought of. The metaphors hit the spot and Maris' performance not only represented a lot of young girls out there, but also those who are mentally struggling. Seeing someone doing everything alone and bear the burden of something that isn't normative is heartbreaking. Children must not be guilt tripped into doing things just to survive. Proper education and guidance is what we always hope and pray for. May this film pave the way to a more open and safe space for all that are struggling.

if there is light, kahit konting-konti lang, we chase itâ€”because sometimes thatâ€™s the only thing left for women to hold.sunshine (2025) is the kind of film na hindi ka pinapa-wow sa effects or spectacle. instead, it sits beside you quietly, like a friend na alam lahat ng pagod mo kahit hindi mo sinabi. itâ€™s woman-centered in the most unsettling, honest wayâ€”walang sugarcoating, walang mythologizing, just the raw truth of being a girl in a country that asks you to endure more than it ever protects.the film strips away the usual softness associated with its title. sunshine isnâ€™t light; sheâ€™s a girl trying to survive a world that keeps dimming her. and when the story touches the issue of abortion not being legalized in the Philippines, it doesnâ€™t sensationalize itâ€”pinapakita lang niya â€˜yung totoo: na in this country, women are expected to carry consequences alone. that reproductive rights become moral battles instead of health and safety; na the system treats our pain like an inconvenience, our choices like crimes.â€˜yung internal struggle ni Sunshineâ€”â€˜yung fear, guilt, confusion, desperationâ€”hindi dahil â€œmahina siya,â€ but because society makes women feel cornered by circumstances we never chose. and the film doesnâ€™t villainize her for thinking about her future; it villainizes the world that forces her to justify wanting one.and then thereâ€™s Miggy.Miggy isâ€¦ familiar. not evil, not abusive, just painfully typical. he represents the kind of boyfriend most girls in the philippines know too wellâ€”the one who â€œcares,â€ but only until it requires accountability. the boy who says â€œIâ€™m here for youâ€ pero umiilag sa big conversations. the boy who loves you but doesnâ€™t understand the weight you carry because heâ€™s never had to carry anything like it.Miggy is the embodiment of how boys in this country are raised: may freedom without consequence, may opinion without knowledge, may presence without responsibility. his reactions, his avoidance, even his attempts to comfortâ€”they feel real because theyâ€™re exactly what so many girls have lived through. boys who think support is just saying â€œkaya natin â€™toâ€ while leaving the actual pain to us.sunshine 2025 becomes a commentary on how women are taught to be accountable for everythingâ€”including mistakes that werenâ€™t only theirsâ€”while men are taught to be forgiven for everything. the movie doesnâ€™t hate Miggy; it exposes him. it shows the casualness of male privilege, the way it slips into daily life unnoticed but heavyâ€”always heavyâ€”on our side.and thatâ€™s what makes the film hit: itâ€™s not loud, not preachy, not dramatic. it just shows the truthâ€”and the truth is already loud enough.sunshine isnâ€™t a story about brightness; itâ€™s a story about women trying to navigate a world that refuses to make space for their choices, their fears, their bodies, their futures. itâ€™s a film that says:the pain wasnâ€™t yours alone, but somehow, you were the only one expected to carry it.and long after the credits, youâ€™re left with that hurtâ€”the kind that reminds you why we keep fighting for a world where women donâ€™t have to beg for the right to their own lives.

okayâ€¦ where do i startâ€¦sunshine hit me like a quiet knock on a locked room, the kind you pretend not to hear because youâ€™re afraid of whatâ€™s waiting behind it. as someone who also had to make a decision that didnâ€™t just redirect my future but rearranged the entirety of my life, this film didnâ€™t simply â€œresonate.â€ it reopened drawers i thought Iâ€™d sealed.this movie moves with a kind of fragile honesty. it sifts through grief, guilt, conscience, and that stubborn ember of self-worth that refuses to die even when the world tells you it should. and for onceâ€¦ finallyâ€¦ i felt seen. really seen. thereâ€™s a rare tenderness here toward the kind of vulnerability young women carry when theyâ€™re forced into crossroads far too big for their age, their support systems, or the people who claim to know whatâ€™s best for them.what sunshine captures so precisely is the suffocating tension between choice and consequence, not in a moralizing, finger-wagging way, but in a deeply human way. the doctorâ€™s coldness, the judgment tucked inside every question, every lookâ€¦ it reflects the reality that abortion is still treated as a shameful confession rather than a complicated, personal, and painful decision. yes, society frames it as a â€œcrime against morality,â€ but the film quietly asks: whose morality, exactly? and why are women always the ones made to bleed for it?watching sunshine felt like someone finally holding space for a story thatâ€™s usually whispered or erased. itâ€™s tender, confrontational, and painfully relevant, a film that doesnâ€™t try to save you, but sits beside you while you try to save yourself. fuck it, maris, sobrang galing mo! thank you for bringing sunshine to life.

I donâ€™t usually leave reviews, but Sunshine stood out to me as such a critically significant piece in filipino cinema especially in a culture rooted in colonialism and christianity. I love how manila is depicted in its rawest form. Maingay, magulo, heck you could even smell it from the screen. It does not romanticize the city nor flatten it into a mere backdrop. The theme of Sunshine is something we rarely see portrayed in filipino cinema. It doesnâ€™t try to force itself into the usual â€œblockbusterâ€ formula, instead, it exists to open eyes and start conversations. Having a renowned actress like Maris Racal gives the film a real chance to break through and reach the wider audience it deserves.Now let me make a completely different and specific take. We often argue for the legalization of abortion for these reasons: cases of rape or coercion, inaccessibility of contraceptives, the lack of proper sex education, and the health risk that comes with women resorting to unsafe means of abortion. All of these are very very real, but we often oversee a simple fact â€”that many women are just NOT READY TO BE MOTHERS. Which is why the confrontation between Sunshine and Pastor Jaime struck with me. Simply because sexual desire is natural. Hormones, curiosity, and intimacy are physiologically innate within us. Yet discussions of sexuality are shrouded in taboo. Sex is framed as sacred, premarital sex as sinful, and expression of desire as something to be suppressed. Telling young women â€œkung â€™di pa kasi ready, â€™wag nalang makipag-sexâ€ ignores the realities â€” not only of the youth but women in general â€” and places a burden of purity and morality solely on girls while the system fails to provide us the education, resources, and safe spaces needed to navigate this issue responsibly and safely. Regardless of reason, no woman should be deprived of rights over her own body. A right thatâ€™s still treated like a debate in a country where â€œgodlinessâ€ is apparently put above the reproductive autonomy and wellbeing of women.

This is good, it highlights struggles of having a dream and being in that journey where you are so close to getting what you want then problems arise. This movie featured how she stayed strong despite what she was going through, believing in yourself and staying committed to the grind for your dream. They also showed different kinds of scenarios we would normally tend to overlook when we hear about teenage pregnancy like having no options because abortion is illegal in the country. Things like selling unsafe substances for abortion, sexual abuse that happens in the household, the health risks for the body being pregnant at an early age, not having access to healthcare and even overcrowded maternity ward in public hospitals. This movie shows us the struggles that many teenage moms go/went through, give it a watch and you will love the how the story goes.
I weep for the women in the Philippines and anywhere where the right to choose is not an option. Abortion should be legal, accessible, affordable, and safe.

Source: www.reeladvice.net/2025/12/sunshine-2024-movie-review.htmlAntoinette Jadaoneâ€™s Sunshine has been one of our most anticipated local releases of the year and it does not disappoint. Emotionally charged and socially resonant, the film tackles teen pregnancy and the realities of limited reproductive rights in the Philippines with honesty and empathy. While it may not offer clear-cut moral answers, Sunshine succeeds in revealing the real and painful stakes of becoming a young mother tackling equally both sides of the moral coin.National gymnast Sunshine (Maris Racal) has always dreamed of competing in the Olympics. With qualifiers fast approaching, she pushes her body to its limits until she suddenly faints during training. What she assumes is exhaustion from her intense regimen and strict diet turns out to be something far more life-altering: she is pregnant. At only 19 and with her lifelong dream on the line, Sunshine faces a bitter decision: keep the child and lose her final chance at the Olympics, or pursue an illegal abortion and grapple with the moral and emotional fallout.As expected, Sunshine doesnâ€™t shy away from tough conversations. Its central dilemma is painfully relatable, regardless of where you stand on the right to choose in a predominantly Catholic country. Maris Racal is a revelation, delivering a nuanced and deeply human performance as a young athlete forced to confront consequences that will shape the rest of her life. And while we wonâ€™t spoil where the story ultimately lands, the film takes a definitive stance without betraying the complexity of its subject matter. It was a balancing act handled with notable care.What elevates Sunshine further is how vividly it captures the societal pressures and chaotic realities of Philippine society when it comes to the right to choose. The judgment, the ironies, the lack of support systems, everything feels painfully authentic and grounded. Where the film stumbles slightly is in its more fantastical elements. Though the intent behind these sequences is clear, they often feel out of place and not fully integrated into the narrative, appearing more convenient than cohesive. Still, Sunshine is a compelling and important watch and not only for Maris Racalâ€™s standout performance but for its bold and compassionate exploration of an issue that remains deeply relevant in modern Philippine society. Itâ€™s a film that provokes and ultimately shines.

Teen pregnancy and the topic of abortion have long been an issue in the Philippines. This movie shows exactly the mindsets of Filipinos towards those two subjects, both are extremely negative. Teen pregnancy or minors getting pregnant in general are often looked down upon in Filipino societyâ€” often times there arenâ€™t even facilities that help teen parents process what theyâ€™re going through properly. Furthermore, a lot of people tend to shame these children for bringing more children into the world without even knowing the full story, leading to these children feeling afraid to open up about what happened to them â€” thus making them use extreme methods in order to rid of the pregnancy due to the fact that abortion is illegal in the country, as well as to avoid the shame that comes with people knowing about their pregnancy.

sunshine, gets kita.bilang isang pro-choice at pro-abortion naninindigan ako para sa karapatang pumili. isa ito sa masalimuot na realidad ng mga kababaihan, at ipinipilit na ang pagpili ay hindi dapat pinagkakaitâ€”ito'y isang likas na karapatan.hindi ito nagsisigaw, ngunit malakas ang dating ng pelikulang ito. hindi ito nagtuturo, ngunit nagbubukas ng mata. isa itong salaminâ€”at sa bawat repleksyon, nakikita natin ang realidad kung gaano kasakim ang gobyerno, gaano kagulo, gaano karumi, kaingay ang pilipinas at higit sa lahat repleksyon ito kung gaano ka mapanghusga ang bansang ito. may mga taong ginagawang batas ang moralidad habang binabalewala ang dignidad; mga matang mapanuri, mapanghusga at sabik sa pagkakamali. madaling hatulan ng lipunan, dahil sa mundong ito, laging kasalanan ng babae ang maging tao. ang maging marupok. ang maging matatag. ang pumili para sa sarili. the audacity na hatulan ang mga babae nang mga hindi makatarungang husgaâ€”lalo na kapag maaga silang nabuntis. nakakagalit panoorin kung paanong sila'y tinitingnan na para kahihiyan, na para bang mas masahol pa sila sa isang nakakahawang sakit, habang ang mga lalake naman ay patuloy na nagpapakasasa sa buhay, ligtas sa parehong batikos at bigat ng responsibilidad.at kung ako ang tatanungin, sasabihin ko ito ng buong puso: kampi ako sa bawat babaeng may karapatang magdesisyon para sa sariling katawanâ€”malaya, marangal, at walang sinumang pumipigil.

Isang ngiti naman d'yan Sunshine!

Every â€œbadâ€ decision Sunshine makes, I support her.Against the backdrop of the Philippinesâ€™ conservatism, Sunshine makes decisions for herself and what is best FOR HER. And I applaud Antoinette Jadaone for making these choices.Sunshine should not have made those â€œbadâ€ choices because the system should have it there in the first place. Filipino women should have access to safe abortion services and we should have accessible reproductive healthcare. Thought-provoking. Intense. Honest. Yet still tender. The addition of the kid sometimes takes me out of the immersion but in the end it makes sense.But as a Manila girlie, the scenes where Sunshine is walking around Quiapo and especially when she is driven to the hospitalâ€¦ I canâ€™t help but scream â€œWhy are they driving her too far?!â€Anyway, Maris is a revelation. Excited for her next roles. But the scene stealer is really Jennica Garcia, sheâ€™s in just a few scenes but all of her scenes are fucking amazing.

Gets mo ba? Gets ko na. Long vent incomingâ€¦This film bro I have never felt something that raw and real and to think that this is what many women even young girls go through and the fact that itâ€™s here in the Philippines is just so hard since everyone here is so deeply rooted in religion and shaming those who want to prioritize themselves and not to be held down by this fucking expectation na â€œmagkaka-anak ka din balang arawâ€ Even at my young age I dreaded the thought that Iâ€™d have to bear a kid and raise it someday because my family says so- everyone says so. But then again, why should I tie myself down with that expectation? Why canâ€™t I decide for myself if I do want to have a kid or if I donâ€™t in the future?Even up until now iniisip ko talaga na ayoko magka anak bc IN THIS ECONOMY?? IN THIS FUCKED UP WORLD??And itâ€™s also not even that, I have so many trauma and issues its crazy ğŸ˜­ I think Iâ€™m definitely not in the right state of mind/mental health space to even see myself having kids in the future, and the thought of just repeating the cycle of trauma on my own kid in the future? Thatâ€™s something I want to spare them from.This movie just HITS that spot. And you know what? Not wanting to have kids or being unsure of it, itâ€™s okay. Because at the end of the day itâ€™s your body, your choice. Itâ€™s okay to pursue your dreams and prioritize yourself. I know it might not mean much since hello asa pinas tayo ?? We need more people to be woke/educated and for people to see that not all women can afford to have a kid and some are forced to because of unfortunate circumstances and that scene with doktora in the public hospital and yung tito? KALOKA RAGE BAIT TALAGA but it hurts knowing that actually happens and the other choice youâ€™ll have is dangerous drugs and operations that could very well kill you instead of being able to have a form of healthcare for women that could be much more safer and free from judgementâ€¦ youâ€™d just want to hope that in these changing times na baka sakali na maintindihan din nila katulad tong pinagdaanan ni Sunshine and many, many more other women, even young girls. And the presence of the kids as mere hallucinations and the personification of their What Ifâ€™s for the kids, I have those thoughts as well but then again, like they say, I rather regret not having a kid than regret having them. Ayoko maging ina, and whatever they say, your reasons and whatever your decision may be is VALID!!

I love that there's a physical representation of their kid in the womb. It's not literal, she's not ill in the head, it's a part of the story the movie wants to show.Most mothers from the previous previous generations have the similar story of giving up their dreams because they got pregnant and started a family at a young age. So Sunshine's story kind of counters that, which is really cool.It's very interesting that it's about a strong topic... abortion by young adults in the Philippines. I mention the country because I've watched other movies about abortion in the U.S., and it's nowhere near as sad as this. (i.e: Unpregnant (2020)).I personally know someone, although not an athlete, but went through this exact thing and upon seeing this, I feel more deeply for her.I hate men who don't use their brains, and do not care enough to wear protection. And I hate that women have to only either keep it against their will, or settle for this dangerous and illegal way to fix their problem. This is why it's really only up to us women to be definitely wise about our bodies. Be smart. Don't rely or entrust yourselves on these good-for-nothing men.Yeah sorry, this movie affected me. It's not perfect, but I liked it.P.S. that scene when sunshine finds out who the uncle was and hit his head with a bottle was absolute cinema. he deserved that.

The film shows that abortion isnâ€™t always the â€œbadâ€ thing people make it out to be. For some women, itâ€™s a necessary option especially when theyâ€™re not ready emotionally, physically, or financially to raise a child. But as much as possible, itâ€™s important to avoid sexual activity at a very young age or when youâ€™re not prepared, because every decision you make will affect the child. I also believe abortion should be legal, because in many situations, carrying a pregnancy to term can be unsafe. We need to stay open-minded and understand that not everyone has the same circumstances.The movie also highlights how close-minded some people can be, and how our local hospitals especially public ones still struggle with safety, hygiene, and proper care. Healthcare should be accessible and free, especially for those who canâ€™t afford it. Decision natin toh pls choose the right thing. Always. Stay safe.

WOW!!!shet wtf ang ganda!!! teka waittt will edit this para sa review buzy langEDIT: ( so heto na nga mga bading)HI, SUNSHINE!It took me days to figure out how I would write my review for Sunshine. It wasnâ€™t just because I was busy (gosh, I hate having an actual life), but also because I needed time to take this film in. Like Iâ€™ve said, IT WAS SO BEAUTIFUL. I really had to think everything through just to articulate exactly how this film made me feel. And once again, Iâ€™m haunted by the regret of not watching another absolute banger in theaters when it was released. Iâ€™m so sorry, Direk Tonet!! Sunshine deserves to be seen on the big screen, and Iâ€™m forever broken by the fact that I didnâ€™t get to experience it there!!!!But enough of that already, let me finally get on with my actual review.First, I want to say na bilib ako sa tapang ng pelikulang ito, and the same sentiments go to everyone behind Sunshine. To talk about abortion in a country where itâ€™s considered tabooâ€”a very conservative, religious, and deeply judgmental society like oursâ€”is already a risk in itself. Yet this film went there. And that was so, so brave, exactly the kind of bravery people in todayâ€™s generation need to see. Same with my co-letterboxd reviewers heree. You guys are awesome for talking about it! It genuinely gladdens me to see that most of the reviews here are filled with positivity and enlightenment. I love that so many viewers agree that what Sunshine did was not only necessary, but the right thing to do. A lot of us now are far more open and accepting, and many finally understand that abortion goes deeper than the knee-jerk â€˜masama yanâ€™ mindset many were raised with. You guys rock!Now, the film from beginning to end wasâ€”WOW. Grabe! Honestly, it was so beautiful, pero hindi ko pa rin maiwasang kabahan. I still had my fingers crossed because I really thought she might change her mind at the last minute and decide to keep Bata. I was scared that the film would shift from something liberating to something trapped once again in the usual Filipino cultural expectations. But thank goodness I was proven wrong. Also, Iâ€™ll admit, I was confused at first kung sino ba si Bata. Akala ko siya si Sunshine as a kid. Mas naging malinaw lang talaga sa akin kung sino siya noong dumating na si Ariana. But, mamaya na natin siya pag-usapan.This film is a powerful example of why legalizing abortion in the Philippines is important. With Sunshineâ€™s story, being just two months away from finally reaching her big dreamsâ€”only for everything to be jeopardized by an unwanted pregnancyâ€”is such a heavy and heartbreaking burden. And yes, her reason for not wanting to keep the pregnancy and become a mother is completely valid. Iâ€™m genuinely happy that she stood by her decision. Her dream is the Olympics, not becoming a young motherâ€”and choosing herself was the right thing to do. Yes, she made a mistake by engaging in sexual activity at a young age without protection, but this is exactly where proper sex education should come in. If only our education system focused on teaching children about the things that actually matterâ€”their bodies, consent, responsibility, and safe sexâ€”situations like Sunshineâ€™s wouldnâ€™t be treated as moral failures, but as preventable circumstances. If we taught young people the truth instead of scaring them with shame, we wouldnâ€™t have to watch teenagers face life-altering consequences they were never prepared for. Maybe thenâ€”if sex education were implemented properlyâ€”the chances of needing abortion might be lower (but never zero), and could potentially be prevented if itâ€™s really that strongly considered sinful or unwelcome in this country, ONLY IF we also truly advocate for and implement proper sex education. But again, as a woman, not wanting to legalize abortion for any reason is beyond unacceptable. Legalizing it isnâ€™t an invitation for anyone to engage in sexual activity recklessly, or to encourage others to go do it themselves, or whatever else people think. It isnâ€™t about themâ€”it is about a woman, a person, who needs hope, a chance, and a life that isnâ€™t trapped in a cruel world where she feels neglected.(Shet, ang dami ko pang gustong sabihin! I hope anyone actually reading this can hang in there, I really tend to go on endlessly when I find something this interesting. At nag-explain pa talaga yan sha.)Now, going back to Arianaâ€”â€™yung dahilan kung bakit siya nabuo is sobrang nakakapanghina. Menggay is only 13 years old. At that age, she should only be worrying about herself, not carrying a child. My heart completely dropped when I heard her age. Her body is only starting puberty, and to make things worse, it was all because of her own uncle. Tangina mo, Bobot! Whether Sunshine will literally hit him in the head with that bottle of Red Horse (?) or not, Iâ€™m passing the message telepathically to Sunshine na basagin yung bote sa ulo ng hayop na â€˜yon. Kulang pa nga yung inabot niyang iyon sa kahayupan niya. tangina siya, tarantado!LAHAT NG MANYAKIS AT MAPANSAMANTALANG TAO, SANA HINDI KAYO MAMATAY PARA MARANASAN NIYO LAHAT NG HIRAP SA MUNDO, TANGINA JIYO.Now tell me, kung bakit hindi pa rin dapat i-legalize ang abortion sa Pilipinas? Ang story ni Sunshine at Menggay ay iilan lamang sa napakaraming rason kung bakit kailangan ng abortion sa Pilipinas. At ito pa, andito na naman sa pinakaayoko, ang ipapasa-diyos ang nangyari, na parang literal na siya ang bahala sa lahat. At kailangan pa talagang humingi ng sorry sa kaniya? Bakit? Para saan? Kapag tinuloy ba nila, si God ba ang mag-aalaga? Siya ba ang maghihirap for the rest of their lives? Siya ba ang gagastos? Alam niyo na ang sagot. Kaya sobrang bullshit to force Sunshine na magsorry kay papa God dahil sa ginawa niya. Also, just look at what actually happens to women in this country na nagpaâ€‘paabort. Halos ikamatay na nila dahil hindi safe. And honestly, itâ€™s so funny pa to think na sa tabi pa talaga ng simbahan makakahanap ng pampalaglag, diba? At kung ayaw talaga ng Diyos doon, edi sana, ayon sa logic nila, matagal nang nasunog â€˜yung mga nagtitinda. Since ayun naman lagi nilang sinasabi, masusunog kapag masama (kaya siguro ang hot q).Now, with Racalâ€™s performance naman. Baks, wala na akong masabi. Ang husay niya! I saw her video post talking about what she did with her script, and she said that after Sunshine found out she was pregnant, she went on autopilot with one goal, to get rid of the baby. And you can clearly see it in her character, present but determined. Galing! Wow k jan!!!Aaaaahhhh, ang dami-dami ko pa talagang gustong sabihin, but Iâ€™m pretty sure it would take me a month or so pa to finish. Basta, the bottom line isâ€”Sunshine isnâ€™t just a good movie. It transcends the typical. It breaks boundaries in storytelling, performance, and, most importantly, in social impact. This film makes you think, feel, and confront realities many would rather ignore. Sobrang Pinoy rin ng vibes niya. Have I forgotten to mention how ganda the cinematography is? Legit, walang tapon sa pelikula na ito. Sunshine is not only a breakthrough in Filipino cinema, itâ€™s a bold statement for our society, showing that films can challenge norms, spark conversation, and leave a mark. At sana nga, sa lahat ng nakapanood ng Sunshine, nagets niyo rin ang punto.A round of applause, a standing ovation, and full-blown respect to Director Antonette Jadaoneâ€™s Sunshine (SOBRANG OA)â€”from me and all my countless personalities.

Kung ang OPM may Skusta Clee, si Maris naman sa Ph Film. This movie tackles several pressing issues in the Philippines. While abortion serves as its central theme, it also delves into related concerns such as misogyny, the healthcare system, and bodily autonomy. With its strong cinematography, blunt yet well-written script, and solid sequencing and storytelling, Sunshine stands out as anything but a typical Filipino film.Maris delivered a performance that truly did justice to the role, and itâ€™s important to separate the art from the artist. The film has its own story to tell, independent of the personal character of the actress portraying the lead.I believe the storytelling could have been strengthened by presenting the sports aspect more clearly, rather than relying heavily on context clues. A more detailed depiction of the sport, and how it reflects the ongoing challenges faced by Filipino athletes, would have added even greater depth to the narrative.

I, for one, found myself questioning my values. Tanginaaaaaa, sobrang mararamdaman mo yung pagkatao ng film. Na hindi ka lang audience ng pelikula kundi kasama ka rin dahil mamamayan ka. Mamamayan kang nabubuhay sa ganitong sistema at responsibilidad mong isipin ang reyalidad ng marami pang Sunshine sa Pilipinas.Sa tingin ko kasi hindi mali si Sunshine, pero hindi rin siya tama. Kung right and wrong lang ang pag-uusapan, madaling husgahan ang karakter niya. Pero hindi. Maraming aspeto ang nagpapakumplikado ng lahat. Hindi iisa, hindi dadalawa. Hindi lang itim at puti, kundi makulay talaga. Wala ngang tama at mali; ang meron lang e kung anong direksyon ang tatahakin niya kasi either way, mababagabag si Sunshine. Kahit anong maging desisyon niya, talo pa rin siya. Noong eksena ngang naospital siya sa unang attempt niya, I was hoping that she succeeded. It was so heartbreaking kasi to see a young woman go through that painful process without anyone caring for her. With all the thoughts in her head and the pain in her body, itâ€™s mind damning. Mamumulat ka talaga. Maaawa ka. She has a bright future ahead of her pero tao lang din siya. Bata. Walang magulang. Mahirap. Walang kwenta pa naging shota. Pero malaki ang pangarap.Basta ang hirap iexplain. Hahahaha! Marami kasing sides talaga. Ibaâ€™t iba ang naratibo. (Hindi ko na lang muna bubuksan yung sa kwento ni Red dahil ibang usapan yung sa kanya. Dapat sa mga nang aabuso talaga kasi â˜ ï¸âš°ï¸. At Iâ€™m all for the victims erasing the product of evilness inside their bodies.) Isipin na lang siguro ng mga sensitibo pa rin sa talakaying ito kung gaano kabigat para sa mga taong pinipiling i let go ang mga baby nila kasi gets naman nilang hindi rin nila kayang magpakamagulang sa mundong magulo. Hindi na para dagdagan ang linya ng henerasyong may trauma. Enough na parusa na ang konsensya, hindi na para parusahan din ang magiging bunga. Wala kasing halaga talaga ang makakabili sa pangarap o sa kagustuhang maging ina. Ayun.KUDOS TO MARIS! SOBRANG GALING! SOBRANG RAW! SOBRANG SUNSHINE!!! Siguro may mga parts lang ng film na kaya pang iimprove PERO THE MESSAGE, THE INTENT, WHAT THE FILM TACKLES 10/10!!! KUKWESTYUNIN KA TALAGA!!! TATARAKAN KA NG MGA TANONG AT BUBUKSAN ANG ISIP MO SA MAS MALAWAK PANG DIMENSYON!!!

I was attending Jakarta Film Week and was queueing for Crocodile Tears, tickets sold out and I had to pivot to Sunshine. Going in blind adds another wow factor to this film. I was expecting something moving, empowering and uplifting, like a zero-to-hero movie, defying odds but what I get was pretty dark and bittersweet I suppose. Sunshine is a big surprise that it is very dark, devastating, heartbreaking but also extremely funny and comical. But it is very serious. It is very relevant to the current climate, where women in many countries are not facilitated enough, not enough healthcare for women and young women in general going through the same situation, abortion, and laws that strip away womenâ€™s rights and choices. This Philipphine drama really hits close to home as our fellow South-east asia country, that sometimes religion takes precedence over everything. Hiding behind religions and God, condemning others about their decisions, shaming others. Sunshine is very raw and blunt when talking about these issues. Sunshine should be a clear message to many countries how systemic failure causes damage to young women who is going through similar issue. Society fails to provide enough help and accessible healthcare, but also support from society. As we can see, there are only women involved in showing care and compassion throughout them movie. The only man, the pastor, even minimizes and belittles Sunshineâ€™s choice to keep the baby. Sunshine is incredible, but its a hard watch.

Jakarta Film Week 2025The existence of this film is simply a miracle. I went into this with only very vague knowledge on what it's about (although I do know that the abortion part does not come with a long-distance travel), and the turn in the last third is wholly unexpected. It's both comforting and harrowing, it speaks to the problems right-on while presenting that yes, there is a future where we will be able to choose.To be able to choose is to shine the light of sunshine. Sunshine and her sisters faces their burdens at night, where every choice they make will affect their tomorrows. But in reality, women are still unable to live with the freedom to decide for their future. If they can't choose to not carry life, then what about their future life?Why is it men who has to be the authority of life? To carry life is a burden that risks the life of people who has the ability to that. Why can't they choose to not carry the burden? Why should their lives be ruined for not wanting to bear the burden?This should be shown to teenagers, it's a shame that this gets slapped with 16+ everywhere (although the number of "fuck!" being spoken might be to blame). Ang daming kalaban ni Sunshine. â€˜Yung sarili niya, si Miggy ang bumuntis sa kanya, Thea ang best friend niya, si Doktora, Coach, Kultura, moral, paniniwala, at higit sa lahatâ€“ang sarili niya, the little Sunshine in her. That fight she took on was for the little girl who dreamt bigger than Manila could ever be. A dream so big and gripped so close to the heart, that it brought her to the stage she shone the brightest in. In the Filipino culture, where an already embedded Catholic belief system among Filipinos insists itself as a dominant value. Religion is the lawâ€“both moral and written. The system, therefore, finds itself an enemy to Sunshine. When your whole body rejects a value youâ€™ve held onto as a child, you will take the pain of leaving your morals behind and choosing the path that feels right. â€˜Yung labag sa loob mo, pero, kailangan moâ€“kailangan mong piliin ang sarili mo. In the laws of Religion, masamang bagay ang ginawa ni Sunshine. Disgraced by the OB-GYNE doctor from her abortion attempt, invaded by the Pastor and child to make negotiations for reputation's sake, and the stigma her fellow students held onto her for being pregnant. Hindi ito sakit. However, what stood out to me was hypocrisy. The Ate from which Sunshine brought her pills from in Quiapo reaps the benefits of both Catholic figures and abortion pills. The opposing beliefs and the lack of a moral standpoint are, in themselves, a belief. The birth of different belief systems creates a divide in the basis of faith. As for the Ate, she manages to capitalize on the ideas of both, prioritizing the capitalistic wealth over the spiritual one.

Raw, urgent, devastating. Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s Sunshine follows a teen gymnast whose unplanned pregnancy threatens not just her dream, but her sense of safety. The film makes it clear: laws and conservative norms that say they protect often do the opposite, forcing women into danger and silence.Yet, Sunshine also shows the deep solidarity between womenâ€”holding each other up when everything else fails. Their strength is real, but it shouldnâ€™t be an excuse for a broken system. Valorizing resilience without demanding accountability lets those in power off the hook.Quiapo wasnâ€™t just a scenery. Itâ€™s a lived map of the problem. Crowded streets, devotional stalls, and informal markets where abortifacients appear next to religious items, showing how faith, commerce, and survival collide to leave women with few safe options. More than anything, Sunshine challenges us to face the stories weâ€™d rather not see. Those stories that are real, painful, and demand difficult conversations.ğŸ“ABC Hall, Osaka, Japan â€¢ OAFF 2025 Expo

âœ¨ON THE PSYCHE OF A TEENAGE GIRL IN A PARADOXICAL CITYâœ¨I usually step into the cinema with my ears wide open for melodic or even textural cues, so at first, I was disappointed that Sunshine was not narrated by music.Yet, this film is a mirror to reality. What drives it is the noise of the outskirts of Manila. It perfectly captures the cityâ€™s paradoxesâ€”how medicines for abortion are sold right outside the church, how even those we look up to in the pulpit sometimes abolish the very values they preach. And we see all of this through the lens of a teenager with big dreams, someone who has always been drowned out by the voices outside her own.I love how her sport, gymnastics, becomes a metaphor for letting go of the noise to hear that determined, resounding music inside her. Even the ribbon she uses in her routines subtly foreshadows the choice she will make by the end of the film.Kudos to Direk Antoinette Jadaone for being brave enough to tackle a taboo topic in a self-proclaimed Christian nation.And while the score isnâ€™t the narrative driving force, the intentionality of using it sparingly only makes those few moments shine even brighter.

as much as it tries to appease both sides, it succeeds in giving attention to the harmful effects of criminalizing abortion: people will always find a way even if it places them in danger. itâ€™s a call to action to lawmakers to legalize abortion and prioritize sex education, as well as to shed light on sexual assault. what i particularly like is that it tells the audience that regardless of your reason (e.g. SA victim or dahil ayaw lang maging nanay), women should have affordable access to abortion. << another good detail is the subtle women solidarity that helped sunshine and mary grace >> while the movie succeeds in its objective, one striking detail is the inclusion of the â€œchildren.â€ their purpose is to show the guilt and emotional turmoil of the women, however they might also come across as abiding to the belief that unborn fetuses have lives. it pushes women to feel more guilty just because they want to save their lives and futures.still, it was a great and brave movie especially in todayâ€™s political climate.

bata pa para magmura pero â€˜di bata para pilitin na magdala ng buhay sa sinapupunan? maris racal embodied the cry for help that is screaming in every woman in this country. this is a movie that is made for all filipina, by a filipina, and through a filipina â€” sunshine. she is every good and bad and all in between this country is. mapapaisip ka na lang talaga na bawat mura valid. hindi natin sinusuportahan ang teenage pregnancy, pero â€˜di rin â€˜to dahilan para isara ang usapan patungkol sa abortion. dahil hindi sa lahat ng pagkakataon ang pagbubuntis ay bunga ng pagmamahalan, kung kadalasan ay may mga gaya ni menggay â€” bunga ito ng pangaabuso. regardless, a woman should have the right to decide. paano kung nandiyan na? nagbunga na? the only question we all should be asking is: what are the safe choices available to women when she decided to not continue? with all my heart, i am not ashamed to say that abortion should be one of the options, because it is healthcare.sa gitna ng init at madilim na maynila, ipinakita ni sunshine na hindi siya magpapatalo, kahit pa magdala ito ng panganib sa kaniya. she faced her adversities with grace despite her shaking nerves. and in that moment, i felt like i was there with sunshine, making a space for myself in that tiny filthy room. and i wish i was. i wish i was there to hold sunshine. that sequence alone shows that this country puts women in dangerous position â€” alone and afraid. when theyâ€™re supposed to be supported and cared for in such difficult times, not ridiculed and preyed upon. because a choice should not be dressed as shame, it should be shrouded with pride and dignity. amidst all the pain that is sipping from the story, sunshine saw that even in the roughest edge of life, kindness and sense of community in every filipino will always remain. itâ€™s just that, in reality, the truth is not all women are meant to be mothers. especially not a child. despite the crazy scene between that ob-gyne doctor and sunshine in the maternity ward, i heard her loud and clear: â€œgising na ang bataâ€, nagising na siya sa reyalidad.

From Jane in Fan Girl, Mace in That Thing Called Tadhana, Joanne in Never Not Love You, and especially Lillia Cuntapay in Six Degrees of Separation from Lilia Cuntapay, Antoinette Jadaone has never been afraid to push boundaries and champion strong women leads. However with Sunshine, she takes on one of the most urgent and most avoided issues in the Philippines, womenâ€™s reproductive rights. Itâ€™s a subject that still feels taboo in mainstream conversation, weighed down by religion, politics, and stigma, yet Jadaone dives right in, making a film thatâ€™s both brave and necessary.Maris Racal leads the film and delivers what I think is her best performance yet. She carries Sunshine with a mix of quiet strength and raw vulnerability. Every hesitation, every glance, every burst of courage feels lived-in. Alongside her, Jennica Garcia is a standout as Sunshineâ€™s feisty sister, funny, protective, and fiercely loyal.That said, Sunshine isnâ€™t flawless. One recurring element (the little girl who keeps appearing as a symbol) doesnâ€™t always land. It does add emotional weight, but there are moments in the film where it felt like it's trying hard to be poetic which the story didn't need as it's strong enough on its own.However, there is no denying of the film's influence. Sunshine, challenges the taboo around women's choices and their bodies in the country. It shows the limits that society has built against them. It challenges the audience with the harsh reality of women in the Philippines, to empathize, and perhaps even to reconsider beliefs that were thrust upon us.The performances by Racal, Garcia, and the film's women ensemble were bold, the message timely, and incredibly personal. Sunshine, ultimately achieves its purpose of inspiring thought and discourse in the modern day.

Plando, may attention to detail, and thoughtful are usually not descriptions for a Filipino movie (especially now), but this one was a joy to watch. It treats the audience as adults, it rewards them if they pay attention and if they actually turn on their brains. Never mind the deeply emotionally captivating subject, its attention to detail is enough to keep you watching. Its also a gorgeous film to watch (nde mala bodycam footage), with concise editing. It's just sad na all of these things should just be the absolute bare minimum, pero nowadays its already such a high bar to reach for the vast majority of films.

Bravest and probably one of the best Filipino movie of the year. The story is somehow not new, teenage pregnancy in a religion dominated country while being torn in pursuing a life-long dream, yet it delivers a profoundly powerful message. What makes the movie stand out is the raw and very realistic story telling. Another key element to note on the movie is the portrayal of women in the society. Showcasing the different types of women and the choices they make with the hardships they face. The actors did a stellar job delivering their roles with such depth but in a calm yet strong performances from the lead (Maris Racal) to supporting casts.Sunshine is a wake up call that choosing yourself before anything is not selfish. In time where dog eat dog society focusing on your dream and life goals is never bad. Never let others choose the path for you and you should never be defined by your mistakes in the past.
