Sunshine glows with a quiet brilliance, weaving through the shadows of its heavy subject matter with the grace of a film that knows precisely when to hold back and when to break you open. The narrative feels unforced yet deeply felt, as though the film is simply breathing alongside its audience, letting the undercurrents of sacrifice, determination, and bittersweet resolve infuse every frame. Itâ€™s cinema that neither wallows in its pain nor shies away from it.At the heart of this achievement is Maris Racal, delivering what can only be described as a star-making performance. Racal inhabits her role with a disarming naturalness, navigating the character Sunshine's emotional terrain with nuance and restraint that make every flicker of joy, every crack in her voice, and every moment of silence resonate all the more. She doesnâ€™t perform so much as she exists on screen, making the characterâ€™s struggles and small triumphs feel achingly personal. Her chemistry with the ensemble cast only amplifies the filmâ€™s emotional pull, but itâ€™s in her solo moments that you realize youâ€™re watching an actor step into her full power.If thereâ€™s a stumble, itâ€™s in a sequence that leans heavily into magical realism and heightened sentiment: well-intentioned but a touch uneven compared to the rest of the filmâ€™s assured storytelling. Still, Sunshineâ€™s value lies beyond its craft; it opens space for difficult but necessary conversations about the tangled intersections of agency and structure in abortion, religion, and healthcare in the Philippines. Itâ€™s a tender, unflinching work, and Racal is its radiant core.
Sunshine shines (literally and metaphorically). Pampaisip, pampaluha, pampalakas, kasi grabe, hirap talaga maging babae.

I'm glad this movie's gaining the traction that it's getting. It makes for a tough conversation, but it's a dialogue that needs to be had. I watched it during its 3rd week here in the Philippines, but the fact that it's about to go on its 5th week is a huge deal! Things are looking bright.With Sunshine herself, I've never seen any of Maris Racal's movies/shows, but she definitely carried this movie. She showed so much vulnerability and grit, and I'm glad this movie didn't hold back with its punches showing the journey she went through. She was definitely in good hands being directed by Antoinette Jadaone.Having seen a good amount of Jadaone's movies, she really does well with writing female characters. She doesn't make a princess out of them in her stories, instead she creates such raw figures that are passionate but flawed. They're put out of their comfort zone, placing them in situations that give them a reality check that changes them. Sunshine, to me, is probably Jadaone's best, pushing those boundaries.Personally, there's a lot of love to give this movie, but the few things I'd complain about with Sunshine are really just nitpicks. First off is the use of code switching. Jadaone's movies aren't great with that, honestly. In this movie, it didn't sound natural and came off more theatrical, taking away from the grounded tone. It didn't make or break the story, but it did pull me out a bit. The other thing would be the use of a celebrity cameo. It happens during such a pivotal scene and I'm not sure if the cameo really had to be in that moment because it felt distracting. Either way, Maris Racal's performance was so strong, she brought the attention back to her.Regarding other things I loved about Sunshine, the kids impacted the movie hard! The way they were used to show conflict towards Sunshine's act of abortion displayed how sensitive of an act it really is. They bring up the conversation of choosing your own life or theirs, the failure of the healthcare system, and the type of pigs people can be. The conversation that struck me a lot was honestly the one regarding religion and how it viewed abortion. Being someone who's grown up with family members who have similar views, the dialogue sounded like an echo. Having seen Sunshine, I'd honestly show it to them in hopes for an understanding that there's more to life than scripture.Sunshine is another one of those movies that prove how good PH Cinema is at displaying the faults of the Philippine society. It has a stance and seeks justice. Hopefully someday, the freedom of choice is given and brings us to a brighter future.

Read a lengthy review of this film prior to watching it and Iâ€™m genuinely glad I did not let it sway me. This movieâ€™s far from what it is being criticised for; it demands something from the watcher, the whole thing is a call to action.I donâ€™t think this is a film that you could fully grasp unless youâ€™re well versed in the experience; sometimes your own body is the enemy, most of the time it is the patriarchal system that doesnâ€™t grant you autonomy. I approached this film with a fair amount of skepticism, scared how this film might be twisted into something anti-abortion/pro-life, and there were points in the film that made me question Antoinette Jadaone's true stance on abortion. This film is far from perfect, but it should not bar it from receiving any merit, especially from the local and international scene.Many people wax poetic about Maris Racal (Sunshine)'s and Jennica Garcia (Ate Geleen)'s performances, and I wholeheartedly agree. But, my favorite scene does not even center around the actresses. Maris Racal had very few lines when she walked in the maternity ward: it was framed in such a way that the spotlight was given to the mothers. In that cramped, underequipped ward, how many of them chose to be mothers? How many of them did not have any choice? What kind of socioeconomic condition are they bringing their children into? Is that in any way just or fair for both mother and child? This film is more than just about whether or not you are pro/anti-abortion, but what it means to bring life into this country. I hope people see the material conditions in which mothers are forced to raise their children, and how these conditions work against so many women who are just like Sunshine, Ate Geleen, and Mary Grace.Truly, this is one of Direk Tonet's best work yet. I can only hope Maris Racal continues to accept more gripping films like Sunshine.

Antoinette Jadaone is easily one of the more exciting directors in Philippine cinema today. From That Thing Called Tadhana to Fan Girl, she has proven that she has a knack for great storytelling. Sunshine follows a young woman named Sunshine, an aspiring gymnast on the cusp of joining the national team. However, on her way to the tryouts, she discovers she is pregnant. From that premise alone, you can already sense the filmâ€™s intended message. The real question isâ€”did it manage to convey that message effectively, and was it worth watching?Honestly, there were moments when I wished the storytelling had leaned toward subtler messaging. At times, the delivery felt jarring, with certain lines of dialogue seeming out of place against the filmâ€™s overall themes. The whole subplot involving the little girl, while clearly meant to be uncanny, didnâ€™t quite land for me. Iâ€™m not sure if it was the dialogue, the acting, or both, but the scenes didnâ€™t hit the emotional beats they were aiming for.The storyline with the pregnant child, which could have been deeply moving, failed to evoke much emotion for me. The relationship between Sunshine and the child felt rushed and underdevelopedâ€”lacking the depth and â€œmeatâ€ that could have made it more impactful. And while the film did attempt to portray the pressure Sunshine was under, it felt limited. Aside from her coach and the broader societal judgment, there didnâ€™t seem to be other tangible forces at play. Given her status as a decorated gymnast, surely there would have been more parties invested in her career and personal choices.That said, the film absolutely succeeded in its core objective: to shed light on the struggles young pregnant women faceâ€”the emotional turmoil they endure (a burden I would argue no man could fully comprehend) and the necessity of abortion as an option. In a society steeped in religiosity, Sunshine sparked discussions, provoked current beliefs, and opened minds. Was it worth watching? Absolutelyâ€”100 percent. Films should provoke thought, and this one certainly did.In terms of performances, I have no complaints about the cast (apart from the awkwardness with the child actors) and some peculiar dialogue choices. Maris Racal, in particular, was phenomenalâ€”truly the anchor of the film. Her range and emotional depth were on full display, and sheâ€™s the reason I remained engaged throughout. Honestly, if anyone else had played Sunshine, the impact would have been far less potent. I even found myself shedding a tear by the end, purely because of her performance.All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed watching Sunshine in theatersâ€”especially with the guy on the back's funny commentaryoverall 4/5

si elijah canlas pa-english english pa pero napakaconstipated maglabas ng 5k??? like hello ok ka lang???anyway, i honestly didnâ€™t expect to like this movie as much as i did. but wow the storybuilding was soooo goooooooddddddddddddd!!!!!!!!!!! itâ€™s one of those films that a lot of people love for a reason!!!!!!!! made me sob in my seat twiceâ€¦â€¦â€¦.. the way maris acted, and the way direk told this story felt raw and sosososo real. like painfully real. thereâ€™s comedic relief here and there, but i think thatâ€™s exactly what helped it land. it gave the masa space to breathe and connect kahit mabigat yung topic. despite the sensitivity, i donâ€™t think it alienated anyoneâ€¦â€¦â€¦..the scene that really hit me was when sunshine visited menggay in the ward, and there were other moms aroundâ€¦ idk something about that moment just made me realize how much women carryâ€¦ emotionally, mentally, physically. iâ€™m not saying all women donâ€™t want to be mothers but the reality isâ€¦â€¦â€¦. a huge number of us donâ€™t even get to choose when and how we enter that role.i love how sunshine didnâ€™t have to scream the plot to peopleâ€™s faces. it speaks so strongly to women but it also says something to anyone whoâ€™s ever felt cornered by circumstance. and for once, it felt like someone was finally brave enough to show that on screen with no sugarcoating. just real life and real filipinos trying to survive.a lot of filipino films today tend to go for trauma after trauma but never really take the time to tell the stories of actual filipino people. this one felt different. it was pro-choice, yes, but more than that, it was deeply people-centered. you could feel the care and the intention in every frame!!!!!!!!! it didnâ€™t treat its characters as symbols, it treated them as human beings, with flaws, fears, joy, and agency. and thatâ€™s what made it so good :)

Mahirap din ikwento yung ganitong kwento dahil nanganganak â€˜tong issue na â€˜to (no pun intended) sa context ng Pilipinas so pwedeng mag all over the place yung delivery (again, NO PUN INTENDED)Peroâ€¦ iâ€™m glad they handled this carefully. Same formula ng teleserye drama and realism na trademark ng mga indie movies ni Ms Jadaone. I really like na itâ€™s always women ang tumutulong kay Sunshine, even if some of them are against her decision. Goes to show na tayong mga babae lang rin ang magtutulungan sa isaâ€™t isa.Iniisip ko paano magiging ending nito while watching. Kasi it can only satisfy a single viewpoint regarding this matter. Pero! yung build up ng character ni Sunshine compensates for this. She gives you a walkthrough of her life, ng mga mahal nya sa buhay, ng mga pangarap niya, ng personified guilt niya. And in the end, ang perspective niya lang ang mag ma-matter.

On SUNSHINE by Antoinette Jadaone: A film can only get better not with its insistence on a belief but its provocation. When it does provoke, it lays down what triggers a conversation rather than merely playing woke. It tells us to look into the very fabric of our being: challenged, wounded, longing to have the freedom to choose. Not long in the film Sunshine (Maris Racal) gets on and off a classic puj with a huge phrase on its top front: Gift of God. The film uses a tool for contention against its voice, telling us it is aware of the moral indignation it faces.The film lays down everything in clear context: Agitated, confused, and lost Sunshine on the streets of Manila; by and in its proverbial structures (school, church, motel) with her dreams at stake.Jadaone captures Manila as the rightful milieu where Sunshine struggles to walk through cramped, narrow spaces in pursuit of her dreams which are challenged by society's expectations.This is cinema opening up a conversation that does not displace religion. It actually depicts vulnerable humanity, and the conditions that make it hard for people, especially women, to exercise their own agency.The film is especially brilliant in how it captures Sunshine navigating her choice and along the way showing empathy for others. The part where she connects with a young girl expands the film's statement on how women and children are left to suffer without much of a choice. I'm not crazy about the penultimate scene, though.Visualizing Sunshine's internal struggles through that little girl played by Annika Co is a good choice, albeit too much in the end. The statement in the penultimate scene need not be said as the two characters' gestures already speak it.The film should've thrown out such literalism and just allowed us to make sense of it without the words. We could've silently uttered them ourselves.

[Personal note: Ang cheap lang tingnan nung ending, parang hindi naman world championship, parang pang Purok Dos lang eh]But.. THE MOVIE IS SO GOOD. It talks about abortion in in a more deeper sense, but not that morally god-fearing shit that they usually shove to our months, but rather, it focuses on women, their dreams, and the healthcare that they need. I just wish that the Philippines will consider legalizing abortion and the proper healthcare that women should receive. Itâ€™s always been â€œhow about the child?â€ bro, the kid wasnâ€™t even born yet, but we tend to forgetâ€”the mother, who will literally carry the child, and motherhood? thatâ€™s not fucking easy. I love the little kids aspect symbolizing their conscience, guilt, and innocence, but I think they are more directly portrayed as the personification of the unborn child. and the scenes of Manila? this is one of the films that really captured the heart of the unfiltered Manila streets. I hope regarding this issue that society still actively avoids, I hope sooner or later, ma-gets din nila why it matters.

Quiapo is perhaps the clearest picture of the irony in how reproductive health is addressed in the Philippines. It is both an iconic seat of Catholic devotion and a bustling marketplace where, in the shadows, unsafe abortion remedies are sold. Beneath all the rebultos and religious pageantry festers a moral hypocrisy; a silent yet suffocating grip on womenâ€™s rights that controls and restricts womenâ€™s bodies under the guise of â€œprotecting soulsâ€.Araised fist to the bravery of the crew for taking on such a sensitive topic without resorting to outright antagonism toward religion. The film doesnâ€™t just tell a story; it forces us to see the contradictions we live with every day, making the screen a mirror we cannot look away from.

When I was still a teenager, an old friend very drunkenly showed up at my home unannounced asking to stay the night. They had shared that they had gotten an abortion that day and they didnt want to go home as no one knew. Even after a decade, I still think about that night. Itâ€™s been a decade, and thanks to this film, only now am I truly understanding the degree of how truly isolated and at risk my friend was. Abortion is health care. It should be legal, affordable, and accessible. To deny it, especially to those most at risk, because of absurdly misunderstood doctrines is a failure on our nation.

Choice. A woman's struggle is not merely choice, it is built upon the fabric of society in patriarchy. Patriarchy that seeks to subvert the ideal of autonomy for any gender and any human. The right to autonomy has no bounds because it is ultimately the human destiny to choose its path. It is ultimately our own story. Others have no right to vandalize it. Feminism is not just about being morally communal but about lifting collectively ourselves from the binds that the ribbons of capital and hierarchy have interlocked. Sunshine is brave. Sunshine is proud. Sunshine is all of us. Human. Mortal.

I went into this movie not knowing what it was about or what to expect. And when I found out that it was a local film about teenage pregnancy, I got vertigo from rolling my eyes because I expected a Ted Talk on abortions disguised as filipino acting (aka â€œ hysterics and histrionics).In fact I prematurely dismissed this as a hokey afterschool special and joked that they should have just called this â€˜Maris Racal: Ate Nadali â€˜ Well. Sunshine is the best example that nothing is as delicious as sinking your teeth into a wet, juicy wrongburger with a slice of humble pie for dessert. Letâ€™s start with the performances. The acting was so authentic and so genuine at times it felt like I should apologize for sticking my nose into their conversations. I think the caster should also be given their flowers because I donâ€™t think anyone other than the artists could have played them in the film. I expected Maris Racal to Rachel Berry her role as Sunshine but she played it with such earnest aplomb, she made her struggle so real and visceral, I still didnâ€™t know how to handle it even if I was just a fly on the wall. Then thereâ€™s the (Iâ€™m doing the air quotes with my fingers) TWIST that Stevie Wonder could see a mile a wayâ€¦ but that really wasnâ€™t the rug pull here. Actually it was pretty smart and meta that the rug pull was the fact that the reveal wasnâ€™t a rug pull. At the end of the film, it wasnâ€™t resolved if abortion is bad or good, or if the Church is unsympathetic or cares genuinely, or if teenage pregnancy is the choice of the mother or the family. And that lack of resolution is the only correct answer.

[a reply to a friend seeking a review, so this is rather spontaneous]G: itâ€™s simple, affecting, in a sense na it gets that ricky lee-stamped edge-of-your-seat combo ng social realist and entertaining. and the subject matter was carefully handled, and (as a child of women and devt) itâ€™s a good entrypoint sa struggles of getting the kick done dito sa atinâ€¦ you face the same hurdles, what more sa taong nag-iisa.itâ€™s an update to Hinugot sa Langit i would say. update in a sense na Hinugot was primarily tackling social dilemmas by situating a woman who must contend with them to move forward along with her peers, Sunshine exposes social realities through the lens of a gymnast then proceeds to zoom in on her individual success, conquering the realities. How they work perhaps isâ€¦ Bernalâ€™s film is outside looking in on Carmen, Jadaone is inside her gymnast looking out.and lastly: update in a sense na you get to see kung ano ang objectives ng film artist ngayon, given the issues we have always grappled with.

In the 21st-century Filipino cinema, I believe Sunshine is, by far, the most daring. It tackles the struggles most women suffer in a country that suffocates them.It's baffling that to this day, the Philippines still does not legalize abortion, divorce, and same-sex marriage. All of these stem from religionism that was pushed down our throats by one of our colonizersâ€”the Spaniards. And it's funny how all of these are legal in their country now, and we're still stuck and continuously regressingâ€”all because of a belief and an intangible figure.And Sunshine was able to highlight that. The pressure from society and the backward thinking of its peopleâ€”especially that certain doctor in the filmâ€”are among the reasons why basic rights and safer options are still being denied to women, why abortion is still being frowned upon.I hope more upcoming films will dare to challenge the status quo, without the concern of playing it "safe," something that I think persisted somehow in Sunshine. We need more stories that disrupt, provoke, and refuse to conform.

ang maynila ay pinagpapawisan at puno ng kalagkitan.malayang iniikot ni sunshine ang maynila, ngunit ramdam sa bawat hakbang niya ang gapos na nagpipigil sa kababaihan upang tumakbo at sumayaw nang may lubos na kalayaan.nasa pelikula ang iba't ibang uri ng kababaihan at paraan ng kanilang pakikitungo sa mundo. may mga pagkakataong nakakapagtaka ang kanilang aksiyon, ngunit hindi ito ipinakita upang ipinta sila bilang kasuklam-suklam, kundi bilang biktima ng ideolohiyang humulma ng mapanlamang na hirarkiya.hindi naging duwag ang pelikula sa pagpaparamdam saâ€™tin na hindi lamang maynila ang nababalot ng malagkit at hindi matuyo-tuyong sigalot. karamihan pa rin sa atin ay pawis na pawis na makialam sa desisyon ng kababaihan sa kanilang katawan at awtoridad.pero ang katawan ng babae ay hindi battleground ng opinyon. hindi ito lunsaran ng debate. ito ay pag-aari niya. hindi ng simbahan, hindi ng estado, at lalong hindi ng kung sino mang naniniwalang alam nila ang mas tama para sa kaniya.hindi hinayaan ni sunshine na maging pawis na lamang siya ng maynila. hindi siya nagpalamon sa masikip, mapang-gapos, at dumaragasang kaisipan na nakabaon saâ€™ting lahat. nangibabaw ang kaniyang pangarap at pagkababae.at masakit isipin na maraming sunshine ang bumitaw sa kanilang mga pangarap dahil sa mapagpigil na kaisipan. ngunit ano man ang maging desisyon ng sinumang sunshine, desisyon nila ito, at hindi kailanman magiging sukatan ng kaniyang pagkatao o magiging rason upang tuluyang tumigil mangarap.dahil ang bawat pagpili ng babae ay para sa sarili niya. hindi ito obligasyon na kailangang ipaliwanag. hindi ito pagpapatawad na kailangan niyang hingin. hindi ito kasalanan na dapat niyang pasanin.aaminin kong hindi naging perpekto ang pelikulang ito sa pagpapakita ng bigat at presyon na kinakaharap ni sunshine. naging kalat at mabilis ang takbo ng kwento. pero hindi sapat na rason iyon upang tuluyan kong talikuran ang naratibong nais nitong iparating. gets na gets ko ang naging takbo. kahit na may mga pagkakataong naging tunog pilit ang usapan ng mga karakter, gets ko pa rin kung bakit. tingin ko dahil na rin may mga manonood na naghihintay talagang subuan. pero kahit anuman ang maging interpretasyon natin dito, ang pelikulang ito ay naging matapang at totoo.nawa ay maging pelikula ito na mumulat hindi lamang sa mga tulad ni sunshine, ngunit pati na rin sa kapatid, coach, kaibigan, ob-gyne, pharmacist, receptionist, tindera, boyfriend, at sa lahat ng nakapalibot sa kaniya. maging paalala nawa ito sa lahat na karapatan ng kababaihan ang mangarap at abutin ito nang may kalayaan.go sunshine, my olympian.

Antoinette Jadaone, one of the most interesting and exciting filmmaker working today is a champion of realism, and-or, telling the story as it is. This style compliments humor (Six Degrees of Separation from Lilia Cuntapay), romance (That Thing Called Tadhana), or drama (Fan Girl). Her latest effort aims to tackle a taboo topic amongst Filipinos, and based on her latest works it's pretty evident that she's the right person for the job.Sunshine is a neatly paced movie with a force of an acting from Maris Racal as the titular character. Jadaone managed to brought the audience into the streets of Metro Manila, effectively making the whole city claustrophobic by the help of sound mixing. However, I find myself not being a fan of some of the writing decision. First, it took me a long time to fully digest the Kid as a narrative device; I would've preferred a raw and natural point of view from our main character. This is more of a preferential complain and I wouldn't fault the movie for it, since I also understood what it's going for. My second issue is a subplot being suddenly introduced in the second act. It's easy to understand why they had to mix in some sort of parallel to make the subtext richer, but it disrupted the movie's cohesiveness and flow.Nevertheless, this movie exists for a reason, it already existed as the lives of many and will continue to be.

"Raw" â€” I think thatâ€™s the best word to describe this film.From the story to the cinematography, walang halong arte. I love how it showed Manila as it is.No filters, no polished sound. Yung kantang malakas sa jeep, videoke ng kapitbahay, pati mga batang sumisigaw ng "Kuya, isama mo kami!" all of it made the film feel real and alive.Itâ€™s a film starring a woman, made by a woman, and for women. It gives us a glimpse into the life of a Filipina just trying to survive and follow her dreams sa mundong puno ng judgment, lalo na galing sa mga lalaki. Imagine the struggle, for a choice to her body all because of patriarchy, toxic culture, religion, at expectations ng society.Pero ang ganda rin ng message: kahit gaano kahirap, ibang klase yung support ng kapwa babae. Meanwhile, yung mga lalaking wala namang karapatan manghusga, sila pa yung pinaka maingay.I watched this alone, but with a full crowd. Collective reactions were so telling. Tawang tawa lahat sa mga funny scenes, then eerily silent during the heavy scenes. Ang bigat. Sunshine represents so many Filipinas, lalo na yung mga walang privilege. Sobrang tumama sa akin yung take niya on Christian guilt, abortion stigma, at kung paano faith and culture, though well-meaning, can also be oppressive.Hindi ako babae, pero after watching this, kahit papaano, may nakuha akong kaunting understanding. Hindi ko mararanasan yung pinagdadaanan nila, pero ngayon, kahit papaano gets ko na.

The film is bold for presenting the reality faced by women who experience unwanted pregnancy. Maris portrayed the role excellently â€” it fit her perfectly, making it satisfying to watch.

Ang galing ni Maris! She mothered that role. No pun intended.I'm not really fond of Filipino films as they always fail to peek my interest when it comes to filmmaking. However, if the movie talks about social and political issues like it has in SUNSHINE, I can tune and lock in.SUNSHINE is straightforward to its message. It's about dealing with abortion in a country where not only is illegal but also discriminated hardly. A sensitive topic portrayed with a really good script by Jadaone. What a complete package in terms of writing. The story is justified.Even though I may have found the climactic moments not explosive enough, I'm sure the average Filipino conservative does. Personally, I am pro-abortion and I believe women have the rights to their own bodies. I'm glad the movie went in the direction I wanted. As someone who has seen a lot of abortion films in Holywood, this is the first Filipino. And I just applaud everyone in this project for the risk and making a statement through SUNSHINE. For that, it's already a big win for independent Filipino cinema as theaters flock and raise the demand. Because at the end of the day, a movie is not only good if it's good, but also if it sparks conversation. Hundreds of essays and reviews are out there for this film. It makes the whole movie going experience worth it even more.#Sunshine 4/5

I've been curious about Antoinette Jadaone's SUNSHINE ever since I saw the teasers some months back so I am glad to see it in cinemas now, and doing very well at that. First off, it's refreshing to see a Filipino actor commit to a role so fully whether its the physicality required as a rhythmic gymnast or the emotional demands of a complex character going through a tumultuous personal conflict, something Maris Racal did admirably. The movie happens basically over three days but delivers a roller coaster ride of emotions for Maris who is in virtually 95% of the scenes and carries all of the heavy lifting. SUNSHINE is also unlike anything Antoinette has ever written and directed and it is wonderful to watch her evolution as a writer and director, tackling such a sensitive and challenging material with sure handed confidence. Meryll Soriano, Elijah Canlas, Xyriel Manabat, Jennica Garcia, Angeli Bayani and others provide ample support but this truly rested on Maris Racal. This movie doesn't have commercial written all over it so when it succeeds like OPPENHEIMER or HOW TO MAKE MILLIONS BEFORE GRANDMA DIES, the performance is something to cheer about. The theater was packed [sold out], had an enthusiastic audience [a little too chatty with some commenting on everything going on] and the film was well-applauded as the credits rolled. Unlike many Filipino films that screen in cinemas but could just as easily be viewed in streaming, SUNSHINE delivers with full power on the big screen. I came in with little background except for the film's premise but was thoroughly immersed for the next 90 minutes. Aside from the writing and direction, the film boasts solid DP work from Pao Orendain and score by Rico Blanco.. Congrats Tonette, Dan, Bianca and the rest of the team behind SUNSHINE.

if this shares anything with films from ph cinema's golden age, it is a strong thesis statement about manila. a lot has changed since we have moved from one marcos to another, but the power sunshine holds is to choose the one thing that has endured -- belief.driven by ambition, comforted but oppressed by religion, and deceived by folk medicine, sunshine's situation is a product of the convictions of those around her. fact and fiction are difficult to distinguish from her perspective. whether the effectivity of unregulated medication or the potential of an unborn child, a pregnant woman has to deal with the gradient of reality that is muddled by a conservative environment. importantly, sunshine is not a product of circumstance, but an active agent in negotiating her place amid all of it. i have my gripes with the main plot device of her possible unborn children, but i also feel open to interpretations that explain them. this is going to be an important filipino film and its artistry is probably secondary to how it might change views.

Honestly, 3.5 stars for the movie overall, but here's extra 0.5 star for the super random cameo that was also somehow super on the nose. It's such a good bit that amuses me to no end. I'd rate the movie higher if not for a plot device that felt completely unnecessary and at times distracting. Take it away, and it won't even change anything about the movie. Every time they employed this plot device, it was just so unnecessary and distracting. The movie also squeezed in too many "unwanted pregnancy" tropes that it risked being too bloated story-wise. Think of an "unwanted pregancy" trope, it's there. They stop short of it being too bloated at the expense of the story (and you have to give it to Antoinette Jadaone for this balancing act), though I still spent a good chunk of the movie wondering how many more tropes were coming. Still the movie is brave, and is made so much better for its bravery. It does not shy away from the realities faced by so many women in this country when it comes to maternal health. It tackled head-on the heavily religious overtones that tends to dominate the conversations around this topic. It shows the ironic juxtaposition of abortion pills being sold next to religious artifacts. But most importantly, it does not get preachy. It does not feel like it is patronizing the audience about what should be in each scene that squeezes your heart, it just shows it. But also Jennica Garcia steals the show in every scene is in. Maris Racal deserves the accolades she's getting for carrying the movie so steadily as its lead and with everything asked of her for the character. But Jennica Garcia just commands every scene even she doesn't say a word. And every scene these two have together was really gold-medal worthy.

This has the conviction needed to show the reality of having to live as a woman. It tells a story of having your life bound to the socially constructed rolesâ€” no agency over your choices, body, and womanhood as a whole.I just love how Sunshine is unapologetic about its message. Despite it being from a country that is critically conservative, it did not care. Rather, it tried to deliver its essence in a way that makes people understand it. I am not going to take that plot-wise, it might have lacked. But it did manage to start and end strong. Maris killed itâ€” so to speak.

set the scene. modern-day manila, a city equally bound by the abundance of opportunity as it is bound by the abundance of consequence. sunshine is a dreamer tied to the goal of becoming an olympian. she is told to drown out the noise while she lives a life enclosed by it. she gets pregnant by a good for nothing conyo elijah canlas and is told that her poverty-stricken ass should carry the burden of aborting the baby. and of all places, she finds herself in quiapo, manilaâ€™s catholic landmark, praying to Jesus as she repeatedly journeys through the downtown in her search for the most effective pills while surrounded by statues of Mary, her conscience carrying the loudest whispers that deem her a murderer, echoed by the church she sought forgiveness inâ€”and the very God she prays to.there exists an assumption about the matriarchal philippines, a country that holds its female sensibilities to the highest regard in the same way it adores Mary. yet as we are exposed to our societyâ€™s deepest cancers, the mask of matriarchy only rings true for as long as it submits to the role of patriarchy and as a result, we are a nation of contradictions because of this reality. only in the philippines you can see a catholic girl pocketing abortion pills in a church. sunshine is no Mary, and manila is no matriarchy. her conscience rides through a push and pull with the conservative ideals she was brought upon. her best friend briefly ditches her out of familial pressure. her exâ€™s family (hi papa p) barges in their house to own up to the mistake. sunshineâ€™s life is filled to the brim with contradiction. in spite of this, even with her lack of maturity and the ever-so demanding backdrop of a patriarchal manila, there remains glimmers of hope, her own thriving matriarchy within the small space she can truly call her own. an environment not bound by fluctuating contradiction, but by the permanence of choice.

sunshine isn't just a film, it's a mirror held up to every system that tells women to endure and accept. from the very first scene, i was already scared for sunshine, i felt her fear, her desperation, her quiet panic, and the film forces u to sit with it.the film hits hard on a truth that shouldn't even be up for debate, sa traditional at conservative country na tulad ng atin, it has always been easier for men. and yet, men should have absolutely no say over women's bodies.sunshine also dismantles the idea that motherhood is the default setting for womanhood. it's not. it has to be a choice, our choice.and sex? it's human and natural. pretending otherwise only creates more situations like sunshine's, where women are forced into situation without access to safe, comprehensive healthcare.this isn't just a movie you watch. it's a movie that makes you remember why we fight, because the sunshines of the world are real, and they deserve better.

Sunshine is definitely a must-watch. More than just the brilliant performances, especially by Maris, who portrayed her role with such raw honesty, the film strikes deep because of the story it tells. It dares to talk about what many still shy away from: the state of our healthcare system, the stigma around reproductive rights, and how these deeply affect the lives of women every day. It powerfully shows how abortion is healthcare, and how denying safe, legal options doesnâ€™t stopâ€¦

Sunshine is an important filmâ€”one that Filipinos shouldnâ€™t miss. Itâ€™s not the strongest film, but itâ€™s certainly worth discussing.In fact, it currently tops my list of Filipino movies this year. And thatâ€™s precisely why I feel a sense of disappointment. At the very least, I wish it had resonated more deeply. It had the potential to delve further into its realism, but instead, it chose to spoon-feed every emotional beat, leaving little room for quiet reflection. While I understand why Jadaone took this direction, I canâ€™t say it worked for me.Personally, I wasnâ€™t fully sold on the use of children as a narrative device. The way the film delivers its message too overtly makes the subplot involving the 13-year-old feel disconnected and distracting. The child character might have been more effective as a symbolic presence, her inner voice, her conscience. Had it stayed that way, rather than taking the more problematic route of literally giving life to unborn children, as in Arianaâ€™s case, the film might have delivered a far more powerful impact.Still, there was a moment near the end, a line that marked a turning point of understanding and acceptance, where freedom was finally felt from guilt. That scene alone earned the film a 9 out of 10 from me.

Maris and the rest of the cast were perfectly chosen for the film, with each character making a meaningful contribution to the plot. Maliban sa acting and galing galing din ni maris sa mismong mga gymnast performances niya!!To be honest, I initially found Sunshine disturbing and lacking in many parts. It felt like the film held back, especially in its screenplay and pacing. But as I reflected more on it, I realized that might have been the pointâ€”although many of the scenes were commendably filmed, the film wasnâ€™t trying to entertain; it was trying to confront. Maliban sa mismong tema ng storya, sobrang daming iba pang paghihirap na danas ng lipunan natin na mismo ako ay hindi aware ang naipakita sa pelikula.The rawness and silence I initially perceived as weaknesses were actually reflections of Sunshine herselfâ€”caught between the pressures of gymnastics and the weight of her misfortunes. In that light, I came to see that her quietness was powerful and already served as the message.The film was created not just to tell Sunshineâ€™s story, but to help us recognize the many "Sunshines" around usâ€”especially in the Philippines, where abortion remains heavily stigmatized due to political control and religious conservatism. Sunshine challenges us to understand their pain and see their urgent need for help.I truly hope that someday, those in power will recognize that safe and legal abortion is not just a debateâ€”itâ€™s a right every Filipina deserves to have.

sunshine explored important and sensitive topics that are not only necessary for filipino audience to see but also essential to open dialogues and conversations, to shed light on and ultimately to spark change especially on things that are often labeled as taboo in a conservative and retrogressive country like the philippines.the film does not impose, it only depicts the struggles of the character. it shows her grit, resilience and her power to decide for herself. sunshine is a beautiful portrayal of a womanâ€™s ability to choose and her autonomy to determine her fate. despite the living ironies sheâ€™s confronted with, she remains hopeful, that she could still follow her dreams and that she could rule over her life against all odds. she doesnâ€™t have to conform. no one else could dictate how her story goes but her.sunshine does not necessarily promote pre-marital sex or abortion. it goes beyond issues of healthcare and reproductive health. it advocates empathy and compassion to the sunshines of the world. it allows us to understand the complexities and the silent pains and plights women go through and why thereâ€™s a need for them to have access to safe and equitable options.

"sunshine" delves deeply into prevalent social realities and dares to question long-standing traditional systems. but what struck me most was how it thoughtfully explored womenâ€™s bodily autonomy, weaving it into a narrative that felt both natural and unforced.the lead's inner turmoil exists in the gray areasâ€”a subtle moral dilemma, especially when prioritizing autonomy challenges societal expectations.this raises critical questions: how does sunshineâ€™s obligation to herself impact the broader community? and what roles do the people around her play in shaping or reinforcing these expectations?i honestly wished there was more screen time, yet in the moments it was given, it still managed to leave a profound message about women's reproductive rightsâ€”one that lingers and quietly settles in your mind.

The OB admitting section was, and still is, one of the busiest parts of the hospital I worked in as an intern. It had been renovated prior to my first duty there, and it would be renovated once again after I'd left. Both of those renovations were done in part to address a persistent issue: that the place never runs out of patients. Every day, and especially on Mondays and Fridays, the admitting section would take in a significant number of expectant mothers with all sorts of conditions. Some would be giving birth for the first time. Some were veterans who were familiar to the staff working there, giving birth like clockwork every year. Some had serious conditions alongside their pregnancies that made giving birth extremely complicated, to the point where their current state posed a significant risk for death while giving birth. Nevertheless, they would slowly fill up the adjacent labor and delivery room, often two to three mothers to a stretcher. On very busy days the stretchers would run out, and the labor room would be filled with mothers settling down wherever they could, mostly on the cold, tiled floor.I remembered those days in the admitting section when I saw Antoinette Jadaone's latest film, Sunshine, about a young gymnast (Maris Racal) who gets pregnant right before a very important event that might lead to the SEA games and eventually the Olympics. Sunshine doesn't have any qualms about making the decision as she immediately gets to work trying to find an abortifacient to terminate the unwanted pregnancy. This process is not made easy. Miggy (Elijah Canlas), the man who impregnated Sunshine, wants nothing to do with her after learning of her pregnancy. He doesn't even tell her to have an abortion directly, only saying that 'she knows what to do.' Getting medical help is equally difficult, and intersects gender with class: medical treatment is expensive (despite the fact that state sponsored healthcare should be financially accessible) and as abortion is still illegal in the Philippines, people resort to black markets to seek the care they need.Once in a while, the OB admitting section will receive a patient who has lost her child. Miscarriages are common, and often they are spontaneous. Once, a mother of a stillborn child asked me if the cries in the next room were her child's, when I knew the infant was lying in a box, ready to be given to back to their parents. Then there are the other kinds of patients, ones who made a choice like Sunshine. They all had their reasons; this was a conscious and informed decision. After a while you know it when they come in. Sometimes the doctor would come in and tell them that what they did was illegal, some would even threaten to call the police. Nothing ever came of it; they were empty threats - often to 'scare' them into not making that decision again. It always made me uncomfortable.To be born a woman is to be born into violence, into a world where the odds are stacked against you. Sunshine is not the first film to depict this violence - films like Rae Red's Babae at Baril (2019) and Jadaone's own Fan Girl (2020) are two examples. They show what a deeply patriarchal society creates: people like Miggy and a certain other character near the end, people who I interpreted as not exactly archetypal or allegorical towards the structures that created them, but as the inevitable products of it. But unlike those two films that I mentioned earlier, Sunshine feels far more indignant, full of anger that Fan Girl lacked, and drawing towards a different conclusion compared to Babae at Baril.Quiapo has been a backdrop for many a Filipino film, and here it is a sanctuary of sorts. It is here where Sunshine goes to find the solution to her problems. Ironically draped in religious imagery, it both embodies the faith it represents (as a source of refuge for those who are in need) and as something that stands against its tenets.Sunshine is a film about choices: the choice to live one's own dream, the choice to live freely as the best person you can be. Sunshine's sister Geleen (Jennica Garcia) coaches Sunshine as she practices in their shared home. Certain background elements (thanks to the film's excellent production design) hint that Geleen, too, was once an aspiring gymnast, whose dreams ended with a baby. If she had the choice, would she have lived a different life? It shows as well in Geleen's character, and Garcia gives a standout performance as her.Finally, that idea of "refuge" may not refer to Quiapo, but something else entirely. Throughout the film there are many people, both seen and unseen, who help Sunshine in her quest. "Ipagdadasal ko kayo," a hilot tells Sunshine after they bring a child to the hospital who made the same choice. "Mag-ingat ka," another one tells Sunshine as she sets off. A sympathetic medical professional gives a knowing look. Every doctor has a story like it: in one of my last rotations at the labor room, a patient walked in nervously in the robe the hospital supplied her. It was a very busy day, and pregnant women overflowed on the stretchers and sat on the floor. She had no business being here: she looked no older than 14, and she should be going to school and playing with friends, not in the last stages of giving birth. Suffice it to say, this pregnancy was not her choice. If she had the choice like Sunshine did, would she be here? On the other hand, the point of the film for me is not whether one makes one choice over the other, but that people like Sunshine and that kid has the ability to choose in the first place.Because the labor and delivery room should be semi-sterile, companions (in this case, the kid's very worried mother) are not allowed in. But the rest of the mothers in that labor room heard us taking the medical history and heard her story. The other expectant mothers gave the kid their blankets, talked to and comforted her, up until she gave birth. Everyone was that kid's mother that day. In a world where you are denied agency, where one is subjected to violence from birth, the least women can do is find refuge in each other.

Promise, 'di siya overhype.Weâ€™re halfway through 2025 and far from its denouement but I must say that SUNSHINE, if not the best, is one of the best and one of the most important films of the year. Iâ€™m so sorry, SIX DEGREES OF SEPARATION FROM LILIA CUNTAPAY, but I believe I now have my new favorite Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s work. They said during the promotion that this is the last day this will be shown here sa provinces and then starting tomorrow, sadly, it will only be shown to 3 cinemas na lang so I felt the substantial need to watch it tonight. Mind you, sobrang bigat pa rin ng pakiramdam ko, tapos na lahat, at ngayon na tina-type ko lahat ng to.Sunshine heavily tackled significantly sensitive issues here in the country - rape, teenage pregnancy, poor healthcare, and machismo. At habang ina-absorb ko lahat kanina inside the movie theatre, I couldnâ€™t help but think about my two sisters who are the same age as the protagonist. Ang bigat. Ang lala. Ang hapdi. Give me a span of time to write an essay about this and I will take that challenge without a doubt. Thatâ€™s how it affected me big time. It hits home.Now letâ€™s talk about the performances. First sequence pa lang, itâ€™s apparent that Maris Racal studied the role. Inakap niya at binigyan niya ng kaluluwa yung karakter. Hindi siya bumitaw hanggang final sequence. She had a lot of silent moments in the film and those were the most powerful. Nakakabingi yung katahimikan na halos hinahabol ko na rin yung hininga ko minsan. Jennica Garciaâ€™s character, on the other hand, though itâ€™s just a supporting role, is one of the main highlights throughout. Yung kahit minimal lang yung dialogues niya, tignan mo lang siya sa mga mata niya, maiintindihan mo sya. I love her here. Sheâ€™s too authentic. May eksena silang dalawa ni Maris dito and that was when I lost it. Iyak ako eh. GRABE YUN. Grabe yun!!!!As for the direction, from the bottom of my heart, thank you, direk Tonet. Iba pa rin talaga kapag ang kwento ng babae ay gawa rin ng babae. Maselan, matapang, at may puso. Salamat sa buhay mo. Nag-uumapaw sa social realism ang pelikula mo. Lino Brocka wouldâ€™ve been so proud!! Sunshine knows Manila and all its aches and decays. May problema ka? Okay, pero hindi titigil ang mundo. Hindi titigil ang buhay ng mga naka-paligid saâ€˜yo. Dagdag mo pa na nasa Maynila ka kung saan life is always on survival mode. The film captured those perfectly.Lastly, Sunshine doesn't preach or impose. She makes her decisions but doesn't force you to change your opinion either. Your role as an audience member is to listen. The rest is for you to reflect upon on your own.Gets ko na.
i trust that direk tonet will always, always introduce her female characters with so much care and understanding.

sunshine is a film by Tonet Jadaone. context is very important because if you have seen jadaoneâ€™s films (That Thing Called Tadhana, Fangirl, Alone Together among others) then you will know this is HER film. you feel it in every frame. the writing. the direction & performances. thereâ€™s no voyeurism here. no moralizing. just truth. honest, specific, sometimes messy truth about what itâ€™s like to be a woman in this country. not in the headlines, not in theory, but in the streets, in health centers, in quiet conversations with friends who are too afraid to say what they really need.maris racal delivers the performance of her life. she holds back when she needs to. she breaks in silence. she carries every scene with restraint, sensitivity & precision. she becomes sunshine. and itâ€™s the kind of performance that demands to be remembered.the ensemble is just as grounded. jennica garcia, thea, the kid: each one brings something real to the table. nothing is forced. they donâ€™t play characters. they play people youâ€™ve probably met. maybe they remind you of someone you know. maybe they remind you of you.what makes sunshine work is not the acting or the direction but the refusal to look away. the film doesnt hide behind a metaphor. it gives us a manila that feels exactly like the one we move through. where pamparegla is sold outside churches. where motels wonâ€™t let you in if youâ€™re alone. where grieving teenagers are all around but they have kept it in because no one has dared say â€œyouâ€™re safe here.â€ from my POV, the film takes a narrative risk. thereâ€™s a device that briefly pulls you out of the realism it builds so well. but it sticks the landing. because what matters is that you never stop feeling for these women. and that you leave the theater asking why stories like theirs still feel unsafe to tell.iâ€™ve had my own sunshines, close friends, a relative, a classmate. women who needed care, not judgment. watching this film felt like watching them again. and all i could think was, â€œplease, let her be safe.â€this film deserves a seat in our national conversations. not just in cinema panels, but in health committees, in policy rooms, in the offices of people who still think there is a valid excuse to deny access to care.one of the most necessary films of the year.

Kung hindi ngayon, kailan? Kung hindi ako ang magiging boses ng aking mga batang babae, sino? Mahalagang pakinggan, bigyang halaga, pagtuunan ng pansin, at kilalanin ang boses natin, ng mga kababaihan.Ang usapin na ito ay hindi â€œbastosâ€ at â€œnakakahiyaâ€. Ito ay usapin ng karapatan at pagtatanggol sa karapatan ng mga babae. Ang pagiging kaisa sa abortion ay hindi ibigsabihing hinahatak natin ang mga kabataan sa mga gawaing imoral. It is about having choices especially sa mga kababaihanh biktima ng karahasan, kahirapan, at pagsasamtala sa kamusmusan. Not having a choice is actually a choice but sadly, that choice is not what us women need. We want to be heard. We want to have a choice that is pro women. Bilang guro, tungkulin ko ang ituro ang karapatang pantao at kasama sa tubgkulin na yon ang pagbabahagi ng karapatan na dapat ay malayang ibinibigay sakanila.Hindi ako makapikit sa mga isyung direktang nakaaapekto sa kanila. Kung hindi ako magsasalita para sa kanila ngayon, baka wala nang makinig bukas. At kung hindi ko sila tutulungan na magkaroon ng boses, paano nila maririnig ang isaâ€™t isa?Sana ay magkaroon tayo ng kamulatan tungkol rito, hindi batay sa takot o pananakot, kundi batay sa science, kontexto, at malasakit.

Sunshine does not go the way of those brutish Brillante Mendoza social commentary flicks where the end goal is to suffer, and suffer, and suffer... instead it opts to project its demons as an internal problem. That, which works quite splendidly if not for the fact that this is a film supported by a very tepid and uncharacteristic score from Maris Racal's own ex-partner.That being said, the best things about Sunshine actually emanate from its night sequences. It captures wholly the distress, illegality, and dismay of everything to do with abortion, the black market, and whatever Sunshine's problems are adjacent to in reality. Those night scenes seemed straight out of Abbas Kiarostamiâ€™s Like Someone in Love.It's actually so apparent by the film's end that everything that does come out of this leads to the most reasonable one: a film that doesn't explicitly preach what to do, save for what its problem is tied to in context.But yeah, that score really does this thing a disservice. Tom Cruise was right.Anyway, WHAT IS MY HIGH SCHOOL PRINCIPAL DOING IN THIS MOVIE? (siya yung binasagan ng bote nga pala)

In an infamous spot near Quiapo church, "Sunshine" presents one of the biggest ironies in this Catholic-dominated country. In there, a vendor can be found selling religious figurines and paraphernalia, along with illegal pills and abortifacients tucked in plain sight. Whatâ€™s more sarcastic is that a poster of â€˜Abortion is Murderâ€™ can be sighted on one of the stalls. If youâ€™ve ever been to that place, you know that itâ€™s all true.And so, teen gymnast/aspiring Olympian Sunshine (Maris Racal) searches through the alleyways of the aforementioned Quiapo for a quick solution to her dilemma. How can she terminate her unexpected pregnancy to avoid being disqualified from an upcoming SEA games competition? Director-writer Antoinette Jadaone has always been superb in writing female leads by adding deep empathy to their plight (as seen in â€œFan Girl,â€ â€œNever Not Love Youâ€). When you have a fully-fleshed character on screenplay, plus an actress who possesses the right amount of emotional depth and range, the resulting portrayal feels genuine and lived in.One of the filmâ€™s highlights takes place inside a seedy motel. With only minimal lines, Racal, in a career-defining performance, deftly showcases Sunshineâ€™s internal turmoil and physical pain. Pao Orendainâ€™s sensitive camerawork captures the whole ordeal in an unobtrusive shot. Likewise, his cinematography excellently mirrors the growing anxiety in Sunshineâ€™s head, from the bustling streets of Manila to the crowded wards of public hospitals.Piling up to the metaphorical noise are secondary characters and conservative ideals that dictate whatâ€™s best for Sunshine. Admittedly, there are moments where the film could have represented the â€˜pro-lifeâ€™ side more nuanced than an ultra-conservative OB-GYN or a patronizing pastor, as depicted. But the film finds profound intent in the emotional journey that Sunshine goes through, with no sympathy begging that most advocacy films do.Hence, it will be reductive to say that â€œSunshineâ€ is just a pro-abortion film. Instead, it is a complex look on womanhood and pregnancy, and how the Philippinesâ€™ patriarchal laws fail to prioritize their bodies. It is also an admission of how Catholic guilt shames young women engaging in premarital sex, when young men should also be equally put into check.Elsewhere, Jadaone keeps a keen eye for casting an ensemble of on-point performers. Annika Co exemplifies the right level of abrasiveness required in her ambiguous role. Meryll Soriano brings a calming presence as Sunshineâ€™s steely coach. Elijah Canlas and Xyriel Manabat are also effective in their teenage archetypes. And Rhed Bustamante will probably haunt the viewers the most. But it is Jennica Garcia, as Sunshineâ€™s older sister, who lends the most empathy for our titular heroine. You can tell that there's an entire backstory not explicitly stated in the script. Regardless, Garciaâ€™s performance carries the weight of the unsaid history. â€œSunshineâ€ did not win the Crystal Bear for Best Film in the recent BIFF for nothing. Whatever reservations you have in the abortion issue, RH bill or the need for comprehensive sex education in the country, this film is a necessary addition in feminist cinema. It plays a pivotal role in stirring up conversations on womenâ€™s reproductive health. By focusing on the human stories of Sunshine and the countless women trapped in outdated laws, the discourse reaches political without any pretensions. It is one of Jadaoneâ€™s most incendiary works to date.

marami akong nakikitang western reviews calling this so-so. if titingnan mo nga from their pov, oo nga? ano bang bago dito, it's literally about a high school student getting an abortion to focus on her olympian gymnast dreams. but this is where context matters. films like sunshine are so important as a conversation-starter in countries like the philippines where abortion and reproductive health is deemed not as important by a male-dominated government and a religious culture. ang dami pa ring pro-life kaya sobrang hirap para sa mga kababaihan tulad ni sunshine at mary grace magkaroon ng access sa safe ways for abortion. sobrang nakakadala makita sila na irisk ang buhay nila para magpatuloy pa mabuhay. mahirap magbuntis pero di hamak na mas mahirap magpa-abort.at lalo itong pinapahirap ng isang patriyarkal na lipunan, katulad ng doktor na unang nilapitan ni sunshine para tulungan si mary grace. tumatak siya sakin kasi siya ang salamin ng mga kalalakihan sa ating legislation chambers na walang pakialam sa karapatan ng mga kababaihan at galit na galit sa mga plataporma na nagsusulong ng kanilang welfare. isa pa yang si miggy at ang tatay niya. mga barumbado. kaya oo, importante ang paggawa at pagpapalabas ng mga pelikula tulad ng sunshine. nagulat nga ako pinondohan to ng fdcp? at pinayagan ilabas sa maraming sinehan. sana marami pang mamulat sa importansya ng pagbibigay ng choice sa mga kababaihan. choice mabuhay, at hindi lang bilang tagadala ng buhay.

it reflects the real lives of many Filipinos, the struggles, the pain, and just doing whatever you can to get by.itâ€™s brave of the director to tackle abortion, especially in a country where itâ€™s still illegal. u really see the different perspectives people have about it. all in all, the movie was goodâ€¦ no judgment, just raw, real stories.ty.d

I LOVE THIS SO MUCH ğŸ¥¹ two things: (1) you already know my gripe with movies nowadays being too self-aware, esp when making commentary on social issues (e.g. through infodump dialogues and/or in-your-face monologues). given the themes of this movie, i was initially scared that this'll end up having the same issueâ€” but THANK GOD that wasn't the case here. this one actually took the effort to situate us in Sunshine's shoes. it knew how to convey Sunshine's story by fleshing out the world that she lives in, by showing how she relates to others, by showing us the things she does not do and does not say. this movie knows how to practice restraint! that's how it managed to really make Sunshine shine :D(2) i love that this movie makes a very decisive stance on abortion, without having uhhhh such a cold attitude towards children. like, never once did Sunshine change her mind about having an abortion, and this movie also made several strong cases about how motherhood disadvantages/endangers womenâ€” but it also makes it clear that the problem is not... the babies/children? in fact the children are also victims here, as shown in Ariana's case. instead of being shown as ~the problem~ pa nga, this movie instead shows us that children may symbolize hope and companionship and possibilities. the unwanted pregnancy made life difficult for both Menggay and Arianaâ€” but wasn't it Ariana, still, who stood up for Menggay? what Sunshine went through throughout the entire film was difficult and isolatingâ€” but she wasn't exactly alone, was she? hindi man niya gusto 'yung bata, there was a part of her that sought comfort from the possibility of the child's companionship. i think it's just human nature, yenno, to seek connections from others when going through a difficult time. and when you live in a society where you can't disclose all these troubles to anyone, not even to those closest to youâ€” whose companionship can you seek, if not your own flesh that's taking shape into another life? sino pa ba ang mas makakaintindi sa 'yo kundi ang sarili mong laman at dugo? yeah in practice that may not be true LOL kaya nga ipinaabort pa rin ni Sunshine eh xD kahit anong "romantic" ng notion na susuportahan ka ng anak mo anuman ang pangarap mo, that's practically impossible when its very existence is what could hinder you from reaching them lol. pero ayun nga, it's the difficulty of the situation and our human vulnerabilities that add nuance to these discussions.â€”some pro-choice people (and i know they mean well naman) like to claim that abortion is ok because it's just getting rid of some soulless clumps of tissue anyway. and i guess that's scientifically true... but if fetuses are rly just soulless clumps of tissue then why are we so afraid of pregnancy at all...? why do we want to do abortions as early as possible...? I MEAN LIKE, it's silly to keep dismissing the possibility of actual growing life when discussing these things. and the fact that Sunshine Did Not Do That makes this movie good and relevant and real and special and a must-must-must-must watch. i love this movie <33 i hope more people get to see it

A perspective from a young woman's struggle towards her dreams in Urban Manila. Handle delicate and sensitive timely issues-abortion and #ProChoice. The juxtaposition of society and women's struggle. How each scenes will straight out of reality. Your social support will vary and how public space are intermingle of ideas. Each realities matter yet beliefs they hurt-from a Conservative Christian Obgyne female doctor who cannot fathom how a young woman would not want to give birth, to a female Quiapo vendor selling abortifacients in front of a Church, to a dear sister who raised her both siblings who will love her no matter what (Jennica's performance here is so superb, I almost cry), to a 13 year old girl who been raped because by a family member, and finally Maris Racal's Sunshine who undergo making a decision, a choice--that is so hard and required ethics, but understandably absorbed into her role, how every woman in the Philippines simply existing is so exhausting. But also how the patriarchy compels women as their biggest supporter draping the country's public health that hurt and judge women for their choice, to the point of penalizing them as criminals.Sunshine is realism, carefully managed and lay out how women needs always to advocate for their own choice and bodily autonomy.

i cried silently in my seat a few times. i mean how can you not when you remember youâ€™re a filipino woman living in this hell hole? always failed by men, by society, by the government and even by your own religion.i had been anticipating this filmâ€™s release for so long as iâ€™m hoping it will somehow finally get people talking about something as controversial as abortion. so stigmatized and taboo, i literally even took a while to decide whether or not i should write that word down.iâ€™m relieved that this film went where i hoped it would go. i might write a longer review soon but for now iâ€™m just going to say antoinette jadaone was so brave for this.

the irony of the super christian ob-gyne treating sunshine like a child (say thank you papa jesus) while also expecting her to carry a child full term.there are lots of ironies in this movie, especially in how sunshineâ€”a girl, barely a woman herselfâ€”is treated. â€œwhat if the child youâ€™re carrying is the next president of the philippines?â€ but what about sunshineâ€™s dreams? must those dreams end when motherhood begins? whose dreams and potential are more important? sunshine the movie doesnâ€™t answer these questions outright, leaving you to chew on them instead and come to your own conclusions. at the start, i found the narrative device of the child as a manifestation of sunshineâ€™s guilt a little too on-the-nose, but the pay-off in the ending made it worth it. as the ending says: gets ko nabut the best parts of sunshine are when it dwells on the almost fantastical ridiculousness of manilaâ€”not just the place, but also the people. details like the abortifacient vendor using the money sunshine gave her to â€œblessâ€ her holy figurines or the santo niÃ±os looming over their whole transaction or dangerous illegal abortions followed by scenes of overflowing maternity wards. the movie passes no judgement on these scenes but merely offers them up for observation: here is manila in all itâ€™s messy glory. itâ€™s the perfect backdrop for sunshineâ€™s series of bad choices. (and also reminiscent of lino brockaâ€™s film style which i absolutely ate up)

I was lucky enough to be an extra for this film prior to knowing what it was about, upon seeing the trailer, I knew this was going to be special.Maris Racal truly gives one of the best performances Iâ€™ve seen in a long time. She is able to express pain (both physical and internal) in ways that make me writhe with her. I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve wanted to hug a woman through my screen like this in a while.And wow!!! Annika is a star in the making. She impressed me so much in this, especially in the scene where they head to the hospital. Itâ€™s definitely a scene that will stick with me for a long time. Jennicaâ€™s performance also stuck with me (as a panganay~)Manila is presented so cruel, yet so kind in those moments where Sunshine finds help. Iâ€™ve seen a couple of other films talking about abortion in the Philippines (Hinugot sa Langit and 12 Weeks specifically), but I think this one struck me the most. I found this to be extremely nuanced, the presence of the kids and their roles in Sunshineâ€™s life really made me think. Iâ€™m still not a hundred percent sure how I feel about their presence, but I appreciate that it made Sunshineâ€™s plight something to really think about.I also appreciated the ending, I think we often see a remorseful side post-abortion for female characters here. But Iâ€™m glad we get to see someone who gets to move on and continue to dream, to live.I also thought about the other women Iâ€™ve heard about going through similar situations. With how much the world seems to be going backwards, I really hope this piece makes people think about womenâ€™s right more here. No one should have to suffer.

I always say that I sympathize with women who aborted their pregnancy, but this film showed me that I could never feel what they went through.Maris Racal nailed her role; she made me feel like I was the one going through it. I hope in the next generation, people will be more open to respecting womenâ€™s choices.

Not gonna lie, when I first saw the trailer I wasn't sure how this would tackle the topic of teenage pregnancy and abortion, knowing how hard it is to talk about the latter outside of hushed circles without getting a stern lecturing or some weird looks. For most of the movie I was thinking about how in the world this got past MTRCB, CBCP, and literally every old-headed person out there; I'm so glad it did, btw, because it's an important story to tell, and so bravely told at that. Im not sure of the other devices used in this movie but I'm glad we have media that bravely shows a side society tries to push aside. Ang hirap maging babae!!!! We should have better legislation that supports women and children's health and welfare. Whether you choose to be a mom or not, you should be able to carry that out freely and safely. You should be able to be a girl freely. (Such a sorry state of public health honestly hay!!!!!!) Also reminds me of Happening by Annie Ernaux, one of my first brushes with this topic.

we really felt sunshine's struggle. the irony is incredible in using quiapo as the setting. in manila's most sacred place, that's where she finds what she needs.the noise in the entire film feels like it's saying sunshine has no time. everything is urgent, chaotic, pressing. there's no moment for her to process, to think, to breathe. even when she's making this decision, the world doesn't stop. it keeps moving, keeps demanding, keeps being loud.our country pretends these problems don't exist, but here's sunshine, a woman who has dreams, in quiapo searching for a solution to a problem that shouldn't be her problem if we had proper support systems.i like how the film shows us the reality with no sermons, no preachy momentsâ€”it just shows you what is.

Sa wakas napanood ko na din ang Sunshine. Ang ganda ng pelikula at ng acting ni Maris dito, sana magkaroon pa ng ibang pelikula na nagttrigger sa topics na kadalasan ay considered as taboo sa bansa dahil taliwas ito sa nakalakihan na paniniwala ng ibang henerasyon. Hindi madali ang usapan na to pero KAILANGAN gawin dahil dumadami ang kabataan na nalalagay sa gantong sitwasyon. Wala man ako sa posisyon na sinapit ni Sunshine at Mary Grace, pero alam ko na sila dapat ay may CHOICE sa kapalaran nila dahil buhay at kinabukasan din nila ang nakataya.

The entire time I was watching, I felt like I couldn't breathe. It's claustrophobic and suffocating, just like how Sunshine herself feels. You feel her world slowly closing in on her, invisible walls tightening around her in every frame. The camera doesn't let you breathe, and neither does the sound. Manila's noise is constant, overwhelming, and disorienting, especially for a gymnast who needs focus and silence to thrive. Sunshine is literally and figuratively trapped in tight spaces, cramped jeepneys, crowded streets, the overbearing sound of trains passing by, judgmental stares, and high expectations. Visually and sonically, it captures how isolating and terrifying it is to carry a burden like hers in a society that is less than kind toward women. (Btw, just to put it out there, the cinematography and colors in this film are GORGEOUS.) In almost every film that tackles women's issues in the Philippines, you'll find this line repeated in many reviews here in Letterboxd: "Ang hirap maging babae. At lalong mahirap maging babae sa Pilipinas." It's because it's true. Every day, women here continue to fight for autonomy, for safety, for the right to choose themselves. We live in a deeply patriarchal and religious society that expects women to always put others firstâ€”especially family, be it their parents, siblings, or childrenâ€”and shames them whenever something bad happens to them as if they brought it upon themselves. Society never asks the men who take advantage of women simply existing to change, rather it expects women to quietly endure. Bakit kailangang babae ang palaging mag-adjust? I appreciated how the film showed moments of solidarity between women, but it's sad how that's not always the case in real life.Exceptional performances from the entire cast, especially Maris Racal, who is tremendous in the titular role. From the start, she's completely convincing as an elite athlete and future Olympian: disciplined, focused, and has no room for error, as both her dreams and the dreams of others rest heavily on her shoulders. But it's in moments where Sunshine wrestles with fear, guilt, and inner conflict that Maris truly shines. She captures and presents the character's vulnerability so well. Also, as someone who always adored Jennica Garcia since her GMA days, I absolutely loved watching her quiet and subtle acting as Sunshine's sister.I said in my first review of Fan Girl that I hoped Direk Tonet would make an even braver film, and she did. Sunshine focuses and dives deep into the themes it introduces and stands firm in its critiqueâ€”something that I felt was somehow lacking in Fan Girl. While some moments didn't always work for me and the magical realism elements sometimes took me out, I understand the choice. Part of me wishes it stayed more grounded and direct, but the â€œGets ko naâ€ scene near the end hit so hard that I stopped minding altogether. It's a great, important film and I hope it helps open up more discourse on women's reproductive rights in the country.Go see it in cinemas when you can. ğŸ“½ï¸ SM City North EDSA Cinema 6

â€œMy body, my choice.â€ But is it really when your options of what you can do with it is stuck in a country overtaken by religion and politics stuck in the medieval times? Sunshine falls under one of my most favorite genres: social commentary by simply showing girls just trying to live. You can see throughout the film that sheâ€™s just a girl. Asking Miggy for money, asking for help when she needs, acts on her impulse, has dreams and goals, using twitter and Reddit for research (#real), etc. She knows she canâ€™t take care of a whole ass child right now, all she can (and she should) do is to chase her dreams and make a career out of it.Though you can also see that Sunshine doesnâ€™t really hate the kid. She takes care of her the way she canâ€“ giving her money to get home, looking for her when sheâ€™s lost, protects her from adult themes (drinking, abortion, etc). So her decision at the end, itâ€™s not because she hates the kid, itâ€™s because she loves herself. With the limited choices she had, she made the most out of her youth And whatâ€™s so wrong with that? With being just a girl?

" Drown out the noise."This line in the Sunshine struck me after watching the film. Noise is considered as a plot device in the film literally and figuratively. I like how the background music or the noise from the background is used to set the tone and mood of the film especially in scenes where Sunshine is walking or riding a jeep home. Noise in the film can also represent the doubts that fill her while practicing and self-righteous religious people who judge her actions throughout the film.The film is about a gymnast who plans to join the tryouts for the Olympics. However, she receives a result that is unexpectedly pregnant which can hinder her chances in getting in. Maris Racal is great in her role as Sunshine and I think that she embodies the role of a gymnast especially since she tried gymnastics to prepare for her role. There were scenes that were remarkable for me such as when she tries to hit a the mirror of a car after her boyfriend (played by Elijah Canlas) doesn't take responsibility for her pregnancy. I also loved the supporting characters as well. Despite their small roles, they made a mark for me. For instance, Jennica Garcia was impressive in her scenes with Maris Racal as her older sister. You can feel that she defends and protects her sister and stay by her side especially during her revelation that she is pregnant. Xyriel Manabat is no surprise for me since I admire her acting skills since she was a child actress. She is great as Sunshine's best friend. Annika Co, an upcoming child actress, is a scene stealer where she acts as a conscience to Sunshine. She is charming and witty in her role and I think the twist made sense to me in one scene.In addition to it being a sports drama, this film also tackled the themes of women's choice and abortion. These topics are considered sensitive and taboo in a dominant Catholic and conservative society. As a man, this film moved me and realize how hard it is to be a woman in a society wherethey are judged for having an autonomy in their body. In a third world country, healthcare is considered a privilege especially for the poor. Because of abortion being considered illegal and immoral, women are forced to resort to unsafe practices which can endanger them. It is shown in the film and I think it's interesting that it depicted two doctors: one which discriminates women because of her religious bias and one which tried to understand and helped another character in the film who turned to abortion. It's a sad reality, but I'm glad that this film will open conversations about themes like these.Overall, I find Sunshine an impressive film. I think this is Antonette Jadaone's best film so far. It's my second film that I've seen in cinemas and I'm grateful to witness it in the big screen because it is worth the watch there with its immersive experience. I was definitely looking forward to it since it's rare to watch a sports film which centers around gymnastics and it has been shown in film festivals abroad. I was worried that it won't be shown here because of how controversial it would be because of the stand of the Catholic Church and other religious sectors regarding abortion. I guess more people are more open-minded towards the topics unlike before. Aside from the acting, what I found compelling in the film is the cinematography and scoring which adds tension and mood to the it. Despite its limited release and pitted against two superhero films during its premiere, I really hope more people will get a chance to watch this movie. Even if it shows the harsh realities of life and in sports, I agree with other film critics that it also shows hope. There is Sunshine after the rain.

Watching Sunshine wasnâ€™t just watching a movie. Parang I was sitting beside a woman, listening to her story ng tahimik lang, pero sobrang bigat. Itâ€™s not easy to watch, but thatâ€™s exactly why it felt so real. What hit me the most was how the film didnâ€™t try to be loud or preachy. The film doesnâ€™t try to romanticize or a free promotion for abortion. It just let the silence do the work. Minsan iyak lang, minsan wala talagang salita. That makes it more powerful. Hindi ito simpleng kwento. Itâ€™s about pain, dreams, and mga choices na hindi talaga madaling pagpilian.Pero I have to say, may parts na medyo kulang for me. Sana mas dark yung cinematography, like Khalel 15 â€” gritty and raw. Lastly, hindi ito movie para sa lahat. But still, Sunshine gives us something real. And if youâ€™re willing to sit with it and really listen, then youâ€™ll see a side of womanhood na madalas tinatago.
