It is refreshing to see such a brave filmmaker like Antoinette Jadaone take on such a taboo topic as this, and despite its obvious flaws, there is so much to be celebrated about "Sunshine". Her depiction of realist Manila within a predominantly Catholic albeit judgmental Philippines is strikingly affecting, and the first half of this in particular is a worthy showcase of great filmmaking. The plot device did take me out of the film from time to time, and I do not think it was necessary nor was it effective. Yet, what more can you ask for when you have such a riveting turn from Maris Racal, who puts forward a performance for the ages. Those around her are also excellent, particularly Jennica Garcia, who embodies so much heart and emotion in the little scenes that she is in. Could this have been a better film? Yes. But is it one that is worth seeing? Absolutely.[Watched at SM Mall of Asia cinemas]

"Gets ko na. Gets ko na."Antoinette Jadaone's Sunshine sheds light on a divisive but essential issue regarding women's rights, particularly on access to reproductive healthcare. It may come across as a little heavy-handed for some (not me!) in its handling of an abortion story but it illuminates essential truths on the Filipino female experience in a way that's thoughtful, and beams with poignancy, and sincerity. Maris Racal shines along with a strong cast of supporting actors, especially Jenica Garcia. That Maris and Jenica scene at the last act of the film was very moving, iykyk. I saw the film with my mom (who btw adores Maris) and we were both misty-eyed during that scene.I just love that people are having important conversations about this movie. It's proof of the relevance of this story, and of Sunshine as a character who could be any young woman we may know of. So, sana gets na din ng iba dyan!

although i already knew what the premise of the movie was, sobrang emotional pa rin nung dating nung intro sakin. it opened with Sunshine performing her gymnastics routine almost flawlessly tapos maya-maya, it was immediately revealed that she was pregnant. knowing all this beforehand didn't lessen the impact of the intro scene for me - my heart broke for her all the same. living in an extremely conservative country with an extremely poor healthcare system is a nightmare especially for people like Sunshine. where the only choices are to carry on with the pregnancy or risk going through an unsafe abortion - she will get judged either way.another thing that i liked was the kid's character. she can be interpreted in many ways - some say she is Sunshine's what if but i interpreted her as Sunshine's conscience. in the early parts of the movie, she was discouraging Sunshine from going through with her plan but eventually came at peace with Sunshine's decisions by the end of the movie. for me, she was also a manifestation of Catholic guilt - something that most of us carry since we grew up in a religious country. the things she says to Sunshine is exactly the kind of thoughts you would think of when deciding on something that is against the principles you grew up with.surely, this movie will become something that starts a discussion on the sensitive topics it tackled - para sa mga taong nagdadawang-isip pa sa pagiging pro-choice, sa mga taong sinsubukang intindihin yung mga pro-choice, at para sa mga taong katulad ni Sunshine.i just hope that people with more conservative views can watch this para naman maintindihan nila yung point ng mga nasa kabilang side ng diskursong ito.

Sunshineâ€™s strength lies on its strong messaging. It confronts the audienceâ€” yes, what you heard was right. Maternity wards are in terrible conditions. A lot of R*pe and incest victims are of that age. Bigotry and victim-blaming play a huge part in our society. Antoinette Jadaone doesnâ€™t tiptoe or walk around with her message: she is loud, angry, and knows where she stands. Her direction is both observational and sympathetic, allowing the audience to feel for Sunshine and feel helpless in situations out of our control. Despite all of these, itâ€™s an incredibly hopeful movie about choice. Maris Racal is radiant and fantastic, and Jennica Garcia is the heart of the film.
make congress watch this film

We are introduced to Sunshine through her warming up with other student-athletes and performing her routine for the upcoming Olympic team tryouts. Viewers can tell that her prowess and national team member status is a mix of talent and hard work, that even when she messes up halfway through, it doesn't make her any less of a great gymnast.When she first finds out that she is pregnant, the camera focuses on her hands tremble. But she immediately acts on it â€“ searching for suspicious dealers for pills, telling the boy that knocked her up, and going to church to pray that the Lord takes away the being forming in her womb â€“ even when we see glimpses of her trying not to lose her composure in the humid streets of Manila.The film shows and justifies Sunshine's reasons for wanting an abortion, even if the means available in the Philippines will harm her. She has dreams that can't be put on hold, and she clearly is a young girl with mannerisms and tendencies deemed "immature" â€“ factors that do not make her fit to be a mother.But in a scene wherein she talks to a pastor (played by Piolo Pascual, who made everyone in my cinema gasp) that promises financial support throughout her pregnancy and motherhood, she rejects it. "Ayoko maging nanay," she says, plain and simple.That was my favorite part of the film, because it felt cathartic to hear it. Although Sunshine had good reasons for the choices she makes, we must not need to have justified, valid, and layered reasons for wanting an abortion. Some of us do not want to be mothers and undergo the medical complications that come with carrying a child, just because.I hope that it has more time to stay in cinemas. I hope that more people see it, and by the time the credits roll, sana ma-gets niyo na kami.

Really nice. Brava ğŸ‘ğŸ½ Nakakatunaw ng puso. Also shot in Manila, My Manila. So you know how I feel about it haha. What can I say man. Tonette Jadaone. Napakalinis magkwento. Favorite ko rito yung little transgressions. Madalas ang pekilula tungkol sa shame, kumporme sa shame. That is to say parang laging uphill battle. Pero dito ni minsan hindi ako kinabahan para kay Sunshine. Panatag na panatag ako, nakakatuwang panoorin ang deliryo ng biyahe niya mula Quiapo-Avenida-Paco. Wala akong awa, naluluha lang ako sa lungkot. Bitin na bitin lang ako sa last sequence which looking back looked like an Aronofsky reference but contrivedHere is Maris Racal, who Iâ€™ve told my friends has a Mona Lisa face. Minsan 'di ko mawari kung anong nararamdaman niya, but with her command on-screen you could tell what she wants. Desperado. That is an actor you want to play Sunshine.Because Sunshine only has her mistakes to prop her up to dreams, which is a tricky proposition in the city, but nonetheless possible. And is often the case. Kailangang gustong-gustong-gustuhin mo lang talaga. Some kneel for a quarter-mile in Quiapo. Ang iba, pumapatay. Nevermind if your conscience is (literally) following you, you just have to make it work. Ito ang ibig sabihin kung mabingit ka sa mga kuko ng liwanag. To be a womanâ€¦. to be a mother. Gets mo na?

The fact this got to even show in SM nationwide makes me amazed and is a testament to what this film symbolizes and argues for in our society. Even if I didnâ€™t really care for a certain plot device used in the movie and in fact took my enjoyment at certain points from a very grounded and compelling story, the highs of this film is extraordinary and something I will always praise. The way the camera and direction paints the complex feelings of Sunshine, the usage of Manila as both familiar yet alienating in its loudness and chaos, the rage and social commentary that is extremely brave in our current societyGiving tons of flowers for this film, I would even say that taking away the campier/comedic aspects of the film would have made this a masterpiece in my eyes! Maybe in another rewatch, this would get a higher score!If you liked the direction Direk Tonet took in Fangirl and wanted to see it taken to a different level, this film will be for you!

Sunshine (2025, Project 8 Projects)I acknowledge that there are a lot of things in life I take for granted as a cisgender man. In Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s new film, Sunshine, she presents a flawed yet heartbreaking tale on the female cost of pregnancy.In the film, we follow nineteen-year-old Sunshine, who has dedicated most of her life, along with the support of her sister who was also a former gymnast, in rhythmic gymnastics and her pursuit to enter the Philippine team for the Olympics. However, several weeks before the National tryouts, Sunshine discovers that she got pregnant after a recent sexual encounter with her boyfriend.Stepping out of the theater, I realized how itâ€™s so hard to be a woman, not just in the Philippines but in general. And pregnancy, one of the human experiences that only a cisgender woman can experience, and how much it impacts on their health, emotions, and even their dreams or aspirations - especially when it happens completely unplanned. All of these are further amplified in the situation here in the Philippines where sexual education is still not a priority, access to quality maternal care is expensive, and role of religion to beset unfair expectations towards women.Despite having a strong message, there are things in Sunshine that I wish had been improved on. I must admit I felt a bit cheated out because the movie was initially hyped as a sports movie focusing on gymnastics - the same way Rookie did for volleyball, but in the end was more of a character drama that whose lead character is a gymnast. I wish that Jadaone delved deeper on Sunshineâ€™s motivations on why gymnastics is important to her because at how the story was written, Sunshine couldâ€™ve played any sport and the story would remain the same. Before I get called out, I know the movieâ€™s true intention is a commentary on the state of female reproductive health in the Philippines, but I felt like it was just a missed opportunity to highlight the state of female sports in the Philippines, particularly gymnastics because Filipino sports movies are so rare. I also felt like that the script couldâ€™ve been tightened up a bit as the elements of magical realism introduced in the story (without going too much in spoiler territory) didnâ€™t land as much in terms of story logic.As a follow-up to her lead starring role in 2023 movie Marupok AF, Maris Racal continues to be one of the promising actresses of her generation. And in Sunshine, she delivers one of her career best performances so far, especially at lengths her character goes through and in the dedication to train of the gymnastics segments of the story.Overall, Sunshine is not an easy watch because it doesnâ€™t mince the hard truths of how it is living as a woman in the Philippines. And now with with the ongoing female reproductive health and sexual education discussion in the Philippines, Antoinette Jadaone offers a strong message on why it is imperative that protections for womenâ€™s health should be passed, and why the movie Sunshine deserves your time and your attention.However, irony that this movie can only be seen by a limited number of people because of its R16 rating as well as the unfair cinema practices in the Philippines, makes this even more frustrating.

i mean before anything else: maris racal is RIDICULOUSLY good in this. like, she's really one of the greats we got in the philippines right now. i seriously need to tap into her other work.but wow. what a film. it never really tries to pull back with handling the topic of abortion and how taboo it is here. and it doesn't make it some overdramatic thing at points too because... it's all real, once we pull back one surreal element the film has. the way the people treat it, talk down on it, that near total disregard for the pregnant person. it's heartbreaking. watching this just made me think of how much people act like men and women are wholly equal under the eyes of the law in the philippines. but with incidents like what's seen in the film still happening, is that really the case?a real shame that this will be in like three theaters by the time wednesday rolls around. even then, i'm glad a film that handles a difficult topic was able to screen nationwide. i seriously hope this film resonates with people this opens up more minds.

After two decades in the industry, Antoinette Jadaone has cemented her capacity to bend, direct, and write with different genres â€” the deconstruction of ekstras with Lilia Cuntapay, the ironic and hilarious takedown of cosmetic surgery industry with Belo-approved meta-comedy â€œBeauty in a Bottle,â€ and the dialogue-driven romantic hugot dramas with â€˜Tadhana.â€ Without a doubt, Jadaone stands as one of the most vital voices in Philippine filmmaking today, consistently challenging conventions and pushing Filipino Cinema forward. In all her films, one thing thatâ€™s notable she's put women's voices at the forefront. She has since taken a pandemic pause after Fan Girl, but this has also led to her researching and diving deep into her most recent film, Sunshine. The film follows a student gymnast, Sunshine (Maris Racal), who discovers sheâ€™s pregnant just as sheâ€™s about to compete for the SEA Games. The film takes a surreal turn when she encounters a kid/ alter ego appears in crisis moments, reflecting her inner turmoil as she faces societal judgment.Throughout the film, Sunshineâ€™s emotional arcâ€”marked by anguish, desperation, and vulnerabilityâ€”lays bare the reality where womenâ€™s access to safe choices is morally questioned and legally denied. This taboo isolates her: abandoned by friends and her partner, judged by doctors, and pressured by her coach to give up her dreams. Social stigma is one, but the films also highlights how poverty and consequently, sexual miseducation put into question the dignity of women. To be able to choose freely, is too high of a cost for Sunshine who has to deal with its social, financial, and legal repercussions. The film understands how for women in the fringes thereâ€™s little to no choice.The film is not without hope. Her sister, whoâ€™s a single mother, grounds Sunshine. Her alter ego serves as emotional salve during her many crises. And she also chances upon an underaged girl months into her pregnancy who reflects and echoes her experiences. In each of them, Jadaone realizes Sunshineâ€™s future: to be a single mother, carry her pregnancy to term, and have a daughter. The film effectively wrestles with the nuances of her situation: to choose her dreams or be with a child. Ironically, Sunshine occasionally stumbles under the weight of its many themes: its surreal elements and side characters threaten to overshadow Sunshineâ€™s emotional arc. It makes one wonder how better the film would have been had it just been, as the film title suggested, about Sunshine. Nevertheless, the film is a showcase of Jadaoneâ€™s confident vision.Thereâ€™s this wonderful scene in the film of a maternity ward that just for brief moment became a community for pregnant women and mothers helping and supporting one another. It epitomizes the warmth that carries Sunshine forward: from isolation to solidarity, and from uncertainty to self-understanding. Parting with her past, she talks to her alter ego hoping sheâ€™d understand. They hug. To be understood thatâ€™s just what Sunshine needed.

i sat at the best seat in the cinema (in the middle!) and love how tastefully beautiful it is visually and sound wisethe visuals remind me of lino brocka + tsai ming liang meets in quiapo, manila. the place itself becomes a character, those shots of sunshine wandering through the urban chaos tell us so much.. especially that scene in the cheap hotel near morayta, when the train passes by and itâ€™s like the city is holding her pain, witnessing everything, maybe even screaming alongside her. the way they use sound here is incredible, and almost throughout the film too, like the noise (and sunshine trying to â€˜drownâ€™ them out) becomes part of her headspace, you know? the city breathes with her loneliness. the city is even â€˜herâ€™though i find the jojo rabbit inspiration kinda out of place with what the movie already has going for it, maybe itâ€™s just jadaoneâ€™s style of directing, trying to move away from brockaâ€™s straight realism into something more surreal, but it doesnâ€™t really work for me since this story needs that grounded feel. still, i appreciate that they didnâ€™t just simplify everything. i personally think films should capture the messy (nuance!) when dealing with complex topic like thisbut overall i think this is really tight and visually gorgeous. my favorite part is when sunshine just whacks that creep with the suitcase. what an improvement from her previous film where the character just called the police lol. this is how you try to attempt a feminist lens in a movie, especially this one, the character arc trying to â€˜breakâ€™ from the â€˜setupâ€™ of the reality they are set in.. like them trying to pull a fourth wall break, but internally, if that makes sense

Late diary entry. It really is true that employment screws the cinephile in us. This is Jadaone's Never Rarely Sometimes Always (2020) mixed with the magical realism of Jojo Rabbit (2020), and Brocka's depiction of Maynila as a harsh, predatory city that traps and exploits the marginalized. There's a night scene that was basically taken from a Brocka handbook, framing, camera movements, dialogue. I love Jadaone's growth as a filmmaker and this project shows how she matured in multiple filmic aspects, but more so on the commendable screenplay. The conversations felt realisticâ€“ something a Gen-Z would say in the present context. There's a clever and subtle critiquing done by adding the English-speaking scenes as well. As if they poke fun at the other contradictions in our postcolonial, patriarchal society now.Multiple ironies and contradictions lie in this filmâ€”the titular character's name doesn't coincide with her lived experiences, the vendor selling the religious images of Nazareno and Sto NiÃ±o also sells the abortion pills, how the people who claim to care for us are so quick to judge if situations do not align with their perspective or morality. Sunshine to me was a thought-provoking way of presenting a very evident issue in our Philippine society, and Jadaone made it brutally honest without lacking the compassion and clarity to bring about this story.I love how hopeful the ending was tbh. I know that this country has been so steeped in religious conservatism that even acknowledging how hopeful that ending was would raise flakâ€”but this movie has done a great deal to create awareness and productive discussions on unwanted pregnancies. Sunshine was a confrontation of our modern maladies, something that very clearly threatens the health and future of women. That's another contradiction in itself, having a government by the people, for the people and yet it chooses to ignore the evident crises of its people. I digress. Gets kita, Shine. [Watched at SM Seaside with my baby]

Although Sunshine (2024) advanced the conversation about abortion and body autonomy, one treatment of the film sets the conversation back.Don't get me wrong tho', it effectively presented difficult conversations within an already difficult subject. It doesn't just talk about abortion in the moral sense, but also its nuancesâ€”such as abuse and inaccessibility of healthcare, including both financial and policymaking aspects that rob women of the right to appropriate medical procedures.It also gave face to the concept of guilt through the personification of the unborn, embodied by the characters of the unnamed child and Ariana.But that very personification is where exactly the issue starts.The argument for the pro-choice position is the fact that life does not start at conception, but upon delivery. To personify unborn fetuses strengthens the narrative that abortion is murder. "Murderer," as the unnamed child called Sunshine the moment abortion crossed her mind upon knowing that she's pregnant.But how much does this set the conversation back? Not a lot, really.The film did not fail in doing its job. By tackling abortion itself, it already succeeded in sparking conversations such as this one. And that's already a huge step in advancing women's right to accessible healthcare.Let's just hope that we'll get to see more "woke indie films" like Sunshine (2024). Art, after all, is not solely for its own sake.

â€œgets mo na â€˜ko?â€ id like to believe that the kid was a depiction of sunshineâ€™s conscience and its such a powerful statement to put out there â€” that sunshine didnt have anyone to convince but herself. that its okay as long as the choice was hers and not anyone elseâ€™s, especially in a society that often robs women the decision to make a choice in the first place.and despite the loud and often guilt-ridden noises that paralleled the packed and polluted streets of manila, it contested the catholic and cis-heteropatriarchal belief that the sole purpose of womanhood is motherhood and to choose to become someone else is to sin. but sunshine wouldnâ€™t have come through all odds if it werenâ€™t also for the women in her life that chose to show up for her. the only thing more powerful than the dangers that women are constantly subjected to, are the embrace of fellow women who just understand it. sunshine didnâ€™t even have to utter a single word, her silence, both in her vulnerable and fearless moments, was heard. the quiet glances between her and thea, reassuring her that she is seen. her sisterâ€™s arms reaching out to her in bed, making her presence known and reminding sunshine that sheâ€™d never be alone, the gentle squeeze of menggayâ€™s hands to let her know sheâ€™s safe. they all heard and seen each other, and having someone whoâ€™s willing to carry and share your burden with is enough for everything else to be bearable. gets na gets kita Sunshine, at sana mas marami pang mga pilipino ang makarinig at makaintindi saâ€™yo at sa kuwento mo.

Jadaone has given justice in telling the plight women face.Sunshineâ€™s character is imperfect and flawed, but real which makes you root for her character. This was emphasized by the camerawork which maintains a certain intimacy with the character that makes you see Sunshineâ€™s vulnerability. Racal portrayal of Sunshine makes you want to empathize with the character because amidst of all the imperfections, there is this young dreamer. Her poor decisions are the consequence of the society she exists in, wherein there is no other choiceâ€” leaving her to opt for desperate methods.This film is so personal bilang isang babae.

â€œGets ko na.â€In this film, we follow Sunshine, a rhythmic gymnast and an Olympic hopeful, as she travels through Manilaâ€™s dark, narrow, grimy, and crowded streets and alleys in search of a way to terminate her pregnancy in a country where abortion is illegal. There are few parts of this film that really stood out to me because they made elevated the movie and made it more compelling.The first part that I really liked is how the city became a living representation of this countryâ€™s oppressive stance against anything pro-abortion. The city allowed us to have something tangible, to be able to relate to Sunshineâ€™s struggles even more. Second, the magical realism aspect is also a highlight for me. Once it finally clicked what Ariana and Annika Coâ€™s characters represented, I was blown away. One common argument of those against abortion is that you are going to kill someone whoâ€™s probably gonna be a very important person. And yet, we get Annika Coâ€™s character. Through a very powerful performance we end up caring for this kid. But once you start to realize who she us and who she represents, you start to realize that sheâ€™s not just an extension of Sunshine but a representative of all babies born to mothers forced to carry a child. She and these babies are vessels forced to carry the unfulfilled dreams of their mothers. She said something like, â€œAng pangarap niya ay ang pangarap ko.â€ And that line broke me. The argument is always, â€œWe are not fulfilling someoneâ€™s potential if we abort them.â€ but thereâ€™s always a failure to acknowledge that forcing someone to bear a child is also not allowing them to fulfill their potential.The last part that stood out to me is Maris Racalâ€™s great performance. She is the movie. Without that performance, this film will fall apart and she delivers. What this film did is humanize a debate thatâ€™s usually so contentious it ends up being too one dimensional. It made the debate more accessible to every one. The movie is unflinching and raw. A harsh criticism of a society and culture who despite being always proud of their women, continues to fail them by continuing to enabling oppressive systems that mostly targets women. A big middle finger to a society that still strongly reeks of misogyny. It also an exploration of the countryâ€™s broken healthcare system. This film is a celebration of female friendships and sisterhood. The people who helped Sunshine in her journey are women. It forces you to be uncomfortable. It forces you to think and have empathy. This film is highly relevant and should be a required watching for everyone. Probably one of the most important Filipino films ever made. Hope it gets an even wider release.

Maris Racal is ready for leading roles, and Sunshine gives her everything to work with. It helps that a stellar ensemble of women round out the supporting roles too, with Annika Co haunting her like an undeniable reality. Its plot, certainly a conversation-starter, doesn't all the way succeed with all its creative choices, but it's welcome forward motion for showing that women's choices command respect even if it doesn't fit the ones you decide for yourself. Another thing everyone should agree on is that Antoinette Jadaone has her finger on the pulse of what Filipinos, and the cinephile-going population of the country, need to discuss.

This movie is so satisfying to watch because it empathizes with its main character, sunshine, a young gymnast training for the olympics who happened to have an unwanted pregnancy. Young women like her are figures often shunned in popular philippine media and well, society so itâ€™s refreshing to see someone like her in a sympathetic light. Abortion is such a taboo topic in this country so i very much appreciate the relentless uncovering of the different failures of the government and society with regards to womenâ€™s reproductive health and rights. Props to Maris for fearlessly embodying the role. Abortion is healthcare. It should be a choice accessible to anyone that wants it. It doesnâ€™t have to be earned which is why I do find the imaginary kid representing sunshineâ€™s conscience or the possible â€œkidâ€ she might bear in the future unnecessary and redundant in the face of all the other oppressive opinions surrounding her. If the goal was to voice her inner worries, it wasnâ€™t needed, it was already felt and wouldâ€™ve been better shown some other way. If the goal was to voice the external conservative audienceâ€™s thoughts, then it wasnâ€™t needed as well because theyâ€™re already thinking it, the film shouldâ€™ve been secure with putting its faith on Sunshine alone. Sheâ€™s a woman and she has dreams and having a baby is not part of that. She has value still for just the fact of being a person. I guess it just rubbed me the wrong way. Itâ€™s a very beautiful film nonetheless, shining best in its moments of truth and courage.

Sunshine is the kind of film that lingers in your chest long after the credits roll. Itâ€™s raw, urgent, and quietly devastating. Maris Racal gives such a gripping performanceâ€”her portrayal of a young gymnast grappling with an impossible choice feels painfully real. The way the film contrasts the clean, structured world of gymnastics with the chaos of Manila's underground makes everything hit harder. Thereâ€™s so much weight in the silence, the stares, the quiet desperation. It doesnâ€™t hold your hand or tie things up neatly, but thatâ€™s what makes it so powerful. Antoinette Jadaone tells Sunshineâ€™s story with empathy and fire, shedding light on the terrifying realities young girls face in a country that offers them no choices. Unflinching and necessary.

I still remember when Direk Tonet shared the concept of Sunshine back in 2021 at a workshop I attended. Everyone knew it was risky, yet the story had to be told. It wasnâ€™t a question of â€œhowâ€ but â€œwhen?â€Fast forward to today, Sunshine finally lives and receives its well-deserved spotlight. Itâ€™s easy for some to dismiss it as â€œjust a film about abortionâ€. When in reality, itâ€™s a gritty portrayal of thousands of Filipinasâ€”all the dreams and lives lost, the could haves and what ifs. The fact that this film exists (in this political and social climate) is already a miracle. It being one of Direk Tonetâ€™s masterpieces is just a bonus.

Tackles many of the socioeconomic issues we currently face as a countryâ€”such as the lack of sex education, limited reproductive health options for women, and the taboo surrounding religion in these discussions.An eye opener film that I hope a lot will watch.

women carries the weight of the world the moment they were born 'no? a woman that chooses herself has a lot of implications that makes them look selfish.this film is consistently tight, not making moments linger a second longer than it should be. it places urgency to sunshine's situation and i just love how sunshine has full autonomy and gets right to it the moment that she knew. admittedly, a certain plot device employed here might've become a burden in the long run, there's a moment where it felt like the film doesn't know what to do with it, but in the end it still landed pretty well. jadaone throws a lot of anger in this film. an exasperation to the tito bubots of this world, to the judgmental people who's supposed to make you feel safe, to the system that prohibits women to have safer options, but never to sunshine. what might this film's great achievement is that you feel it too, the film carefully takes you on a walk to make you understand and feel its anger, to understand sunshine, just how much important her dreams are and how she doesn't aspire to be a mother in this time of her life. women carries the weight of the world the moment they were born, but people like sunshine makes it feel that choosing themselves is an act to be truly selfless and for once be free

There is much to commend about the film and it could have been even more impactful had it fully leaned into its intention of confronting the realities surrounding abortion and calling out institutions to respond with compassion and accountability. While it could have been stronger had it fully explored the idea of safe abortion and pushed institutions to respond, the filmâ€™s restraint is understandable given the legal and cultural context. It opens the door for more Filipino films that reflect the lived experiences of many, especially women whose struggles have long been sidelined. Sunshine is deeply human, and in that honesty lies its strength.

Some films entertain you. Sunshine confronts you.When the credits rolled, no one moved. No one spoke. It was that rare kind of silence. Not awkward, but sacred. As if we had all just witnessed something painfully true and didnâ€™t quite know what to do with ourselves.Because Sunshine isnâ€™t just a movie. Itâ€™s a question. A confrontation. Directed with clarity and deep compassion by Direk Tonet Jadaone, Sunshine doesnâ€™t soften its message or try to make it more palatable.. Itâ€™s brave. Itâ€™s loud in its honesty. It doesnâ€™t ask for permission to be angry or tired or vulnerable. It simply is, and thatâ€™s why it hits the way it does. And yet, somehow, even with all its emotional weight, Direk Tonetâ€™s signature humor still finds its way through. There are momentsâ€”unexpected but perfectly timedâ€”when the entire cinema bursts into laughter. Itâ€™s sharp, itâ€™s honest, and it never feels out of place. Maybe Direk Tonet makes us laugh because she knows weâ€™ll cry eventually. Or maybe thatâ€™s just how we are as Filipinos, finding humor even in the heaviest moments, because sometimes, itâ€™s the only way we know how to carry the pain.What makes this film even more powerful is how it gives voice to things we often overlook. As someone who isnâ€™t a woman, I know I canâ€™t fully grasp the weight of that experience. But this film opened a window for me. A clear, honest glimpse into a reality I will never live, but need to see. Much of that power comes from the performances. Maris Racal, as Sunshine, delivers the most vulnerable and grounded work of her career. Her pain is quiet, but it radiates. You feel it in the way she holds her breath between words, in the weight behind her gaze. Jennica Garcia, as her sister, is just as affecting. Her stillness, her softness, the way she listens. She becomes a reflection of what the film asks of us: to pause, to witness, to respond with care. Thereâ€™s a moment near the end that stuck with me. Sunshine asks, â€œGets mo na ba ako?â€And while itâ€™s said to the person in the room, it felt like she was looking straight through the screen, asking us, the viewers. And like that person beside her, I hope we all have the courage to say: Yes. We see you. We understand.Please, Direk Tonet, keep making films like this (inutusan pa nga). Keep telling stories that hold space for women to be everythingâ€”loud and quiet, strong and hurting, tired and brave. Stories that make people feel seen.Gets kita, Sunshine.

Sunshine Francisco played by Maris Racal, is a teenage gymnast dreaming of getting in the Olympics, got pregnant by accident, and must face the moral dilemma of choosing between her dreams and keeping the baby.Maris Racal carried the film to pitch perfection and rawness. She takes you in and makes you feel her struggles. Her facial nuances and physical vigor makes her the right choice to play the titular role, in what could be a role of a lifetime. Director Antoinette Jadaone's never been more sure and absolute of her vision here. The film stands as an audacious statement in a country full of naysayers when it comes to the sensitive and controversial subject matter: abortion. The ending really made me shed a tear, in response to understanding why women do what they do. Though the film is not without its flaws. I sometimes felt the script and characters could have been more seamlessly sewn, and not just coming out of nowhere, making it feel a bit unnatural. Nevertheless, this is an essential film that needs to be seen by a wide audience. It didn't provide the answers, but this is what a filmmaker does best: to start conversations, to challenge the status quo and make us reflect our own beliefs and morals.ps. support local films, local music, local products, and local boys. eme

Antoinette Jadaone has always been one of the few Filipino filmmakers I deeply admire, not just for her craft, but for the way she tells womenâ€™s stories with empathy and nuance. Her work has always felt personal, films like Alone/Together, Fan Girl and now Sunshine, might just be my favorite Filipino film released this year so far.I remember seeing the trailer last year and wondering if it would even get a proper release here. It tackles such a taboo topic, one that many in this country still refuse to even speak about. Thatâ€™s why I admire Jadaone so much. Sheâ€™s chosen to talk about what others wonâ€™t. In a predominantly Catholic nation where abortion is criminalized, even in cases of rape or incest, Sunshine feels like an act of courage.Iâ€™ve always been pro-choice. I grew up surrounded by the whole â€œabortion is murderâ€ narrative, from relatives, from my old Catholic school run by nuns. But even as a kid, it never sat right with me. I never saw it as a sin. And now that Iâ€™m studying to become a doctor, that belief matters even more to me, because women deserve healthcare that doesnâ€™t judge or shame them. Sunshine affected me on a personal level because of that. It reminded me why I want to do this.Itâ€™s not a perfect film. Some might find the pacing fast or feel like it didnâ€™t say enough. But to me, the point isnâ€™t perfection. What matters is that it exists. It dares. Itâ€™s a film that opens doors, uncomfortable ones, sure, but necessary. I really hope itâ€™s not the last of its kind.

a powerful film everyone should see. ang dami kong naramdaman habang nanonood. Sunshine sheds light on how pregnancy can profoundly impact a woman's ambition and future. it shows what women, especially the youth, endure when defying the harshly conservative norms of filipino culture â€” the pressure, the judgement, the weight of it all. ang husay ni maris for delivering the pain and struggle. kudos to miss antoinette jadaone for capturing the reality of our country with raw honesty, even calling out how our healthcare system fails women.

Maris plays Sunshine with so much empathy that it permeates outside the screen, her win is our win, her disappointment is our disappointment. Through the streets of Manila to the corners of her room, we get to hold hands with her and be a confidant. I like how it positions the audience as part of this journey, not as the usual bystander. One sequence that stood out is the one from the inn to the hospital - Maris lets herself be consumed by Sunshine, almost as if the creeping is part of the routine itself. The messaging gets confusing in the middle but ultimately ends in a tender moment of acceptance and determination. Iâ€™m just happy films like this finally exist in our country.

â€œStart strong, stay strong. You can do this.â€ But what happens when life throws you off balance? Sunshine is a powerful, no-frills story set in the gritty, chaotic streets of Manila. It follows a young gymnast whose future gets shaken when she finds out sheâ€™s pregnant. Antoinette Jadaone tells this story the way she does bestâ€”letting silence, glances, and small gestures speak louder than words. No drama for dramaâ€™s sake. Just raw, real moments. Maris Racal delivers a stunning performance.â€¦

Sunshine is a statement. Raw, delicate, and bold. It presents a social commentary on themes rarely explored yet deeply prevalent in the Philippine context. It dares to be radical. It dares to draw the line. When does the sun finally shine in a morally gray cloud of social disapproval?As linear and straightforward as the film appears, beneath it lies a complex character study â€” fearlessly told, thematically sharp, and emotionally unsettling. Antoinette Jadaone writes for women, and in a cinematic landscape like ours, we need more voices like hers. I was initially worried about where the story would go, but it was brave enough to take the harder path.This is Maris Racal's best performance yet â€” nuanced and quietly powerful. But it was Jennica Garcia who stole every scene she was in. She was the emotional anchor, the tearjerker. Some casting choices outside the leads, however, fell short. Certain scenes and narrative decisions could have landed harder with stronger performances or more fitting direction.That said, the editing needs work. The presence of a stunt double in certain scenes is obvious, breaking immersion. While the filmâ€™s visuals hauntingly capture a side of Manila we rarely see on screen, the sound design lacks polish. These flaws are noticeable but not deal-breaking.Still, this film succeeds in doing what few others do: it makes you ask what is ethical and what is not. It invites reflection. And when a film draws that line clearly for society to see, perhaps thatâ€™s when the sun truly begins to shine.

â€œgets ko naâ€the physical representation of sunshine making peace, letting go of her guilt, and getting complete reassurance in her decision, all in the form of the child she once detested, but in the end, loved, was honestly beautiful. there is so much love and strength with the child in understanding sunshineâ€™s dreams and circumstances, and how society was truly set against them; two females who were young girls at the end of the day. in a way, it reminded me of the popular thought prompt, â€œif my mother didnâ€™t have me, what kind of life would she have had?â€ itâ€™s a bittersweet thought at first, but there is such genuine love and understanding in seeing your mother past her caregiving responsibilities and wanting to witness her thrive as an independent woman with goals and ambitions, even if it meant losing your existence. however, there is also so much love and strength with sunshine deciding what would be best for both her and for the child, even if it hurt. sunshine loved the child enough to recognize that she didnâ€™t deserve to be brought into such a cruel world, not when her own mother was still navigating through it, barely managing to survive the horrors she was dealt with. she knew she wasnâ€™t ready at all and she didnâ€™t want her child to bear the brunt of it, given what she herself has went through. there is love and strength in choosing yourself, recognizing your weaknesses, and acknowledging that both you and your child deserve the best version of yourself; one that has wholeheartedly lived her dreams and life despite societal expectations and harsh realities and one that is ready to help her child to do just the same.despite all odds, naintindihan nila yung isaâ€™t isa. and out of love, for both themselves and for each other, they both let go.

since itâ€™s a filipino film, i was honestly expecting it to go the usual filipino route with a reductive take: pregnancy, unsuccessful abortion, realization & regrets, then continuing the pregnancy despite it all because abortion is murder. but as the story went on, i was surprised it took a more progressive approach yet still left room for familiar cultural and religious themes without pushing a moral agenda. i honestly had a nice watching experience and liked how it handled the topic.
